content.description: Catalonia is run by a couple of likely lads who’ve done their time in London - Brian Villahermosa of Salt Yard and Chris Winter of Embassy – and are back on our fair shores firing up a mix of classic and mod tapas.Their highly styled and sometimes rustic fare can be surprising (the grilled watermelon with cured duck breast is plain confusing) but for the most part the baseline is good cooking and slightly off-the-beaten-track dishes. Take the wagyu meatballs served with caramelised peach - sweet, syrupy acids cut the wagyu and sass up a normally standard tapa. The floor staff are particularly great: Jess Kilner, who used to rock the floor at Surry Hills hotspot Bodega, runs a bunch of young guys and gals serving up punchy sharing plates with plenty of attitude like discs of morcilla with asparagus and a deep fried duck’s egg which looks like a protein comet.The all-Spanish wine list is only just surpassed by the awesome cocktails. Put together by Tom Hoff, it covers all the usual suspects (Sours and Swizzles) but also features a sloe gin Conservative (the sloe is a type of bitter fruit similar to a plum found mainly in the UK but also in some parts of New Zealand) and a Martinez (gin, vermouth, bitters and Maraschino liqueur). There are a few seating options, too – upstairs is around 30 seats, the walls are papered in 70s style red and white patterns and features a corner bar while downstairs sees a couple of window benches inside and a whole lot of outside tables. Your best bet is to order cocktails and sit outside with some jamon and bread rubbed with tomato. There are a few fizzers - mixed nuts are curiously candied and the slow cooked pork belly could’ve stood a little more cooking (the fat wasn’t as rendered as we might’ve liked) - but a ratatouille served with little halves of quail’s eggs with golden yolks topped with cheese crisps is tangy and bright. A crème catalan (a bit like a crème brulee) with rice pudding ice cream is lovely but we can’t work out where the rice pudding is in the ice cream while churros with chocolate is a bit disappointing. Traditional churros (kind of like a Spanish donut but long) are often served with hot bitter chocolate. Here, they’re served with a layered white and milk chocolate mousse. We find dipping them into the catalan much tastier. There’s a ways to go here in terms of menu choices but all the groundwork is there – great staff, fantastic cocktails and a breezy deck (we love the jellyfish mural on the wall). And check out the giant spray paint robot-insect-clown murals on the toilet walls. Freaky.

This one's for all the blues and funk fans out there. The dark but classy Basement hosts a great live performance. No matter where you're standing you can hear the music, see the band and reach the bar. A great musical experience, be it jazz, blues or rock.

content.openingtimes: Tue–Fri 10am–6pm; Sat 11am–5pm; Sun 2pm–5pm or by app

content.description: High-end 20th- and 21st-century Australian art is the focus here, with an emphasis on paintings by such home-grown greats as Arthur Boyd and Sidney Nolan. Its varied programme includes solo shows and arresting thematic exhibitions. Bus 352, 378, 380, 389.

Undisputed home of Sydney rock‘n'roll, the ‘Dale combines the intimacy of a small-scale show with the electricity of the world's best performers. Owners Matt and Dan Rule host all varieties of pop, hip hop and acoustic shows. Some might say the only downfall is the plastic cups, but we know - it's for our safety.

The slogan says it all: "Good food, good wine, great live music." In the past, this popular Cronulla destination has played host to Sarah Blasko, The Whitlams and Little Birdy and continues to host a bevy of talented acts almost every night of the week. The menu is similarly delicious, featuring mezze and tapas dishes designed for sharing as well as a wine list that rivals that of many restaurants. Perhaps this Brass monkey is, in fact, gold.

Sure, you've attended the Gaelic Theatre primarily for kick-ass rock gigs - but they've recently expanded the brief to include damn near everything: dance parties, burlesque nights, and - best of all, for our purposes - quality comedy from big-name locals, touring acts and their monthly Off the Cuff improvisational comedy night.

If you're looking for a dingy dive bar in Newtown to hole up in with a few schooners, the Bank may not be for you. Since its makeover, the Bank has a fancy new interior, a better drinks list and a cleaner floor (a change that divides locals, who either love or hate their shiny new digs), but punters will find the vibe remains friendly, the service efficient and the bar food (courtesy of its subterranean restaurant Sumalee) authentically Thai-tinged. The crowd is a mixture of grungy locals, after-work professionals and a healthy influx of the inner west's gay and lesbian crowd. The space, all high ceilings and slick finishes, is split into sections catering for all your bar needs. There are pub meals like tasty steak sangas, but if you're in the mood to share, try the Thai tasting plate featuring coconut prawns and Thai pork sausages. Out the back, you'll find a sunny patch on the decked outdoor area and dedicated cocktail bar with a reasonably priced list. There are also rotating specials and classics are available if you ask nicely. If you linger late, upstairs houses a velvet-curtained bar full of dark corners and cosy seats for two.

Impressive local and international photography and new media feature in the ACP gallery; innovative video works are an increasingly regular highlight. Aspiring photographers can enrol in the centre’s various courses and hone their skills in its digital suite or darkroom. ACP also publishes the informative Photofile magazine. Bus 333, 352, 378, 380.
Tucked away in quiet Gymea is a gallery/arts studio/school/ and restaurant in one complex. The food is all about the simple things done well - fish n chips, burgers and big breakfasts.

Australian abstract painter Guy Warren and overseas artists such as Leon Kossoff and William Kentridge are some of the names to look out for. The gallery also has a strong selection of Aboriginal work, and pieces by the likes of Chagall and Miró. Bus 370, 470.
Viewings by app.

Expect mainly photography and, less regularly, sculpture, painting and mixed media over two floors in a converted Paddington terraced house. The annual exhibition of photography finalists in the national Walkley journalism awards is a highlight and there are new shows every three to four weeks. Bus 333, 352, 378, 380.

Part of Opera Quays, the smart shopping and dining strip between Circular Quay and the Sydney Opera House, this upmarket gallery shows works by European masters. Look out for originals by the likes of Chagall, Dalí, Miró, Picasso and Matisse. CityRail/ferry Circular Quay.
A street-art creative powerhouse, specialising in supporting emerging experimental artists.

address.street: Asia Australia Arts Centre Hay St
Asia Australia Arts Centre Hay St

content.description:
Tucked away down a Paddington side street, this highly regarded gallery features a diversity of Aboriginal art. Geographical variety is a particular strength: artists from the far north of Queensland, the Central and Western Deserts, Arnhem Land and Western Australia are all represented. Expect bark paintings, prints, woven work and carvings.
Bus 333, 352, 378, 380.

The Ivan Dougherty Gallery is temporarily closed and will be relocating shortly. Watch this space for updates.Part of the University of NSW College of Fine Arts, the Ivan Dougherty Gallery (or IDG for short) is known for challenging and diverse shows and a focus on professional rather than student work. Themed exhibitions often include a range of media, from design to video and sketches on paper. Those in search of quality student art will have to pick their moment ­– the only regular student (Master of Fine Arts) shows are in January and December. Bus 333, 378, 380.

Expect a strong experimental flavour and works from younger Australian artists at Kaliman. Colourful painting, installation works and new media feature frequently, from artists such as Del Kathryn Barton, the Kingpins and Ms & Mr.
CityRail Edgecliff then 5min walk or bus 389.

This building is a landmark of Bohemian Kings Cross and one-time residence of iconic Australian artists including Brett Whiteley and Martin Sharp. Its eye-catching yellow paintwork is said to represent Van Gogh’s unrealised ambition of having a home for artistic expression. Today it offers a strong selection of new work by emerging artists as well as curated exhibitions over two floors.
CityRail Kings Cross/bus 311.

The Rox has loads of comedy and cabaret, but their absolute don't-miss is the regular Red Card Comedy nights. Up to a dozen comedians get up with their best three minutes but – and here's where the cards come in – they have to win over the three judges from the audience, each of whom has a red card to hold up if they're not impressed. Two cards go up – one comedian leaves the stage. As a showcase of local comedy it's brilliant, but as an insight into human nature it's downright harrowing.

address.street: York St, cnr Market & York Sts
York St, cnr Market & York Sts

content.description: Rozelle is a legendary "pub-urb" full of colourful Sydney identities and cosmopolitan bars and restaurants, so if you're out west there are few better bars than the Welcome, a neck oilery everyone wishes was their local. This friendly, cosy Irish tavern serves delicous modern Euro cuisine and offers a heated courtyard that swings to trivia on Mondays, Saturday arvo bands and $15.50 roast-of-the-day and drink combos all week. Don't leave without trying a Speckled Hen, a beery brother to Guinness sans the cream.

There's a cockatoo perching on the leg of a guy who looks like he carries a flick knife in his back pocket and it's grooming the back of his head. "That's Josie," one of the ladies from the next table over offers, as Time Out goes to touch the giant bird. "Short for Josephine. She'll claw your eyes out if you're a girl and you get too close." Yikes. The Friend in Hand is so crammed with bric-a-brac, it's hard to make out the bar for all the mannequin legs, super soakers, bear traps and empty bird cages. There's even a Toohey's train that tootles its way around the top shelves of the bar. This Glebe institution is most famous, however, for the crab races that happen each week. Every Wednesday night at 7.30pm, hopefuls young and old crowd around the circular table to place bets on the sand crabs – first crab to make it to the edge wins. There's always plenty on at the Friend, but Sunday afternoon drinking sessions here are legendary and have nothing to do with organised events. You could take part in the life drawing classes if the mood took you, though. When it comes to what's on tap, their choices are pretty modest. There's Reschs and VB as well as Guinness and Coopers Pale but what they pour, they pour bloody well. They're also an early opener – that means you can get a beer at 6am on a Wednesday, for the truly devoted. This is a super fun pub. The beers are cold, the room's a cack and the bartenders are sweet as pie. Just watch out for Josephine.

Hotel William is a pub that suits all tastes. Have a laugh with the staff and enjoy the company of visitors from all over the world, whilst relaxing in the comfortable atmosphere. Fusion Bar on the second level has room for up to 200 people and is available for private functions.

The first season from Belvoir's new artistic director Ralph Myers is packed with big plays and big names - and comes with a new look and a new (as yet unnamed) company mascot. In the words of Neil Armfield at the launch: "Renewal - isn't it great?"
UPSTAIRS
The Wild Duckby Simon Stone, after Henrik IbsenDirected by Simon StoneHjalmar Ekdal's father was rich until scandal cast the family into poverty. Now he lives in a tiny flat with his father, his wife Gina, his daughter Hedvig and a duck. And there's about to be a new member of the household. Gregers Werle is an idealist who has been living on a mountaintop for the last 15 years and he has just returned to town with a secret that could shatter the little world Hjalmar has built around himself.The Wild Duck is an intricate study of family life from that master dramatist of family life, Henrik Ibsen. The production will star a couple of our favourite Sydney thespians: two of the Three Blind Mice, Toby Schmitz and Ewen Leslie. (The third blind mouse is conspicuously absent.) It's to be directed by Simon Stone, who Ralph Myers calls "the hottest young director in the country in inverted commas". Earlier this year Stone directed The Promise, also in the Upstairs Theatre and starring Ewen Leslie. Last year he adapted Ibsen's 1894 drama Little Eyolf into The Only Child, a bold production - full of emotional and physical nakedness - in which most of the action happened in a bathtub.
Jack Charles v the Crownby Jack Charles and John RomerilDirected by Rachael Maza LongFrom Stolen Generation to Koori theatre in the 70s, from film sets to Her Majesty's prisons, Jack Charles v the Crown runs the gamut of a life lived to its utmost. Charles's unswerving optimism transforms this tale of addiction, crime and doing time into a kind of vagabond's progress - a map of the traps of dispossession and a guide to reaching the age of grey-haired wisdom.Star of The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Koori elder, founder of the first Aboriginal theatre company and former heroin addict - Jack Charles has a heck of a story to tell. Part of it was told in Bastardy, a 1972 play by John Romeril; part of it was told in the confronting documentary of a few years ago, also called Bastardy, which followed Charles for seven years. Uncle Jack Charles v the Crown is the next chapter, as told by Jack Charles himself, with playwright John Romeril back to lend a guiding hand on the script. The one-man show will be directed by Torres Strait Islander Rachael Maza Long.
The BusinessBased on Vassa Zheleznova by Maxim GorkyAdapted by Jonathan Gavin with Cristabel SvedDirected by Cristabel SvedOur central character is a woman who grew up poor, clawed her way out, and built an empire in the outer suburbs. But her salad days in middle Australia are under threat. The world is accelerating into the future, her husband is on his last legs, and the kids smell blood. Now is the time for a spectacular generational showdown over who gets the prize.Cristabel Sved directed the recent production of Parlour Song and Martin McDonagh's brutally funny Beauty Queen of Leenane; Jonathan Gavin wrote Bang!, a mighty play that went off in the Downstairs Theatre in June 2010. Together, they've come up with a new translation of Maxim Gorky's portrait of a dysfunctional family, The Business, re-setting it in politically incorrect 1980s Australia. In Sved's words, it's a wild, dark comedy that threatens to turn into a farce or melodrama at any moment. It stars Sarah Peirse, who made a knockout Home Secretary in 2009's Gethsemane.
The Seagullby Anton ChekhovDirected by Benedict AndrewsThe Seagull is Chekhov's extraordinary gathering of a group of bruised and incandescent dreamers who cannot, no matter how they try, get what they want. It's also one of the masterpieces of theatre about theatre, an exploration of how telling stories and coining symbols interacts with life. By turns elevated and scrappy, gorgeous and mundane, The Seagull is a vision of humanity enduring in the presence of eternity.The visionary director of Company B's Measure for Measure and STC's War of the Roses, Benedict Andrews, is a man whose very name tends to strike equal parts terror and excitement in the hearts of most Sydney theatregoers. Here he'll be turning his fierce imagination and steely gaze (take a look at his headshot in the theatre programmes - the man doesn't sleep) to another champion of new theatrical experiences, Anton Chekhov (Uncle Vanya). The Seagull is a play about love, in all its guises, and a "masterpiece of theatre about theatre". It's a terrific all-star cast: Maeve Dermody, John Gaden, Gareth Davies, Emily Barclay and, back on the boards at last, the legendary Judy Davis.
Neighbourhood Watchby Lally KatzDirected by Simon StoneAnd God said: Thou shalt love thy neighbour. He obviously hadn't reckoned on Eva. Eva is a battle-hardened Hungarian-Australian veteran of the twentieth century. Catherine is her neighbour: twenty-something and waiting for a better world. The question is, will their unlikely friendship outlive the colossal forces of history, the inevitability of death, and a trip to the mall to see Mamma Mia?Playwright Lally Katz hopefully won't mind us saying that she is a mad woman. She brought a female Frankenstein to the stage, collaborated with Hilary Bell on the magical The Mysteries: Genesis and dreamed up one of the more frightening creations to take the stage in recent years, the Apocalypse Bear. Neighbourhood Watch is her latest play, with a part performed by, and written specifically for, the wonderful Robyn Nevin (last seen as the drifting matriarch in Long Day's Journey into Night). It's the product of the two years Katz spent with a real-life Eva - talking to her, cleaning out her birdcage, that kind of thing. Nevin urged Katz to write a part for her that was "tough and funny" - Neighbourhood Watch will surely be both.
Human Interest StoryChoreographed by Lucy GuerinOur world is saturated with news. Torrents of information transport us from battlefields to crime scenes, from celebrity homes to our own backyards. But how does this unending flow of information shape us?Human Interest Story had its debut at Melbourne's Malthouse Theatre in July 2010. It is, in Myers' words, "not a play but a piece of theatre" that finds its inspiration from a most unlikely source: news, current affairs and the mass media. It's the brainchild of Lucy Guerin, and takes place in a set designed by Guerin's partner, Gideon Obarzanek, who masterminded the dance/light show Mortal Engine that played Sydney Theatre earlier in the year. It's a dance work with a sense of fun and a sense of humour, featuring - how many dance works can you say this about? - a special newscast from SBS newsreader Anton Enus.
Summer of the Seventeenth Dollby Ray LawlerDirected by Neil ArmfieldEvery summer, Barney and Roo have come back from the Queensland canefields to the Carlton house they share with Nancy and Olive for their annual season of leisure. This year though, Nancy's gone and got married, and Pearl's taking her place..."After 17 years as artistic director at Belvoir," the season brochure tells us, "Neil Armfield directs the play about how, after 17 years, all good things must come to an end." Summer of the Seventeenth Doll is an absolute classic of the Australian stage - if you haven't seen it, chances are you've studied it - and Armfield, as the brochure hints, will be in a unique position to tell a story about change: the pain, the excitement, and the danger of fighting it. The production will feature the singular talents of actors Dan Wyllie - you will surely have seen him on stage in The Pillowman and Cloudstreet, or on screen in Love My Way and Underbelly - and Robyn Nevin. That's right: two separate Robyn Nevin performances on the same stage in a matter of months.
As You Like Itby William ShakespeareDirected by Eamon FlackThe Forest of Arden: Orlando loves Rosalind. Rosalind is disguised as a boy called Ganymede. Phebe loves Ganymede. Silvius loves Phebe. Rosalind loves Orlando back. Oliver is hunting Orlando. Celia loves Oliver. Celia is disguised as Aliena. The Duke is hunting Celia. The other Duke is hunting deer. Jaques loves the deer. Touchstone is freaked out by Jaques. Audrey loves Touchstone. Touchstone loves words... It turns out to be quite a hard play to describe. In the end there's a wedding and they all go home.Eamon Flack is the genius that had the bright idea of staging A Midsummer Night's Dream in the tiny Downstairs Theatre in 2009 (and, for something completely different, Beckett's moody The End in 2010). He is, as such, the perfect choice to direct As You Like It, one of Shakespeare's loopier rom coms - the play that gave the world Shakespeare's 'Seven Ages of Man' speech. In the cast, Charlie Garber and Gareth Davies, who took turns stealing the show from the cast and each other in that aforementioned Midsummer Night, will be joined by Alison Bell (The Promise, Rabbit... best not mention that ABC2 programme she did) and Shelly Lauman.
DOWNSTAIRS
In 2011, Belvoir will be producing plays in its remarkable, and remarkably intimate, Downstairs space. Cut (by Duncan Graham, directed by Sarah John) will mash up fantasy and reality, thought and action in a one-woman show. The Kiss (by Anton Chekhov, Kate Chopin, Peter Goldsworthy and Guy de Maupassant, directed by Yellow Moon director Susanna Dowling) will be an ambitious word-for-word staging of four short stories (all called 'The Kiss') that takes a leaf out of the book of Gatz, the Sydney Festival 2009 hit that staged The Great Gatsby in its entirety. Windmill Baby (by David Milroy, directed by The Sapphires star Kylie Farmer) is the story of Black Australians in the service of White Australia - and a love story. And They Called Him Mr Glamour (by Gareth Davies, directed by Thomas Wright and starring Davies) is Davies' one-man show that sounds like the result of his descent into madness. Finally, The Dark Room (by Angela Betzein, directed by Leticia Caceres): a time-warping thriller that will mark Brendan Cowell's first-ever performance on a Belvoir stage. Darryn King
Become a Belvoir season ticket holder and save up to $144. For more about the 2011 season and lots else besides, visit Belvoir.
content.openingtimes: Box office: Mon 9.30am-6pm, Tues 9.30a,-6.30pm, Wed-Sat 9.30am-8pm, Sun 2.30pm-5pm

content.description: Located amid the flurry and culinary excitement of Sydney's Chinatown, the Capitol Theatre hosts long-running blockbuster musicals such as The Lion King, Wicked and Guys & Dolls. The original 1928 building was renovated in 1995.

Located on the water at Kirribilli, the Ensemble Theatre is a non-profit company dedicated to producing professional theatre of the highest standard. The Ensemble does not receive government funding and yet puts on an outstanding programme of plays every year for a large and supportive audience. Well-loved Australian actors such as Tara Morice, Alex Dimitriades, Amanda Muggleton and Henri Szeps frequently perform there in new and classic plays.
Bookings: MCA TIX (www.mca-tix.com 1300 306 776)
content.openingtimes: Box office: one hour prior to show.

content.description: As well as regular theatre productions, the 400-seat Glen St Theatre puts on a host of children's shows, community events and concerts, with Sorlies Restaurant also inside to provide pre-theatre dining.

Tucked in among King St cafés and antique shops is this gem. Tatty décor and a general air of wear and tear only add to the charm of one of the longest running theatre company in NSW. Staging a mixture of contemporary and classic, it's perfect for a vintage night out. Bookings: MCA Tix (1300 306 776)

address.street: University of Sydney, Cnr Cleveland St & City Rd
University of Sydney, Cnr Cleveland St & City Rd

content.description: Seymour Centre houses a number of venues including York Theatre, Everest Theatre and Downstairs Theatre. Performances are also held in the foyers and courtyard.
content.openingtimes: Box Office: Mon–Fri 9am–5pm; Sat 11am–3pm; one hour prior to performance.

content.description: TAP Gallery is an art centre and function house with an ancillary organic cafe regularly featuring art exhibitions, independent theatre productions, film nights, sketch club, hen's nights and private events. All are part of the week to week activities at TAP gallery.

Bertoni is full of provincial delights, pre-eminent among them the coffee: the Bertoni house brand. It's an Arabica blend of four beans in classic southern Italian style; strong, sexy and super-charged (this is the spikiest flat white in town) and it comes with almond biscotti riding the shotgun. Weekends find queues snaking into the street fighting for their communal tables and milk crates. Most go for the ooh-la-lasagne! Made from a 150-year-old, closely guarded family recipe, Mama Maria's luscious sheets of pasta encase sweet meats and molten cheese to die for.

Water views meet inspired Middle Eastern flavours in this Turkish delight. They silver serve every single mezze here, down to boreks and baklava which at first is a little strange, but you get used to it quick snips.
content.openingtimes:
Lunch Wed-Fri & Sun from 12pm; Dinner Wed-Sat from 6pm;
(Mon-Tue & Sun for large groups and functions; bookings essential)

content.description: Now that Pho Pasteur down near central has gone down hill this is the next best bet. They serve basil with their beef noodle soup (instead of the ubiquitous mint) and their broth is beefier than most in the city. There's no lemon soda and it's very basic but it does the business for a quick mid-week lunch

This is about the most fitting name for a restaurant we’ve ever seen – none of this naming-a-restaurant-after-a-dish-not-on-the-menu hooey (we’re looking at you, Blancmange), the Red Chilli restaurant is all about the red-hot fruit and plenty of it. You wouldn’t call this food sexy but we’re not talking about fine dining here – we’re talking about getting down and dirty with Sichuanese. Red Chilli’s preserved eggs blob away in a mire of oil and chilli and their squishy cubes of silken tofu are a mix of turquoise-coloured jellied egg and volcanic oil topped with a generous handful of green onion. The creaminess of the preserved egg almost acts as a barrier against the slow-building, intense burn coming from all that chilli. In a plate of dried whole chillies nests a cluster of deep-fried chicken pieces covered in Sichuan pepper – they’re not exactly spicy but they’ve got a cold burn to them – the type of burn that only Sichuan pepper can provide. It makes you feel like the sides of your mouth have melted but the fun of this dish is in fishing out the little pieces of chicken without coming head to head with the dried chilli. Green beans with fried pork mince is always a house favourite but if you really want to pull out the big snacking guns, order the deep fried pumpkin in duck egg yolk – the shards are sweet and salty, squishy in the middle and crisp on the outside – they’re especially good for vegetarians (at least, not particularly fussy vegetarians – duck eggs can be a deal breaker with the more hardcore veggos because they mate for life... the ducks, that is). Come to Red Chilli for the décor and you’ll leave disappointed. This is a restaurant for those who like to eat, not recline in Eames chairs and comment on textured wallpaper. Even the toilets have a character of their own (read: doors hanging on by the teeth). Don’t bother with the steamboat upstairs, either – level one is where the real magic happens, as long as you order specifically and like it hot. If eating tasty snacks is your top priority, you’ll revel here. If glam service and surrounds aren’t a must, the fact remains: this is some of Sydney’s best Sichuan food. Licensed, around $30pp.

Dumplings are the go here, though their noodle soups are nothing to sniff at either. The room’s pretty stark with an eerie blue glow (no need for the ‘No Cash Kept On Premises’ sign – this light’s more than enough) but the food’s great. Try the Peking duck pancake.

Take a round trip from Rose Bay, over Sydney Harbour, through to Bondi Beach and back to Catalina for lunch. Marked by the amazing view over Rose Bay and exceptional wine list, they specialise in seafood but also do gutsy French classics like pigs head with sauce gribiche. They also have their own sushi chef who'll slice you a piece of fish faster than you can say mushi mushi.

The rain in Spain is falling mainly in the Hills, it seems. There’s the more traditional yet slightly touristy El Bulli on Elizabeth St, Bentley Bar’s loopy molecular take on Crown St, Bodega’s rock ‘n’ roll tapas off Foveux and now there’s Cru54 who have managed to take the best from all the aforementioned, slick and shine it up and reduce the noise. Try the calvados apples and chorizo on skewers. Though the chorizo isn’t as moist and flavour-laden with fatty goodness as you might hope, it’s still very tasty. Then there’s the light, airy mashed potato tainted with jamon then deep-fried until crisp on the outside and ultra fluffy and hammy on the inside. And the tortilla layered with wafer thin slices of potato. But what’s this? Russian salad? Strangely and mysteriously, it’s incredibly popular in Spain (known as ensaladilla rusa) and with good reason: it’s delicious. Tiny cubes of potato are mixed through with capers, piquillo peppers and pieces of prawn. And if the thought of braised lettuce sends you as crazy as it does us, try the cos lettuce – it’s encasing pieces of soft, sweet apple and melt-in-the-mouth morcilla (that’s blood sausage, folks). The room is simple – white walls, tables and bars with a large feature light hanging down in the middle of the room like an angler fish looking for snacks – each metal prong is equipped with its own little light. And the menu is concise – there’s a few smaller tapa; crunchy, slightly waxy roasted almonds, marinated olives and white anchovies – and some bustier dishes like the heart of palm and Ortiz (that company who do the excellent anchovies) tuna salad. And though it’s raining like the clappers outside when we’re there – sheets of water slapping against Foveaux Street, waves crashing on the tiles outside the pubs and sodden locals running for shelter as garbage spews from the drains and rats run for higher ground – inside Cru54, it’s calm. We’re greeted on arrival with clean, warm tea towels with which to dry off and a fat glass of tempranillo as we drip all over the polished concrete floor. Impressive touch. One of the most interesting sounding dishes is the calamari with squid ink crumbs and aioli – the squid is lightly grilled and very tender and the idea is that you dip the squid into the aioli then sprinkle the ink crumbs on top. It’s a nice idea but actually not as interesting in practice. It’s also easily forgotten when you’re sitting in front of the banana pain perdu. Basically banana bread fried and crusted in sugar, it comes with a splodge of chocolate ganache (that’s simply chocolate whipped with hot water and crumbled with sea salt flakes), topped with a rough chop of toasted almond and the tiniest drizzle of olive oil. It’s a balanced, beautiful dessert. Unpretentious, unassuming and worth a wander down Foveaux for. Licensed, around $55pp, including wine.

Best for Old school, lo-fi, high-impact pizzeria plying Crown Street with sensational straight-up pizzas for over a decade. A fave of musos recording at bigjesusburger studios on Riley Street (Wolfmother, You Am I). What to order Dimitris Special - balances shaved meats and sliced veg with plenty o' mozz and no pineapple. Go half-n-half with a Mexicana (salami, jalapenos and chilli) for a double-shot of no frills thrills. Atmosphere Rocking, mellow. Comfy couches, tables for knees-together couples, counter for lone wolves and a boho back alley. Extras The pastas are just as good. Get a table Or don't. The Gaslight will let you bring Dimitris pizzas in. BYO, around $15pp.

The giant, wall sized blackboard menu may indeed be written completely in Italian, but it’s pretty easy to get the gist – especially when you’re having it explained to you by a bunch of swarthy Italian men dressed in fi gure hugging black. The minute steak is grouse, as is the fried calamari with aioli.

There are outlets of this very stylish chain all around the world. Essentially a very large bakery, they do basic sit-down breakfasts like bowls of strong coffee and croissants toasted with ham and gruyere cheese as well as googy eggs with saffron yolks and assorted bread soldiers (there’s even a fruit one in there which was a bit weird). Don’t miss the chocolate brownies.

Matt Kemp does the Franglais (mixing up French and British cuisine) thing better than anyone in town. There’s fluffy, crisp potatoes cooked in dripping (that’s beef fat to youse) on the menu at the moment, as well as a cracker of a wagyu pie topped with discs of squishy bone marrow. The value’s sound and that’s before you try the famous pre-Ritz special – two courses for $55. C’est magnifique, innit?
content.openingtimes:
Lunch: Fri 12noon–2pm; Dinner: Tue–Sat 6pm–10pm;
Last Sun of every month Seasonal Degustation Evening – 6.30-10pm

content.description: Rise Restaurant fuses East and West flavours to create zesty dishes which are as colourful as the restaurant’s vibrant surroundings.

Sean's Panaroma: a Sydney dining icon (recently painted marshmallow pink) famed for chef Sean Moran's herbal, breezy cooking, expert restraint and sweet skills. Petersham Nursery: a restaurant set in a nursery just out of London famed for Skye Gyngell's Italian leaning laissez-faire cooking, combining bright flavours and simple technique.
Sean Moran and Skye Gyngell are mates who have been working on this restaurant swap for quite some time. There's similar food brains at work here, where fresh flavours and very little handling shine through, letting ingredients speak for themselves but that's where the similarities end. With Gyngell at the helm, we start with a fantastically chunky, rustic porcini, potato and rosemary soup finished with a little parmesan.
Carpaccio of kingfish with shaved fennel and a light drizzle of chilli oil could do with a little acidity to lift it up while a salad of rocket and goat's curd with roast J-chokes (Jerusalem artichokes) sees beautifully dressed leaves catching some sweetness from roast tomatoes. The ocean trout with horseradish cream is fine but it's a little surprising to pay $26 when the pin bones haven't been taken out of it properly, while the squab (fancy talk for pigeon) is a favourite at the table. Served on a bed of barley, cavolo nero and a hint of anchovy and parmesan, it's a great example of the rustic Italian stuff that really gives Gyngell's food its guts. The veggo offering - a warm salad of asparagus, broad beans and spinach - though simple, is buffed up with crème fraiche and a slightly crunchy sauce of almonds, garlic and olive oil.
Mains fall down with the rare fillet of beef - it's so rare it's room temperature and raw in the middle - this would be totally fine if it were served in thin slices but a big chunk of it is slightly yucky. The accompaniment of chickpeas, pumpkin and salsa verde, however, is exceptional.
Dessert evens out the stakes - especially the lemon ice cream and the taste-sensational combination of slices of perfectly ripe blood oranges sweetened with a drizzle of honey spiked with rosemary.
There's nothing wrong with Skye Gyngell's food. The flavour profiles are bang-on and there are plenty of interesting things going on plateside, but when it comes to basic technique and attention to detail (both essential assets at the $40-plus-a-main level in this city), there's a lot wanting. If Sean's is a favourite for you, you may find yourself hankering after the real deal with the food here but if you're a fan of Skye's books, this is a great opportunity to try her food in person. She's banging the pans at Sean's until the end of September.
Licensed & BYO, around $110pp.

It's the best of everything in the restaurant, all on one plate. We love eating everything compartmentalised on a little silver tray – it's the only way to ensure our food items don't touch each other. Hey, don't judge us.

Sheep's heads - you either love ‘em or you're downright revolted by the idea of pulling the well-done brains and eyeballs out of a skull that still has teeth. There's not much meat on it but what there is, is incredibly flavoursome. All that intramuscular tissue stands up to a culinary caning. But we're obviously not dealing with our sheep skull in the correct way - while we're picking at the meat with forks, the table next to us are dislocating the thing like surgeons. Or hit men. It's not all skullduggery and Retsina - there's plenty of other stuff on the Corinthian Rotisserie menu that isn't served with its own teeth. Start with a Greek salad - big chunks of fetta served with thin slices of raw onion, kalamata olives, tomato quarters, shreds of iceberg, pickled chillies and rounds of cucumber - bright, vinegar-y and fresh, it's what you want by your side when the serious stuff starts to arrive. A cold platter of pickled octopus, skordalia (that's a dip made from potato, garlic, almonds and olive oil) and fresh, briny sardines served with spears of cucumber and pickles is a great way to start, or try the hot version. Grilled haloumi, deep-fried baby squid, dolmades and octopus tentacles, all served with chunks of lemon. Retsina is a Greek wine where pieces of pine resin are added during the wine making process giving it a rather pungent (read: Pine-O-Cleen) flavour. For the uninitiated, it can be a little like drinking battery acid but once you're used to it, it ‘s quite pleasant. It's worth trying at least once - it'll put hair on your chest, if nothing else. If it's the Greek experience you're after, the Corinthian takes on all comers. There are others that go highbrow, but here it's so old-school it practically wrote the book on it - red and white checked tablecloths are covered in clear plastic, big murals on the walls depict women being serenaded by sheep farming bouzouki players, Laminex tables and wood panelling everywhere. Sideways, try the peas slow braised with tomato or broad beans cooked simply and a perfect accompaniment to a large platter of mixed grilled meat like crisp skinned pork, slice of tender garlicky lamb and pieces of chicken rubbed in oregano. The servings are huge - there's enough food on any of these plates for six people or four with an eye to take food home to last through the apocalypse. The baklava is just the right mix of sticky, squishy and firm without being too honey-sweet or wet - a fairly difficult balance to get right. And while dessert may be the last thing on your mind after your festival of meat, it's great with a syrupy strong Greek coffee on the side. What this restaurant does well is the simple fare. Food that's basic, traditional and very homely. You won't find anything tricked up, foamed or soiled here - just honest earthy dishes made with care. And it's cheap, too.

Surf 'n' turf - scallops ‘n' pork belly. Reef 'n' beef - chorizo ‘n' squid. The meeting of the animal proteins of the land and sea has a venerable history both here and around the world. And we're not just talking eating pies at the beach either. That said, the union of the rabbit and fish may not yet have come - but if you want to consider the situation up close, make a bee line for The Codfather. The Codfather is a year-old restaurant on Stanmore's main drag owned by Ross Godfrey (he's the same guy who owns Newtown's Oscillate Wildly). Where Oscillate Wildly is known for its out-there menu (think lots of soils, smears and snows), the cooking at The Codfather's takes place in their strangely enormous kitchen, and with its seafood focus, is generally a straighter affair. Sit down here and you're offered chickpea battered deep-fried mussels as a complimentary appetiser. "Salty," as the actress said to the bishop, "but good". Entrees run from a healthy serve of steamed Boston Bay mussels in a very soupy saffron-tinged tomato sauce with grilled toast on the side to a very straight-down-the-line vego entrée of a big crunchy felafel with slices of beetroot and yoghurt-tinged cheese and tangy orange oil. All good. The mains throw curve balls. The fish curry of blue eye trevalla is more a curry-crusted number than the richer, moister offering you picture. Crisp-skinned Clarence sand whiting is served with vanilla-poached quince, walnuts and watercress. The fish is dandy but the accompaniment might bring to mind a cheese plate more than a seafood course for some. And then comes the bunny. It features in a pie - one of those ramekins topped with pastry, braised shreds of the meat with a scattering of partially dried grapes. The fish - again blue eye trevalla - sits on the other side of the plate napped with a splash of mustard-seed dressing and crowned with a thatch of deep fried sage leaves. It's beautifully cooked, the flakes falling fatly under the knife to reveal a nice juicy interior. The pie is also quite nice. However, why they're on the same plate is the only thing that's unclear. Odd, yes - but not a deal-breaker. Service and desserts are just fine if not endearing in and of themselves. But there's a lot to like about the room, even if the slightly jaundiced glow from a ropey feature light is a little disconcerting. The large graffiti mural on one wall is totally "ghetto" and the touches of whimsy such as the hand-drawn individual piscine placemats make it all the more likeable. The cooking is sound, though some of the combinations are something of a stretch. It might not be an offer you can't refuse but it's no horse's head in the bed, either.
As Lebanese as you’ll fi nd outside the Middle East and bung in the heartlands of the inner west. It’s the rose water Turkish delight we hold so dear, not to mention the cracker baba ganoush.

It's a tiny, blink-and-you'll-miss-it type cafe on screaming loud Harris Street in Ultimo. The roti is unbelievable, and they do all the usual Malaysian hawker favourites like chicken curry and roti or nasi lemak. Get your fix of Malaysian telly while you're at it.

The specials are written in texta on bits of paper around the tiny room. There's a guy in a partitioned corner of the restaurants rolling and stretching noodles. The shallot pancake is as light as anything as well as finger-scaldingly hot and crisp around the edges.

Perched right near the Balmain wharf, this winsome little sandstone restaurant does classic French fare- stiff white tablecloths and all. Try the duck terrine or assiette of rabbit. For something with a little more grunt, maybe the pan-fried skate with braised ox tail.

Crown Street may have plenty of Indian restaurants, but this is one of the better ones. And it’s vegetarian, too. Have the vegetable dosi or maybe dhal and a couple of naan. They also specialise in Indian sweets.

You can't miss it if you're driving along the Princes Highway - it's a massive old building teetering just on the edge of the road. You'll find all your usual Canto favourites here and very decent yum cha during the day.
content.openingtimes: Lunch: Mon-Fri 11am-3pm, Sat-Sun 10am-3pm. Dinner: Mon-Fri 11am-3pm, Sat-Sun 5.30pm-10.30pm.

content.description: Standing solid for 50 odd years just right off Tom Ugly’s Bridge in the heartland of Sylvania is this old school burger joint. The straight burger is a little lacklustre so order The Lot – grilled pineapple, bacon, a fried egg and melted packet cheese all on a soft sesame seed bun. There’s no time to ponder fromage plastique over vanilla milkshakes or fresh pineapple crush – as soon as you enter what looks like a 1970s milk bar you’re faced with someone patrolling the line taking orders and you’ve gotta think quick. The best solution is to play it straight (the lot, the lot or the lot) with a milkshake (stock standard) and chips (DIY packet salt in a paper bag) then stroll down to the jetty a few minutes away to enjoy. What makes this burger so special is the fact it’s completely unexceptional and utterly Aussie old school. There’s no sign of wagyu slaughtered by virgins under a half moon, organic sourdough buns baked fresh by midgets, eggs handplucked from the feathered freckles of broody Bolivian hens or manicured chips handcarved from the vegetated womb of golden-hued potatoes. Yet, for all its working class grunt you’ll still be lucky to get a park at Paul’s at lunchtime on weekends, such is its fanbase of truckies, teenagers and road-weary family wagoners.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Tues closed, Wed-Fri 11.30am-9pm, Sat-Sun 11.30am-7pm, 8pm during daylight savings

content.description: The best Malaysian this side of Botany Bay. Order ahead for their fishhead curry and better still, their black pepper crab.

The number one dish in the world - fried rice sqaures with vegetables and tomatoe sauce- may have the coolest name, but the soup filled dumplings are our favorites. Soup filled dumplings take skill to eat- gently bite off the top and wait till the soup cools slightly before tackling. Or if you've got lava lips, down the whole thing in one fell swoop. There's plenty to choose from here, but the dumplings are king.

You might see the likes of fresh shucked Sydney rock oysters or quail cooked in master stock, not to mention surf ‘n’ turf dishes like pork belly and smoked haddock on chef Nathan Tillot’s menu. Think open plan, polished concrete and lowlighting.

With its flaking burgundy paint job and cracking view of the petrol pumps across the road, Strangers with Candy's tatty urban charm won't instantly appeal to everyone. Cosy and buzzing with table chatter, it's hard not to feel at home here under the corrugated plastic roof of the courtyard out back. Couples talk intently across the tea lights at most tables, interspersed with two or three noisier groups of six and staff are warm, quick with service and always nearby at the right time.Standing out against this casual, comfy backdrop is the food - the slow-cooked pork belly with spiced green papaya strips is a rich, sweet and sizeable slab. Lighter are the steamed prawn wontons with Chinese mushrooms in a sesame and lemongrass broth with coriander pesto, though not in terms of word-count. The duck confit with apple and ginger agrodolce (the Italian version of sweet and sour sauce) is tender and hearty. More delicate is the spaghettini, with its chilli zing stopping nicely short of overpowering a bumper crop of blue swimmer crab meat. Bringing up the rear is the tea-smoked salmon with panzanella (an Italian bread salad). The panzanella - chopped tomatoes, cheese and small pieces of bread - is like eating a salad pizza. Desserts here are comfort food rather than clever and are big enough for two, like the sauternes custard with fresh raspberries and burnt caramel.Ultimately, the shabby-but-chic décor, creative menu and mellow atmosphere add up to a very interesting whole. Rough around the edges but polished where it counts, this is a real gem. Nicola Steerforth
Licensed, around $50pp.
content.openingtimes: Brunch and lunch: Sat-Sun 9:30am-3:30pm. Dinner: Wed-Sat 6pm-9:30pm.

content.description: No, it’s not American football, at least not in Sutherland. It is, however a Chinese restaurant chain that not only does a decent line in fresh juices and health shakes, but also pork noodles and Chinese broccoli – a safe lunch choice.

address.street: Via east or west public wharves
Via east or west public wharves

content.description:
You're driving down a perilous road with a sheer cliff face on one side and a very long drop down the other. Cicadas are screaming in unison, rubbing their wings together in a Sydney summer symphony. Back in the days of Gay Bilson and Janni Kyritsis (the chef-owner combo that made Berowra the legend it is today) Berowra Waters was the only good restaurant in Sydney. Imagine now the hour-long drive back to the harbour from the Hawkesbury before random breath tests. There's no land access to the actual restaurant but the waiting for the restaurant's own ferryman to take you for a ride from the wharf is part of the adventure. Once upon a time they'd greet you onboard with a glass of Champagne. These days, a guy in a Drizabone and an Akubra greets you. The boat's the same though, with new touches like blackbutt decks and engine. The building is something else entirely. Designed by legendary Australian architect Glen Murcutt, the main wall looking out to the river is made up of glass louvres that reflect the water at the same time as the rock face while the room itself is light, airy and open and works in harmony with its outside environment. Chef Dietmar Sawyere's food is as much about being simple as it is studied, artful and styled. Two little nubs of peppery, creamy spinach and ricotta (a bit like nude ravioli) are balanced with sweet yabby tails, a scatter of crisp, deep fried sage leaves and a perfect dice of tangy tomato. The whole idea with this menu is to make a Choose Your Own Adventure degustation with a choice between four, five or six courses (they're quite small so you'll need four or five) with the dishes travelling from lighter to heavier proteins. The brined-then-roasted quail with delicate little spears of white asparagus and micro-herbs is given backbone with fine slices of morel mushrooms and is five bites of pure heaven. Cigars of duck confit (duck slow cooked in fat and shredded finely) are wrapped in a crisp north-African style pastry and brightened with ultra fine shreds of baby cabbage. The winner though is the wagyu sirloin (with a marbling-AKA fat-score of eight, folks) that melts in the mouth with flavour that travels on and on. Dietmar's version of the onion ring is three little rounds of shallot and just to really add some junk in the trunk is the truffled potato butter - the nod to the potato is as much as a stick of butter sitting on the same kitchen bench. Phwoar. It's not just the food that makes this place special (although it helps) it's the feeling of it being absolutely secluded from everything else around and being served by the type of ultra professional crew who don't even wiggle an eyebrow when one of us knocks an entire glass of Alsatian pinot gris into the goat's cheese ravioli with pumpkin broth. They just bring another glass of wine. Bless 'em. Desserts are interesting without being especially memorable (the cheese plate is worth a run, though). A Dutch carrot poached in cardamom water then covered in milk chocolate perched on top of a half sphere of an ultra light carrot cake with a perfect quenelle of ginger sorbet on the side is the tastiest thing here, though the sqooshy Valrhona chocolate tart is nothing to sniff at either. There are times when we sit with our plates in front of us and our water glasses go unfilled. But not for long. And when you look out through the louvers and see mist gathering around the mountains and Sydney rock oysters clinging to the shores of the river while rain softly falls and the fans cut air silently in a restaurant burbling with satisfaction, it doesn't matter at all. MR Licensed, around $250 pp, including wine. The BWI all stars The original Berowra Waters Inn saw many of its staff go on to great things. Here is the alumni in alphabetical order:
Alex Herbert (Bird Cow Fish) Barry McDonald (Fratelli Fresh) Chris Whitehead (Ivy) Janni Kyritsis (Ex MG Garage) Judy McMahon (Co owner, Catalina) Laif Etournaud (Onde) Neil Perry (Rockpool) Nick Hildebrandt (Bentley Restaurant & Bar) Sean Moran (Sean's Panaroma) Tony Bilson (Bilson's)

Inside or out, this traditional tapas-slash-wine bar is a dark little treasure trove of treats, including a bottle shop featuring a stunning range of Spanish wines that you can buy then try on premises. Sommelier Ben Moechtar also heads up the Australian Sommeliers Association, so you can rest assured you’re in safe hands when it comes to the vino. The redand- black-decorated space with its huge exterior blackboard menu is a complete eye-catcher and there’s plenty of outdoor seating too. No longer stocking just bocadillos and tins of sardines behind the counter, there’s now a tapas menu fi lled with delicious goodies like chorizo and chimichurri or churros

There are a pair of sandals at least two sizes too small next to our table. "These aren't for what we think they are, are they?" we ask, eyeing off the little wooden shoes. "Oh yes, the bathrooms are upstairs, if you dare". Clopping proudly up the stairs half crippled trying to keep those little shoes on is one thing. Getting back down the stairs is another. Welcome to Shimbashi. The restaurant itself is broken into two parts - a soba noodle house and ju ge mu which specialises in okonomiyaki and teppanyaki. But you can also order things from either part of the restaurant. In the soba house, you'll find low tables with a little bridge running along dividing each table - you'll need to take off your shoes and then clamber in as gracefully as you can. The menu's huge and if you're not confident with Japanese food, the wait staff is there to help. Soba chips - salty, deep fried noodles - are a more exciting offering on the page than on the plate whereas agedashi tofu (that's deep fried tofu in a dashi broth topped with bonito flakes and seaweed) is exceptional. For the most part, the food here is great - eggplant is slow cooked and topped with sweet miso and a smattering of sesame seeds and turns to goo as soon as it's touched with a chopstick and a Japanese pancake (okonomi-yaki) filled with pork and plump prawns is artfully squiggled in Japanese mayo. The fried rice cake, (which we're warned off - "too plain") is delightful in its simplicity. And even if a salad of bacon and baby spinach errs on the sweeter side of sweet, it's still an interesting offering. They have plenty of Japanese beer on offer by the bottle like Kirin and Asahi but they also have frozen sake - it's incredibly crisp, slightly sweet and perfectly refreshing on a hot day. And the wine list by Michiko Kimura, is excellent. Then there's the soba. Hot or cold, it's all good. There's even a page at the back of the menu explaining how to eat the soba, down to the last slurp. They make all their noodles in house (check the noodle machine in the front window) and the cold soba in warm duck fillet broth is stunning. Military road is loud - cars and trucks go barrelling up and down all evening in a dusty haze and if you happen to be early, there's not a lot to keep you busy. A small complaint compared to a great dinner. MR Licensed, around $70 pp, including wine.

paintby- numbers jobs in the main part of the Chatswood mall is Iwa – a smartly styled, well-priced restaurant that specialises in wagyu – that luxe Japanese beef that Sydney has come to love so well. For maximum taste value, order a few of the different cuts on offer of this incredibly rich, tender scarlet meat shot with delicate, fl avoursome fat. Deep red fl ank is a little more chewy and needs less time on the grill while pink, heavily marbled tri tip (the most luscious part of the sirloin) can stand a little more fl ame – the medallions melt like butter after a spell on the individual table barbecues. It’s a shame though, that the beef is only available at dinner which means you’ll be looking at the likes of crisp, light tempura prawns, spicy edamame (whole soy beans), California rolls and sashimi for lunch. No bad thing, but all paling before the beef. Iwa looks like your average upmarket Sydney Japanese restaurant – dark room, clean lines and dead silence – but it doesn’t feel like one. The incredibly friendly and cluey staff don’t even blink when a punter sends a Kirin accidentally fl ying across the room into someone’s miso. While other Sydney restaurants of this oeuvre have more variety and perhaps more innovative dishes, few are as pleasurable to dine in.

Malaysian in Sydney at its fanciest. Stick with restaurant signatures like the mud crab with house made chilli sauce, the satays and the beef rendang with roti.
A mud crab split and shared at a table is a beautiful thing, especially when it's covered in chilli sauce. The roti are excellent here, as are the satay sticks and you can't look past the otak-otak (thats fish puree cooked in bamboo leaves)

There's a few fancy Indian joints this side of the bridge but this is the most highly decorated. Chef Ajoy Joshi's menu roams regions of India, exploring texture, flavour and cooking methods.The regular specials including some great goat dishes. Corkage $6 per bottle.
Licensed & BYO, around50pp.

Giovanni and Marilyn Pilu have one of the most beautiful restaurants in the area. It may have panoramic views of the beach, but you're more distracted by the genius wine list of sommelier Lara Caraturo and the suckling pig. Licensed, around $100pp, including wine.
Explore 416 hectares of native plants, birds, mammals and reptiles via over 30km of walking and cycling tracks.

entry.name: Freshwater Surf Life Saving Club SLSC

version.name: Freshwater Surf Life Saving Club SLSC

content.description: This gallery down in Elizabeth Bay specialises in art education and works by highly collectable Australian artists.
Features exhibitions from street-inspired and contemporary artists from Japan, Australia, the USA and more.
content.openingtimes: Wed 12 noon–6pm; Thu 12 noon–7pm; Fri 12pm–6pm; Sat 12pm–5pm.

content.description: Alongside its gift shop, the Outback Centre has a well-regarded Aboriginal art gallery, which includes works from the Central and Western Deserts, Arnhem Land and the Kimberleys. CityRail Town Hall/Monorail Darling Park.
Peloton exhibits solo and group works by young, emerging, established, local, interstate and interstate artists.

content.openingtimes: Wed–Sat 10am–6pm; Sun & Tue 11am–5pm. Mon by app.

content.description: Rex Irwin Art Dealer was established in Sydney in 1976. The gallery continues to make a significant contribution to Australian art and each year mounts an ambitious exhibition program which combines important Australian and international art and emerging artists. The gallery is committed to exhibiting works on paper and for the last thirty years has mounted specialist shows of prints and drawings which have included Frank Auerbach, Lucian Freud, Francisco Goya, Pablo Picasso and Fred Williams. Bus 333, 378, 380, 389.
rex-livingston art dealer specialises in dealing quality investment art and the exhibition of professional emerging to mid career artists.

Top-flight Australian artists including renowned photographer Julie Rrap feature, as do sculptor James Angus, indigenous photographer Destiny Deacon and installation artist Lindy Lee. Big-name internationals such as Tracey Emin have also shown here, and the gallery encourages offshore talent. CityRail Edgecliff then 5min walk or bus 389.

This large, bright exhibition space shows leading contemporary Australian photographers and some installation and video works. Represented artists include Narelle Autio, Trent Parke and Petrina Hicks. Bus 324, 325, 326, 327.

John Olsen, now in his 80s, is one of Australia’s most revered painters – and he’s still going strong. His work, along with a Who’s Who of great and up-and-coming contemporary Australian artists, is on show (and for sale) at this new two-floor space, recently relocated from around the corner in Paddington. The gallery is run by Tim Olsen, John’s son, whose sister Louise is a member of Dinosaur Designs.
Bus 333, 352, 378, 380.

Established in 1964, this Sydney institution maintains a loyal following among some of Australia’s most significant artists. Among the notables are late sculptor Robert Klippel, figurative painter Vicki Varvaressos and renowned surrealist painter James Gleeson. Another Watters regular is Chris O’Doherty (aka Reg Mombassa) whose colourful, politicised images fuse fashion and art.
CityRail Museum.
content.openingtimes: Tue & Sat 10am-5pm; Wed-Fri 10am-7pm; closed mid Dec-early Jan

content.description: The Australian Museum (established 1827) houses the nation’s most important animal, mineral, fossil and anthropological collections, and prides itself on its innovative research into Australia’s environment and indigenous cultures. Displays cover the Pacific Islands, Asia, Africa and the Americas, with items ranging from Aboriginal kids’ toys to a tattooed chalk head from the Solomon Islands. Any serious museum-tripper should see a few of the local stuffed animals, and the displays should answer all your questions about Australian mammals. If you’re at all interested in Aboriginal culture and beliefs, visit the Indigenous Australia section, which tackles such contentious issues as the ‘stolen generation’, deaths in custody and problems facing indigenous people today. Around 1,000 Aboriginal objects of a secret and/or sacred nature are held separately from the main collection: access to these can be arranged through the Aboriginal Heritage Unit.

For a city whose history has always been entwined with its harbour, the sea and water travel, it comes as no surprise that this museum is one of the finest and most unabashed when it comes to maritime treasures. An exhibition traces the history of the Royal Australian Navy, but the biggest exhibits are the vessels themselves, among them the 1888 racing yacht Akarana, 1950s naval destroyer HMAS Vampire and traditional Vietnamese junk Tu Duo (‘Freedom’), which sailed into Darwin in 1977 with 39 refugees. A café offers seafood-oriented, open-air eating at the water’s edge, while the shop sells books, nautical knick-knacks and, if you really want to splash out, sailing packages with qualified skippers.
$15-$30 for special exhibits & vessels.

Designed by convict architect Francis Greenway, the barracks were completed in 1819 to house 600 male convicts, who were in government employ until 1848. Subsequently used as an immigration depot and an asylum for women, they eventually metamorphosed into a museum. On the top level are re-created convict barracks: rough hammocks hang side by side in the dormitories, while recorded snippets of conversation surround you. A computer database allows visitors to follow the official records of convicts, from conviction via flogging to rehabilitation. The women’s section on level two is no less thought-provoking – these (mostly Irish) women were escaping an awful existence to start what must have been an equally burdensome new life in a harsh colony. The courtyard houses a pleasant café for a moment of quiet contemplation.
Daily 9.30am–5pm. Adult $10; child & concs $5.

There's little indication of the remarkable contents of the Sydney Jewish Museum on the street side of its heavy Darlinghurst Road doors. But once you step through, the museum opens up to a world of insight and learning, all bundled up in an impressive design. "The museum has got a well-needed facelift and it's now a vibrant institution, much bigger inside than you ever imagine from outside," says the museum's development and marketing director, Charles Aronson. "It offers a lot more than the history of Jewish people, culture and the Holocaust. "Of course we look at the Holocaust, the biggest genocide in world history, and it's part of the curriculum in NSW schools, but it's not a question of making people feel sorry for the Jewish people who suffered. The idea of the museum is for it to be used as anti-racism education; it's used to show what happens with bullying. In schools, if they have problems with bullying they bring them here and show them what Hitler did, the ultimate case of bullying in the whole world." During six months of renovations the building's ground floor was equipped with state-of-the-art presentations looking at Sydney and Australian Jewish history (including paintings by Jewish Australian artists such as two-time Archibald winner Judy Cassab) and the first Jewish cemetery. "It was found under Central Station," says Aronson. "When the Jews came on the first fleet, and there were a few of them, they weren't religious people, but they wanted to be buried Jewish, so they established a cemetery. We have actually found one gravestone dating back to 1842." Another interesting feature is a mosaic weighing six tonnes, found, in all places, in the toilet of a house in Oatley. "That's nowhere near any part of Jewish Sydney. A guy was pulling up his bathroom floor and it was underneath. It was made by the Melocco brothers [one of whom designed both the altar and crypt floors for St Mary's Cathedral] but we haven't been able to trace more than that." But the centrepiece of the space is the enormous Star of David covering the floor just as you enter and made in Jerusalem stone - the shape reflected on the four mezzanine levels above. Set against a reproduction of George Street from the 1840s, the result is striking.
Guided tours of the museum are at 12 noon daily but can also be arranged for other times. In most cases tours are conducted with Holocaust survivors. See listings for more details.

Mary MacKillop (1842-1909) was the founder of the Sisters of St Joseph, an order initially devoted to educating poor Australian children. Often referred to as ‘the people’s saint’, MacKillop’s pioneering work lead to her beatification in 1995 when the Pope visited and blessed the site, giving Australia its first – and only – saint to date. She died on 8 August 1909, and the eighth day of each month has become one of pilgrimage to the museum for devout Catholics. It includes MacKillop’s home, Alma Cottage, and the chapel housing her tomb. A curious mix of humble 19th-century artefacts and high-tech wizardry, the displays of MacKillop’s possessions – including crucifixes, rosary beads, figurines and scraps of her habits – are jazzed up with talking dioramas, videos and other surprisingly cool special effects, all of which take you on a journey through the saint’s life.
Adults $7.50; child & concs $3–$5.

This former power station opened as a fun and funky museum in 1988 and is the largest in Australia, with a collection of 385,000 objects, 22 permanent and five temporary display spaces, and more than 250 interactive exhibits. It covers science, technology, creativity, decorative arts and Australian popular culture, resulting in such diverse exhibitions as Tokyo street style and childhood memories of migration. Also here is the Boulton & Watt steam engine (1785).
Frequently named the best independent bookshop in Sydney, Gleebooks stocks an unbelievably diverse range of fiction and non-fiction presents talks from local and international writers
Family owned Food and Plonk is a Lindfield addition serving up Modern Aus cuisine majoring in French infusions at reasonable rates. The menu is seasonal in hand with daily specials.

address.street: Ashfield Civic Centre, Ashfield Library, Liverpool Rd
Ashfield Civic Centre, Ashfield Library, Liverpool Rd

content.description: When it comes to frocking up an lip-synching a showtune, nothing beats the Sydney drag scene. Jump on the Glee train and see the drag tribute to the hit TV series every Friday night at the Stonewall.
It's all lesbian, all the time. There are regular queer nights including BINGAY, sly comedy and Queer Central and hey, the jugs are cheap.

Darlinghurts's Slide Bar has been pulling sexy serving suggestions out of the bedroom and onto the dinner plate through their ever-popular degustation menu, El Circo. By mixing sensual dishes such as boxed mexican crab tortilla, filled with spicy guacamole, blue swimmer crab and topped with tomato salsa with live entertainment including an erotic silhouette performance by sexy new Burlesque performer miss Elouise Sauer, Slide's Sunday night sitting is the perfect pre-shag dinner date with a difference.
Grab a window seat and watch over-excited suburban girls with fake IDs and hankies for skirts sashay by, peaking waaay too early.

Tone has a lineup of great entertainment each week and a lavish cocktail and canape menus for groups and events. It's a fantastic place for after-work drinks and a great place to go for a great night out with friends and colleagues.

Cock and balls. Depending on where you're sitting, this could be the image etched in your brain as you order your drink at the Flinders, thanks to the graffiti carved into the room-length bar. Bartender and overlord Andy Penney painstakingly applied seven layers of dark lacquer to it and has a sharp bottle opener that he makes available to patrons. You too can carve your name into the bar and capture your message for all eternity, like the enterprising individual who carved the word 'boobs'.The Flinders was recently bought and renovated by restaurateur/club owner Nick Mathers, Ksubi's Paul Wilson, and Bang Gang DJs Gus Da Hoodrat and Jaime Doom. It's modelled on a classic American dive bar. In the US, you can go to almost any bar and get a decent Manhattan or Daiquiri, natural as carrying a loaded weapon in your glovebox, and that's how it is at the Flinders. There are no fancy cocktail glasses, the service is casual as they come (but still professional and personable) and they serve straight-up great cocktails. The new crew haven't done much to the bones of the original Flinders pub, which used to host everything from lesbian breakdance parties and bear conventions to Monkees theme nights. They have, however, covered every inch of the room in tat - old signs, beer cans, bits of animal skeletons, you name it. And while Sydney's other cool new dive bar, Shady Pines Saloon, is all about Williamsburg hipster chic, the Flinders is a little more New Orleans - excellent music (Chris Bell, Television and Patsy Cline for starters), a loose vibe and some very dedicated boozing. You might like to try a Pickleback, for instance. What's a pickleback, you say? Why, it's a shot of whiskey followed by a shot of pickle juice. You may or may not follow this with a beer (we do). It'll put hair on your chest, no matter how you take it. How about a Backscratch? That's a shot of whiskey and a side of pork scratchings. We'll be going back for the Aussie Boilermaker: a shot of Bundy rum, a XXXX and a sausage roll. A tribute to the Sunshine State, maybe? Speaking of sausage rolls (and lord knows, we could talk about 'em for hours), in the coming months the Flinders will also be opening a bistro upstairs run by ex-Tetsuya's chef Thomas Lim (he'll be doing a late-night menu of sliders, dogs and buffalo wings) as well as a boutique hotel. But for now, concern yourself with having a good time in the downstairs bar. If you like your drinks with fewer shots, backs and sides, you might just have a Martini on the rocks - the Flinders serves the dirtiest one in town, replete with a whole gherkin garnish. Or there's always their Nuclear Daiquiri - the instant drunkifier. And if the idea of cocktails is a complete turn off, there's plenty of beer on tap, including crispy Kirin. Given the Flinders is one of the very few bars in Sydney that are serving up the sort of good times that everyone wants a piece of, it's important to choose your timing. Early evenings means you'll get a seat at the bar (and elbow room to carve something rude into it) plus the full attention of the bartender. Later on - the bar stays open till 5am Friday and Saturday - means a full bender where all bets are off.Myffy Rigby

The huge laughing clown’s mouth that marks the entrance to Luna Park is one of Sydney’s most alluring – an enduring symbol of the city’s curious ability to capture human lunacy and elemental awe in one magical, terrifying, mysterious experience.
Walk through that mouth, as so many generations of Sydneysiders and visitors have since the park opened in 1935, and you’ll today find a funfair in full stomach-churning swing after a veritable rollercoaster ride of triumphs and travails in the intervening decades.
Luna Park opened on the site of the Dorman Long workshops used to build the Harbour Bridge, and its heyday lasted well into the 1950s, fuelled by marvels like the Big Dipper, River Caves, Coney Island, the Joy Wheel, Turkey Trot, Barrels of Fun and Crazy House.
By the 1970s, as colour TV boomed, Luna Park was struggling. Sitting on prime real estate, it narrowly avoided being turned into a high-rise development (with heli-port!) thanks to a 1973 artistic rebellion led by Margaret Fink, wife of the lease-holder.
Fink enlisted Sydney’s most famous pop artists Martin Sharp, Peter Kingston, Garry Shead and Leigh Hobbs to rejuvenate Luna Park with a new psychedelic energy. Bright colours, massive murals, metal-flaking mind trickery and cartoon comic strip heroes soon burst from the walls while classic elements of the original park were lovingly restored.
But the threat of development still loomed and following the Ghost Train fire on June 9, Luna Park was shut down. (Bizarrely, Sydney was experiencing a rail strike that day meaning the Ghost Train was the only train running in the whole city).
For most of the two decades that followed, Luna Park’s grin could have been forgiven for turning upside down to mirror the Bridge. But it grimaced through the pain thanks only to the dogged, bloody-minded passion of a group of supporters who fought for its survival.
All the lobbying, cajoling and scrapping paid off. Luna Park reopened in 2000 and Sydney returned in a torrent to enjoy the delights of Penny Arcade, Coney Island and Big Dipper. Screams of delight filled the air and that giddy fug of waffles, fairy floss and excitement returned to the breeze. A new generation, many led by parents and grandparents who had shared their first kiss on Luna Park rides, ran through that smiling face… “just for fun”.
In October 2010, Sydney’s Luna Park is celebrating 75 years as Sydney’s heartbeat, its greatest dating service, toy box, child-minder and most fantastical “laboratory of emotions and experiences”.
The party hits full swing on its official birthday of October 4 but any registration today enjoys $15 off unlimited rides during Spring school holidays.
Time Out’s Top 5 Picks at Luna Park in October…
1. Pop up rides, The Psychodelic and much-loved Tea Cups spin in exclusively for Luna Park’s birthday. Oct 1–10.
2. Luna Park’s famous face now has a “voice” too: John Farnham, who plays the Luna Park Birthday concert with a night of all-Aussie ballads. Mon 4 Oct
3. Street clowns Hu La La and Covent Garden’s The Great Dave wow the crowds hula-hooping juggling and unicycling. Oct 1–10.
4. Rap legend Ice Cube hits the Big Top stage with his new album Drink the Kool-Aid. Fri 22 Oct.
5. October salutes the all hallows tradition and Luna Park is hosting the 18+ Magique Halloween Circus Party with magicians, go-go dancers, hypnotists vampires, aerialists, and DJs. Sat 30 Oct.
More information available at Luna Park Sydney

address.street: William Henry St, Cnr Harris Street
William Henry St, Cnr Harris Street
Warringah Mall, Old Pittwater Rd, (above Warringah Mall Library)
Warringah Mall, Old Pittwater Rd, (above Warringah Mall Library)

content.description: There's nothing better than laughing it up with the monkeys, straining your neck to see the giraffes and getting up-close and personal with our reptile friends - all on offer at Sydney's Taronga Zoo. A casual sojourn around the Zoo is pretty impressive, but there are a few must-do zoo experiences, some not for those a little scared of the dark. Take the VIP Aussie Gold Tour which is full of personalised touches and up-close encounters with the animals, or for another premium experience try Zoosnooz, which gives school children the chance to sleep out under the stars surrounded by native wildlife. The package includes a BBQ dinner and supper, a night walk where you'll see the chimpanzees and other animals being fed, as well as insider stories you won't hear on any old visit of the zoo.For early birds, the Zoorise tour is particularly rewarding for adults - offering views of the sun creeping up across the ocean in the morning and a cacophony of native bird songs. Both make for an invigorating morning (an all-day zoo pass is included). A hot ticket item is the swanky new elephant enclosure, which houses a family of rare Asian elephants, including the first Asian elephant calves born in Australia. Their digs feature a swimming pool deep enough for the elephants to be fully submerged, mud wallows, a waterfall and 2.3 kilometres of walking paths for them to wander straight past the gorillas, penguins and the Kodiak bears. The exhibition is part of a larger new space, Wild Asia: a themed precinct with learning centre to represent a tropical Asian rainforest and to help people understand the habitat. The free flight bird show, with a variety of flying birds such as pigeons, parrots, hawks and owls, happens at 12pm and 3pm in the beautiful amphitheatre that perches on the edge of a cliff - a perfect spot to take in the impressive view of the city. Only in Sydney would the animals get one of the best views. Not that it was always the case - Taronga Zoo was originally based on a site known as Billy Goat Swamp in Moore Park, before moving to its current site in 1916 for the extra space. Adult $37; Child $18; VIP Aussie Gold Tour, Adult $77; Child $41. Zoosnooz Tour, Adult $60; Child $55. In the jungle, the mighty jungle, the lions sleeps tonight. And you can sleep right next to him. Spend a night amongst the animals, with a harbour view. Enjoy luxury beds, a roast dinner, drinks and close encounters with Taronga's famous residents. Every Friday (overnight) $240 per adult, $185 per child (5-17 years). (02 9969 2777).

This Woolloomooloo gem has bequeathed Sydney one of the best beer gardens in town – no mean feat considering we Sydneysiders are outdoor animals. Truly, we’d camp out back of the Tilbury if we could. Only in Australia would you find frangipani and olive trees coexisting in a happy tangle. This popular Sydney waterside haunt is in one of the best spots by the restaurant-studded wharf where jellyfish blob about and highflyer and advertising types stroll up and down the promenade in white pants and billowing shirts. Best to get a spot in the beer garden if you can, or out on the deck one of their regular barbecues. Or prop up the room length polished bar. Sure, they’ll do you a cocktail but they’re not exactly their strong suit. They do, however, have a fair wine list and pull a mean schooner. Bar snacks are few and far between but there’s a great Italian influenced dinner menu.

As Sydney’s first boutique brewery (they started brewing back in 1986), with six different brews in their holster including three ales, two bitters and a porter, the Lord Nelson is the place to go for checking out what local brewers can do. The pub itself is all high ceilings, cool sandstone, blazing hearths and convict history. You can watch the brewing process via views of the fermentation tanks or plonk down outside and watch Millers Point. Order all the beers on tap and conduct your own tasting session. The kitchen dishes out pies, steaks and ploughman’s lunches and the barmaid sisters are eminently loveable.

Built right under the ANZ bank on Elizabeth Street in the CBD is this minimalist Japanese restaurant with a speedy sushi train in the middle: a canny use of space and time if you haven't got much of either. If you do have the chance for a longer lunch, the gyoza are a standout - plump little dumplings with gossamer-thin skins, very lightly fried, and a world away from those deep-frier dunked or bottom-fried-to-buggery pucks you see around town. These ones are perfect dipped in a little rice vinegar. Also above the ordinary are the edamame which are hot, salty and still have the fronds attached (unlike the ones you often see which come in bulk bags and have all the taste of a piece of wet paper). However, the mixed tempura isn't quite as exciting: more of a hodge podge of carrot, sweet potato, squid and prawn. The vegetables would have benefited from being sliced a little thinner but no biggie. Drinks-wise, you have to try the ramune.
