One of the girls behind the bar told us the staff favourite this month: chocolate, peanut butter and malt. Holy mackerel! They’re also licensed, with Coopers Pale on tap as well as Kirin and Corona by the bottle and an OK wine selection. Counter Burger is a little bit like the way you might imagine The Restaurants of the Future looking when you were little – plasma screens on the walls and lots of slick metal. But given the choice between this and the grungy milk bar, old school always wins out. Myffy Rigby

MONKEY MAGIC WINTER SPECIAL! Crown Street’s coolest Japanese cocktail bar fires up a mid-week meal deal.
The only thing hotter than the wasabi and the cocktails at Monkey Magic this month is their mid-week winter special which offers 20% off all food, wine and cocktails.
The special offer runs Monday to Wednesdays during the Sydney winter and applies to everything on the menu, from their lip-smacking salt and pepper cuttlefish to the legendary Dr Zeuss cocktail, a psychadelic mix of gin, St Germain liquer, absinthe, lemon, cucumber, eggwhite and soda!
Boasting chilled beats, dark wood, homemade sake and high-grade Japanese food, Monkey Magic is New York lounge meets mod-Tokyo pop-up and, since opening on Sydney’s most famous eat street, has had tongues wagging.
Some liken its vibe to Longrain for its all-wood fit out, open kitchen, big tables, separate cocktail bar and friendly staff. Others prefer the Toko comparison – Japanese fusion with cocktails (Monkey Magic make their own sake – perfect on a cold winter night!).
But this deal makes Monkey Magic a restaurant bar apart this winter.
So order a Ken Watanabe (a heady concoction of citrus, fresh apple and cucumber with wasabi named for the Japanese star of Batman Begins and The Last Samurai) and a nigiri platter laden with kingfish, tuna and salmon and enjoy your 20% discount, diners!

A brand new noodle bar next to the Shelbourne Hotel on Market Street specialising in ramen. One of the tastiest things they do here is the dragon - hot noodles covered in a spicy, chilli-studded pork mince and boiled egg garnish. They also have an excellent soba noodle and spicy beef soup absolutely riddled with chilli bits. The noodles are far better than plenty of the places you have to queue for hours to visit and there's outdoor seating - perfect for summer. Around $10 per person, including a can of green tea

The room is narrow and incredibly loud and service isn't their strong point but boy, is the food good. All your favourites are here: pad Thai, a very spicy chicken laab (that's a type of cold Thai salad of minced chicken, basil and other bits and pieces) as well as massaman, green and red curries. They also do stir fried morning glory and an excellent fried egg on rice. Super hot som tum (green papaya salad) is also worth a red-hot go.

The young, energetic crowd needs little prompting to belt the ditties. Feed off the amped up aura, grab a brew, and jive. It prides itself in having a comprehensive list of obscure Asian beats. But if Indonesian, Thai or Putong is more mood killer than motivator, they've got you covered with English. You coward.

*THIS VENUE IS CLOSED* The Elk boasts a giant, eyeless, flock-covered deer head mounting the wall, while fake ivy runs up the ceiling over the bar. The downstairs rumpus room is where it's at, for our money, decorated with empty picture frames, antique pinball machines, pool tables, 80s video games and darts. You could easily burn several hours and more than a few dollar coins here. The Elk is broken up into several areas including an outdoor strip directly opposite rival bar Sugar Mill, a darker lounge area, and the bar proper, where you'll find the booze. Cocktails aren't exactly a drawcard, but they pour a decent schooner and the wine list, though short, is modestly priced. Wednesday night is poker night with cash prizes; DJs feature on Friday and Saturday nights; art shows are a regular occurrence; there's even burlesque. You can eat cheaply here, too – there's nothing on the menu over $15 and from Thursday to Saturday it's $5 pizza and house drinks from 5pm. While the Elk isn't really the sort of place you'd linger, it's definitely worth a look as part of a bigger bar crawl through the Cross.

They've got an absolutely kickin' jukebox and a great view of Taylor Square from the window seats. A bit studenty at times and not the cleanest, but it's a good old pub in the thick of Darlinghurst's nightlife.

entry.name: Wiggles World: Wiggly Play Centre - Seven Hills

version.name: Wiggles World: Wiggly Play Centre - Seven Hills

content.description: There's a reason why the Wiggles are one of Australia's richest entertainment export - they rock. And you can rock at Wiggles World, an indoor children's playground featuring jumping castles, mazes, themed party rooms, ball pits and a cafe for adults.
content.openingtimes:
Mon-Tue 9.30am-3pm; Wed-Fri 9.30am-5pm; Sat 9.30am-6pm; Sun 10am-5pm;
Disco every last Fri of the month until 9pm

content.description: The work of the late May Gibbs has given Australian children wondrous fantasies for years with Snugglepot and Cuddlepie. Nutcote is where she wrote her books and long-running cartoon strip Bib and Bub. Reminisce about Gumnut babies and Banksia men in that childhood fantasy world.

Tables and punters spill out onto the street in a happy, busy, buzzy mess. Cordial's BLT is VGI and they also do an excellent corn fritter and steak sambo and are using Golden Cobra - coffee bean of the moment.
It's all about the soup-filled dumplings and chopped glutinous rice noodles with shredded duck.
Located in the old Weston Biscuits factory, best keep it simple when it comes to eating here but go nuts on the excellent coffee.
Stocks Marc Jacobs, Chloe, Michelle Jank, Miu Miu and brilliant hand-bags. For fashion-forward types.
You'll find it all here from snakeskin gloves to cat-shaped bangles. A huge range of vintage gear and costume jewellery is available with a big range of designer clothes.

This store features items for the well dressed home. From London town to Sydney city Davidmetnicole showcase British style and design. Purveyors of quality furniture, lighting, accessories and eclectic objects.
Don't let the name fool you. The items stacked haphazardly on the shelves at Dust are often in remarkably good condition - from old movie posters to mannequins to cane chairs.

Rifle through an extensive collection of antique furniture to turn your house into a pad straight out of your decade of choice. For all you rockabilly cats out there, they specialise in goods from 1950s.

Christmas treasure troves don't come any more amazing as they do at Sydney Antique Centre. With 60 amazing shops, each more wondrous than the last, there's a huge range of wonderful and unique items to choose from - vintage jewellery, one-off collectables, retro furniture and 20th century ceramic and glassware, plus a vast vintage clothing collection where high fashion comes at a fraction of the usual price. But SAC is about more than mere shopping. It's an experience that also takes in fine food and drink at the licensed on-site café the Arts on Dowling, a gorgeous lounge where you can grab a bite to eat and luscious glass of wine or coffee.Soul of SydneyChristmas is a time when reaching your creative potential goes hand-in-hand with a desire to make a difference, both in your own life and in someone else's. This spiritual sentiment is embodied in Soul of Sydney, the perfect Christmas gift for both Sydneysiders or friends and family overseas. As light reflects through this gorgeously crafted crystal, the global icon embedded in its heart unveils itself - a genuine piece of one of the world's most recognised and rhapsodised architectural masterpieces, the Sydney Opera House. Presented simply or lit from within, this incredible piece combines centuries-old skill with Sydney ingenuity and a global environmental ethos. Best of all, a percentage of all proceeds from Soul of Sydney goes to charities such as the Thorndale Foundation, Kiva Microloans and Autism Research.To order this unique and strictly limited memento call 1300 075 010 or go to www.SoulofSydney.com.au.

Release your inner child with an incredible selection of model trains, planes and, um, automobiles. Plus all sorts of 50s and 60s Americana. Savvy staff can help beginning collectors get started and can provide something special for even the most experienced aficionados.
The decor’s a mix between George of the Jungle, Total Recall and The Rat Pack with a reasonable selection of wines by the glass.
Get in the mood for some sweet, sweet music by flipping through the secondhand racks.
Goth it up by browsing through the clothing, art and accoutrements at the centre of Enmore's so-called ‘Gothic Mile'. Discover your dark side.
It may be cramped but it’s super trad. The plum wine is amazing and a great way to warm up your vocal cords - karaoke every Friday and Saturday.
If you’re going to sing crap karaoke pop songs to a crowded room, it may as well be a place where no one cares and anything goes.
Buying and selling art is made easy at this walk-in art shop. Get a Del Kathryn Barton print, Gary Heery's famous 1984 photo of Madonna, or an exquisite piece of glassware.
Obtain anything from a Marc Newson embryo chair to an Emily Kame Kngwarreye canvas at this auction house/gallery specialising in fine, decorative an indigenous art.

It always makes a difference when a bookstore chooses its stock with care, and Ariel has been a Paddington landmark since 1985 thanks to their knowledgeable staff and superb selection of quality titles.

With three decades of dealing with second-hand books, Elizabeth's Pitt Street store stocks non-fiction titles as well as classic and modern literature. Best of all, they have the full range of children's favourites Asterix and Tintin.
If your reading tastes run to swords, sorcery or starships then Galaxy Bookshop has got you covered, with more than 200,000 fantasy and sci-fi titles in stock as well as DVDs and collectibles.

Hollywood has fallen in love with comic books, and now you can too. As well as the latest superhero releases, Kings also stocks a gigantic selection of graphic novels and assorted comic book merchandise.

Arida boasts men's and women's collections from Lanvin, Givenchy, Rick Owens, Celine, L’Wren Scott, Superfine, L’Agence, James Perse. They also carry unique furniture, homewares and decorative objects.
Specialising in his-and-hers architectural pieces from Rick Owens, Dior Homme, Maison Martin Margiela and Undercover, Assin is not to be missed for fans of the darker side of style.

This small store bursts at the seams with stylishly pared-back offerings from APC, Filippa K and Alexander Wang. Well-priced goodies such as K Jacques sandals and Lover swimsuits are the answer to recession shopping blues.

One of Sydney’s most promising new boutiques offers a carefully edited mix of every label women want to wear right now, from cult New York brand Opening Ceremony to the cutting-edge favourite of fashion editors everywhere, Balmain.

It’s difficult to leave Poepke without picking up a pair of adorable Bernhard Willhelm shoes or transseasonal Dries Van Noten coat. Add to this Ann Demeulemeester, Rittenhouse and Bassike and you have an idea of what this boutique has to offer.

Stocking local labels such as Insight and Ksubi as well as cool international brands such as Arvust and Lee, General Pants is a wardrobe to Sydney’s tshirt and shorts-wearing street and surf kids. They also have a good selection of Havaianas, Converse and Vans.
Myer has successfully re-invented itself as a won’t-be-beaten-on-price department store with urban edge. It’s affordable, accessible and reliable.

address.street: The Strand Arcade, Pitt St Mall
The Strand Arcade, Pitt St Mall

content.description: Jurlique takes natural to a new level, growing their ingredients on their own biodynamic farm and using few preservatives in their skincare products.
Keihl’s offer natural cleansers and moisturisers for women, babies, men, and even pets.
This shop is a wonderland for chefs and food-obsessed punters alike. Find everything from pots and pans to plates, and a very broad and affordable range of copper here.
There are more spices available at Herbie’s than you can poke a cinnamon stick at. There are even spice appreciation courses to help you get the most out of your cooking.
The best fresh pasta in Sydney is from a tiny shop in Bronte. Anna Maria makes everything from scratch and the queues are down the road.
Sydney’s best known providore may be harsh on the hip pocket but stocks products you’d be hard pressed to find elsewhere, like super tasty Ortiz anchovies. The cheese room is not to be missed.
This is how groceries shopping should be. An upmarket supermarket with the feel of a deli that isn’t eye-wateringly expensive, you won’t ever want to go back to Woolies/Coles/Aldi again.
Allan’s Music is instrumental for the Sydney muso. Buy a guitar off the shelf, or have one custom made – and they’ll even teach you how to play it with a free beginner’s lesson.

Apple Store: It’s what it says on the box: every single iThing you could possibly iWant or iNeed, presented by impossibly knowledgeable iStaff in a futuristic, three-level store. There’s also The Genius Bar (service centre)and free workshops. iCaramba!

Entertainment is a just a roll of the dice away at Games Paradise, with its diverse selection of board games and puzzles. Stock up for the winter months on Monopoly, Chess, trading card games and jigsaw puzzles.

It may look like little more than a fast food joint, but it ain't so. This is the most authentic Mexican food in the city. Their corn chips are legendary and the D.F Steak & Onion burrito is the bomb.
The oldest and best hobby shop in town has two levels of models, train sets, slot car racers, remote control models, dollhouses, Lego and Meccano.
This sweet little boutique is best known for its collection of pastel-coloured striped china, lamps and shades, and rolls of cotton fabric in stripes, polka dots, and funky designs.
Find everything from Alessi kitchen items to Mandarina Duck luggage to MoMA NYC notepads. They now have ABICI bicycles – hands down the coolest set of wheels in town.
Serious about rugs as a design feature? Check out Robyn Cosgrove’s range reflecting modern design moods, while in touch with classic and traditonal craftsmanship.

It’s easy to get lost in Space. This purveyor of all things ultra cool for the home carries leading names such as Edra, Giorgetti, Ingo Maurer and Kartell. Space is by no means cheap, but then again fabulous things never are.

One glance in the window of this luxe-modern showroom and you’ll fall in love – with Missoni Home shagpile rugs, bold Europa lights, Modernica shell chairs, Askman magazine holders and Sambonet saucepans.
Sydney mum Diana Baker was inspired by the birth of her twins to open this hip one-stop baby and maternity boutique with a spotlight on organic cotton clothing.

Bring your little princess or devil to Carnival and Party Warehouse's costume shop to keep them from raiding your closet. The shop has been in business over 70 years and has built a collection of more than 7,000 items.

address.street: Sydney Central Plaza, Pitt Street Mall, George St
Sydney Central Plaza, Pitt Street Mall, George St

content.description: Grip your child’s hand tightly in this shop unless you want to see why “kid in a candy store” became an expression. Sugar Fix is loaded with lollies from all over the world, from the UK to South Africa.

Kids love to learn while having fun and educational toys from Terrific Scientific will fire up children’s curiosity. There are experiment kits, construction toys, maps, telescopes, robotics and fossils.

address.street: Glebe Public School, Cnr Glebe Point Rd & Derby Pl
Glebe Public School, Cnr Glebe Point Rd & Derby Pl

content.description: One of Sydney’s favourite outdoor markets is a community event. Browse second-hand clothing, accessories, books, recordings, arts, crafts, and furniture to the sounds of live music.

The glory days of the rissole are over. Gone are the daily roasts, cheap beer, sticky carpets, ringing pokies and aging patrons. In their place, rising like phoenixes from the ashes of Sydney’s age-old clubland, are flash entertainment and dining complexes dishing out fashionable food in deluxe environs for a cool, young crowd. Canterbury League Club is one of the biggest Sydney clubs to reinvent itself for the new generation replacing stodgy grub with lighter, more interesting flavours with a mediterranean twist. Two years ago, the club launched Flame Bar and Restaurant, a sophisticated meeting place with a fine wine list, buzzy table service and chic seating. Then there was the outstanding food. Flame’s menu includes a huge range of wood-fired pizzas and also a sensational $25 tasting plate of king prawns, crisp squid, oysters with lime, grilled quail, chipolata, sun-dried tomato tapenade and Turkish bread – hardly the club grub this city has become used to. The recently awarded Flame manages to offer intimate dining for couples and alfresco surrounds for groups. It overlooks the club’s water feature and adjoins the intimate Heritage Bar, which serves lip-smacking cocktails, boutique beers plus snacks. There’s live entertainment in the restaurant from 6pm on Fridays and Saturdays and a jazz band blazes away on the Terrace every Sunday from 5.30pm.

Built and established in 1912 as the Cleveland Inn, this heritage listed hotel underwent a major restoration in 1995 that prompted a name change and Bar Cleveland was born, evolving into one of Sydney's most popular inner city pubs.
More information on the original Chat Thai, Manly or CBD.
This shop is packed to the rafters with second-hand books, CDs, DVDs, videos and LPs. Vinyl junkies will want to set aside a few hours for an expedition here.

Imagine the coolest person you know. Now imagine their record, CD and DVD collection: that’s pretty much what BRN stocks. That sweet import you’ve been hankering for? It’s on the shelf right now – at least, until some other hipster beats you to it.

If you’ve wondered where the independent spirit of record stores has gone, wonder no more. The team at Mojos only stock what they love, in soul, blues, jazz, country, garage, surf, psychedelic, folk and more.

In the middle of the city lies this oasis of indie cool, a shop that focuses on music rather than the music business. It stocks a massive selection of new releases and imports in a wide variety of genres, including a comprehensive Australian section.
The warm tones of vinyl are making a comeback, and if you want to start a collection, from rock to classical to soul and even comedy, then The Vintage Record is your port of call.

entry.name: TITLE Music Film Books - Surry Hills

version.name: TITLE Music Film Books - Surry Hills

content.description: With a filing ‘system’ designed to encourage chance discoveries, you’re bound to find something enticing among the handpicked selection of cult DVDs, books and music.

entry.name: TITLE Music Film Books - Crows Nest

version.name: TITLE Music Film Books - Crows Nest

content.description: With a filing ‘system’ designed to encourage chance discoveries, you’re bound to find something enticing among the handpicked selection of cult DVDs, books and music.

If you’ve got a love for the rough stuff, make sure you head over to Utopia Records, Sydney’s best outlet for all things metal. On top of a wide variety of CDs and LPs, they also stock books, collectibles and clothing.

address.street: Cnr South Dowling St & Todman Ave
Cnr South Dowling St & Todman Ave

content.description: Anaconda runs the gamut of all things nature: from hiking to diving to kayaking to climbing to biking. Tired of browsing? Scale the store’s indoor rock wall.

Paddy Pallin produced Australia’s lightest sleeping bags, tents and rucksacks in the early 1930s to lighten his load when bushwalking. Soon Pallin’s name became synonymous with lightweight gear for heavyweight campers.
Whether you’re skating on ice or concrete, Skater HQ is the place for all your sk8er needs, from inline skates and skateboard decks to longboards and scooters.
With a moderately priced selection of clothes from the 1970s to the 1990s, Cream is a one-stop shop for all things retro, from flannel to floral to a big old pair of Docs.
Turn on, tune in and drop out Timothy Leary-style to a wonderland of the best that each generation of fashion had to offer.
If you have a lust for brightly coloured polyester and a few hours to rummage, Mr Stinky’s is your dream store. Find the weird, the wonderful and everything in between.
Here’s where you’ll find anything from a floor-length red velvet gown to a suit fit for a 1920s dandy. A purchase from Rokit is like owning a little piece of fashion history.
It’s retro heaven inside this inner-west store. The accessories selection is a standout, and their range of apparel for ladies and gents is not to be sneezed at.
Find family heirloom-quality jewellery or a dress that could have easily belonged to a great aunt, minus the mothballs. Fashion editors love the Vintage Clothing Shop.
One of Peter Kuruvita's (Flying Fish) recommendations for Sri Lankan food in Sydney.
content.openingtimes: Breakfast: daily 7-9:30am; Lunch: Thurs-Fri noon-2pm; Dinner: Mon-Sun 6-9:30pm

content.description: Less well known Sri Lankan cuisine takes pride of place at this local fave, serving up large helpings of traditional South Asian dishes like pani puri – deep-fried batter balls filled with spices, chickpeas and potatoes - at affordable prices.
Run by Don and Margaret Prasad, this spice shop specialises in Fijian and Pacific ingredients but also has a great range of Indian and Sri Lankan foods.
A spice centre and Sri Lankan takeaway.

The Brooklyn’s main bar is a local favourite, with urban decor, good food, impressive beer and wine lists, regular entertainment and widescreen plasma TVs, making it a great place to unwind or catch up with a friend or colleague when you’re in search of a local bar in the heart of the city.

address.street: AquaMine Deck C, Chowder Bay Rd
AquaMine Deck C, Chowder Bay Rd

content.description: Chowder Bay's water sparkles like sapphires and sailing boats drift by silently. There's the odd splash when scuba divers go flipper-up and young kids with pale, chubby legs play near the shore. At Ripples, we wait at the door as the sign dictates. And we wait. And we wait.When we're finally met, they don't greet us - we are very briskly asked for our reservation name, and we're sat down on transparent chairs. Outside in the main dining area, long tables of men in pink polo shirts and ironed jeans flop lazy, tanned arms around women in white linen, while inside is a space geared for weddings with large round tables topped with huge pastel flower arrangements. We start with arancini - rice balls with a mozzarella centre and a strong hint of saffron that are okay without being great. In fact, cheese is the dominant element in all the entrees on our table. Crumbed, fried mozzarella is stretchy and more-ish, relieved with a peppery salad of rocket, capers and olives while some sweet little scallops served on the half shell are confusingly weighed down with a goat's cheese sauce.Roast bone marrow with parsley salad is a take on that Fergus Henderson (see review of Fergus' book p23) classic. The original dish sees veal shin bones roasted until slightly browned on the outside with the marrow soft, warm and salty on the inside. This is then spread over dry, grilled slices of toast and topped with a vinegary salad of parsley and capers. Here, the toast is buttered on both sides and the pale bones have been topped with cheese. The result is incredibly fatty and not particularly pleasant.Service is pretty shaky from go - youngsters snatch water bottles off our table without offering refills and one poor girl struggles with our wine for five minutes, trying to take the foil off. She's visibly upset and eventually a senior member of staff comes over and opens the wine for her. The result is a bottle that appears to have been savaged by a vicious dog.Grilled prawns with chilli and garlic are let down by overcooked angel hair pasta and the half duck roasted on a bed of cabbage isn't served with lardons as advertised - instead, it arrives with undercooked slices of bacon. And this is the best thing on the menu. The meringue is described as 'chewy' but we find a crisp cloud of meringue with sweetened mascarpone and bitter, stringy rhubarb. Nobody says goodbye as we leave - they just stare until we're out the door. It's not very often you leave a restaurant feeling empty but this is a rare exception. Myffy RigbyLicensed, around $75 pp, including wine.
content.openingtimes: Breakfast: Mon-Fri 9am-11am, Sat-Sun 8am-11am; Lunch: Mon-Fri 12 noon-3pm, Sat-Sun 12 noon-4pm; Dinner daily 6-9pm

content.description: Beer, beer and more beer. Beers in steins, beers the size of your arm, beers with unpronounceable names like Fransziskaner and Schofferhofer. Try something different or play it safe with Grolsch. Schnack-wise, go easy on the potato rosti – it’s a gut-buster.
One of the only guys that sell Czech beers on tap in Sydney also sell Slivovice (Czech moonshine). Oh, and mince on toast, Czech-style.

Palms is a little like the bar in Cheers, except no one cares what your name is. Unassuming music and hip people on the dancefloor make this underground haven on Oxford Street an undesirable-free zone.

A goodtime bar that keeps on giving, the Rose occupies the hightraffic terrain of Cleveland Street at the mouth where Broadway melts into Newtown. It’s tough country yet this rose flowers in every department and the human traffic from the nearby Seymour Centre and Sydney University ensure it’s always fizzing with fun and bursting with uni students. The front bar is killer, with crowd-pleasers and envelope pushers on tap and a cocktail list that gets you where you want to go fast. Out back is a beer garden dotted with bench seats and big wooden tables and an open kitchen dishing out pizza and pub grub. And there’s even a bocce area. The fit-out is just as fun with an ever-changing array or murals outside and ceiling frescoes, stone cherubs and laughing clowns abounding inside.
It’s right across the road from the beach, you've a choice between classic Aussie or Asian cuisine and there are $5 cocktails on Friday nights.
The next best thing to Vegas, you’ve got the chance to see Elvis impersonators, not to mention a Vegas tribute to ‘Mr Magic Hands’, Liberace.
Stupendous pastry, excellent pies and some of the best bread in the inner west. Victoire is moving to 660 Darling St, Balmain in mid-August 2010.
Tapas by the sea and excellent cocktails encapsulates a free wheeling side of Avalon not always seen.

What? An oft-overlooked restaurant specialising in Peking duck. Other highlights include a hot, spicy and refreshing cucumber salad and crisp, fluffy, peppery squares of deep-fried tofu. Why? It’s cheap for Peking duck, it looks a lot nicer on the inside than the outside (all the better to fool you, nay-sayers) and their soft drink comes in schooner glasses – heavenly reprieve to the hung over. Plus, they do a soup out of the duck bones after you’ve had your duck pancakes and san choy bau. Bonza. How much? Around $30pp.

Your typical Time Out pub review is based on a talented young writer visiting a bar incognito for a couple of hours or so and then giving their heartfelt opinion of said establishment. This one is a bit different. You see, I’m old, not particularly talented and have been drinking at The Shannon for around eight years (although I have been home once or twice in that time). In the spirit of transparency I thought it best to declare that up front. And while we’re about it, I might also have a long overdue bar tab with them - I can’t remember. Previously known as the Royal Oak and operating more or less continuously since 1865, The Shannon pretends to be nothing other than, well, a pub - and a bloody good one at that. Nestled in rapidly gentrifying inner city Chippendale, The Shannon is cornered by two welcoming open-air windows that provide a decent breeze on a good day. The pub’s focal point is its rather striking ten-foot stained glass oval window depicting the Shannon river, County Limerick, complete with crumbling castle, moored boats, leaping salmon and meditative Celtic bards. OK, I made the last bit up but the window really is worth the visit alone. Inside you’ve got an open plan area with a huge bar with bar stools, a loose collection of tables, two decent pool tables and a jukebox with an eclectic 500-plus song selection. Downstairs is a massive new bar, available for private hire. In the beer garden you’ve got a sunny and welcoming outdoor dining area and kitchen. The menu is a lively compilation of the usual suspects - steaks, fish, chicken, pasta - all under $20. The food is nothing pretentious but it’s always fresh, house made and presented to a standard you normally expect to see at the posher, pricier end of town. And then there is Pat the publican. An expat Limerick man, broad of girth and broader of accent, Pat is a throwback to a bygone era when all publicans were gruff, witty, bullshit artists who wouldn’t hesitate to stop, prop and talk to all and sundry. He’s a star attraction. Being old school, Pat is fastidious about making sure the beer is cold, crisp and clean. There’s a good selection on offer at around $4.50 a schooner, from VB, New and Coopers to the increasingly popular younger brands such as Pure Blonde. But the crowing glory is the Guinness which Pat proudly claims as the best in Sydney. And I wouldn’t argue with him. Nor would any of his regulars. His clientele is healthily diverse: from veterans locals to just-passing-through backpackers; from young professional couples to students from the nearby University Notre Dame’s Broadway campus. Different nights attract different crowds. On a Tuesday, you’ve got the dulcet Dublin tones of local Lou Carey, famed around these parts for once telling Bono to eff off and get his own gig. True story. Saturday is jazz night while on a Sunday you’ll often stumble across an impromptu pick-up gathering of up to 40 Irish musos each with a tin-whistle or a drum or a fiddle. Aye, it’s a good craic to be sure. Phil McCluskey

A chophouse can be one of two things: somewhere to get a steak and a glass of red, or a place to get your rocks off. Either way, both are filled with red-blooded men looking to spend some dollars. To further confuse the issue, staff at Bligh Street's Chophouse come a little too close for comfort. Fact: at no time during the transaction is it ever OK for the waitperson to sit down at your table and lean into you. Ever. It's worse than watching them spit-polish your cutlery. It looks like it's house policy here, as they're doing it at the next table, too. It's all the more infiuriating when one of them sidles up to a couple of fellas at the next table and sits on my handbag. Dull the pain with something from the huge and very well priced wine list. It's heavy on the Aussie varietals but there's also a perfectly respectable cotes du Rhone for a meagre 37 clams. We'll be back to visit the bar, too – the light sculpture of cow skulls make it look like an artist's impression of a miner's pub in Lightning Ridge, but the cocktail list is all classics and looks well worth a tilt. Speaking of interiors, the main room is a mix of click-go-the-shears-boys, while curved white metal support beams give it a slightly eating-inside-a-humpback feel. Pulled beef salad with cabbage and horseradish reads well, but the addition of currants on top of roasted hazelnuts makes it more like a dessert. Better is the scallop ceviche with shavings of fennel and apple and a drizzle of lemon oil. But forget the window dressing: what you want is the guts. The red-hot bleeders. You want the beef. And boy there are a lot to choose from – there's 10 different types of steak, plus our favourite, the double lamb chop. The meat comes with nought but what's advertised on the menu – sauces like jus or chimichurri are an extra $6.90 (yowza). Order the kipflers and a side of beans for a little protein respite. The double chops are perfectly seasoned, thick and juicy as hell – absolutely great value for under $30 – while a minute steak of wagyu doesn't have the intense mouth feel and flavour you'd expect from a piece of meat with a marble score of nine. That said, they do a good café de Paris butter to top it – put some fries on the side and it's bistro-tastic. The Delmonico we can take or leave: 500g of dry aged meat cooked on the bone it may be, but there's not a lot of flavour there.Did we mention the cutlery? Mini Laguiole cleavers replace steak knives. It's a cool idea, but cleavers are meant to chop, not slice. No fear, there are regular steak knives at the ready. Desserts play second fiddle to the protein but if you must, try the frozen sour cherry nougat – whipped cream is lightly flavoured with a little rose and tonka bean (a little black wrinkled seed-looking thing that smells like a mix of vanilla, cloves and cinnamon), while dry sour cherries are dotted thoughout, topped with a beehive of pashmak. Get your beef on and chop some. Myffy Rigby
Eat the Singapore chilli crab with roti, the white cut Hainanese chicken and the rich fish head curry. BYO around $50pp

Best for A get-in-and-get-out, traditional Italian experience. What to order It's all about the Four cheese pizza (gorgonzola, fontina, mozzarella, parmo) but be warned - one slice is usually enough to put the most avid cheese fancier into a lactose coma. Atmosphere Bustling and busy, the energy's high and the pizza is churned out at a crazy speed. Talk about fast food! Extras Try your hands at pizza making here - you can book through Gourmet Safaris. The tour starts at 10am and costs $80, and the next one is on Saturday 1 November. Get a table Take a tent and pitch up before 6pm. Turnaround is quick though, so getting a table is more about committing to the wait than scalping slices from the dodgy guy standing on the corner. Licensed and BYO, around $20pp
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat dinner 6pm-11:30pm; Sun dinner 5:30-9:30pm; Wed-Sun lunch noon-3pm

content.description: From very humble beginnings to one of the largest and most successful venues in Sydney, the Blacktown Workers Club possesses a strong philosophy on stability and progress and prides itself on maintaining a true sense of community. Featuring five floors of sporting and health facilities, four restaurants and a coffee shop, multiple function rooms and auditoriums, a great selection of sub and sporting clubs and a host of other facilities for its members, the Blacktown Workers Club is the entertainment and leisure capital of Western Sydney.

Channel Marie Antoinette at the height of her reign with classically restored antique French furniture, flower-filled balconies and charming décor. Don't be tempted to skip breakfast either - the kitchen caters to all desires and appetites and the lovely Kathryn will serve it up al fresco when the weather is warmer. $180-$260 per night

Mixing business and pleasure? Put your money on the split-level Presidential Suite, just a stone's throw from the finance district. A separate adjoining room means that your entourage can be on close call, unless of course you feel like entertaining them for a change courtesy of your room's very own grand piano. $2,000 per night

This bar is somewhere you should drink. The first small bar to have opened on the northern beaches, it's owned by Nova DJ Tim Ross, and run by his wife Michelle Glew-Ross and her sister Brooke Glew. Folks sit around drinking longnecks of Coopers Pale or share carafes of wine and read the weekend papers. If it were any more laid back, we'd fall in a heap. The Ross clan designed the space themselves and they've done a bang-up job. The room is skinny (about as wide as a tiny laneway) and hidden between a bank and a credit union. You might walk straight past it if you didn't notice the cool, industrial-style lettering above the door. The interior, with its whitewashed walls, long concrete bar and banquettes lining the walls, is a study in less-is-more. There's a real larrikin undertone to the sophisticated exterior. Their bar snacks are Twisties (cheese only), their longnecks are Coopers (Pale only) and their house pours are simply gin, tequila, vodka. Their shelf spirits may be Bombay, Patron and Belvedere but they are not trying to be a cocktail bar. They're something better: a small bar offering great service and a very comfortable vibe. If you're planning a day trip to the northern beaches and want to set up camp, this is a great place to do it.
The gallery was established to give COFA students the opportunity to present in a gallery space off campus. Kudos Gallery exhibits a diverse range emerging work from 1st year to post-grad students.
The private gallery of the world-recognised Sydney-based artist Ken Done, with every wall a riot of colour.

Run by unpaid artists and activists, The Red Rattler is a creative playground for performers, musicians, artists, designers, multi-media makers, experimentalists, film-makers, theorists, activists, collective organisers, and local punters, fitted with a full PA, stage, LED lighting rig, projector and screen, licensed bar, two non-residential artist studios, and a rooftop garden.

Morgan McGlone spent much of his young chefing life with Luke Mangan before leaving to cook in New York. But here's the French twist: he decided to take some time out to become a modelling agent in Paris. "I was working as a private chef in New York," he explains. "I met an Australian photographer at a party, we got talking and I started off just helping out. My first job was a Devon Aoki shoot where we were moving Andy Warhols around like coasters. It was just crazy." Several years on and he's left the world of fashion and come back to Sydney to cook straight-up bistro food in a tiny restaurant with an A-grade team. Morgan and his brother Rick McGlone have teamed up with manager Darran Smith and sommelier Rob Young (you might recognise Darran from the floor at Icebergs and Rob from North Bondi Italian Food), who provide seamless service that's professional as well as fun. You'll also find Dave Harris (star barista and ex-owner of Ten Buck Alley) knocking about on the coffee machine on Fridays. All the floor staff speak fluent wine list too. Much of said list is broken up into glasses, mini carafes (250ml), regular carafes (500ml) and bottles. There's interesting stuff on there under $50 but if you're interested in spending a bit of coin, you've got the option to do so with their 'reserve wines'. Start with the salad of roast beetroot - bumps of creamy goat's cheese mess with little hunks of roast beetroot, all crunched up with a scattering of walnuts. It's perfect if you're planning on hitting the proteins later on. The look of it is very bistro, down to the mirrors covered in red lippy advertising the specials such as the firm-yet-tender scallops. They're slightly cool in the middle but, paired with fine slices of sweet, crunchy pickled Jerusalem artichokes, it's a winner dish. Mains wise, we're all about the confit duck served with peas, bacon and lettuce braised in pork stock (ask for a spoon or some bread to capture that last bit of sauce and any rogue peas). And we're very keen on going back for the Flinders Inn burger, Frenched up with frites. The chocolate fondant is a firm puddingy exterior holding a blob of chocolate ooze paired with smooth, creamy honey ice cream. Tasty. If chocolate desserts make your eyes glaze over, the lemon tart is straight-up, no-fuss creamy citrus zing with incredibly light pastry on a plate. Flinders Inn is your ultimate neighbourhood restaurant: simple, straightforward food with peerless service and a fun wine list. It's perfect for a laidback midweek meal or an early Friday night dinner before you hit the Local Taphouse a few doors down. Myffy Rigby

address.street: Corner of Queens Rd and William St
Corner of Queens Rd and William St

content.description: Dancing to retro classics.

Grappa may be as strong as the devil himself but there’s an art to drinking it. For one thing, drink with discernment – being 40–45% alcohol, you’ll be in a gutter before the night’s out if you treat this like a regular house spirit. Instead, choose wisely and drink slowly – this is a digestivi (a drink taken after a meal to aid in digestion and settle the stomach after a big meal and is meant to be almost medicinal) not a shooter. Many people will drink a finger of grappa in a shot of coffee known as cafe corretto (corrected coffee) with a biscotti (twice baked almond biscuit). Distilleries have recently taken more time and effort with their packaging and many of the bottles look a lot better than they taste. Distilling grappa is an expensive and lengthy process and most people concentrate on making small batches. Basically, it’s made by distilling the bits of grape skin, vine and old fruit from the wine making process – it’s vine to seed drinking, really. Some are wrapped up in beautifully printed paper and others just have stylish stickers or their own little accessories hanging off the neck of the bottles. You hear of old Italian guys in Five Dock making it out in their backyard sheds but the first time you try it you might want look into some of the more reputable grappa makers like Nonino, Jacapo Poli and Nardini, lest you go blind by accident (yes, really). Nonino also does a chestnut honey grappa, which is much more mild and drinker friendly than some of the others. There are a few restaurants around town to drink it but for the biggest range, you can’t look past Grappa in Leichhardt.
Daily. Adult $22; child $15. 12-person minimum.
Notes is a purpose built 300 capacity live music restaurant and bar with an incredible sound facilities and excellent sight lines to the stage from throughout the venue.

Fresh, airy and ambient, Garfish is classic Manly dining and allows diners to customise their own meal. Select a fish from the menu, choose how you would like it cooked and match it with the garnish of your choice. Or opt for snapper pie, beer battered fish ‘n’ chips or oysters. Fresh seafood at reasonable prices? We’re hooked! As featured in Time Out Manly Guide 2009

Steaks and ribs is what Ribs & Rumps do best. Their flagship premises offer stunning views over the beach and the only thing more breathtaking than the scenery is their menu. Their steaks are sensational but there’s also sumptuous seafood, bodacious burgers, chargrilled chicken dishes and a delicious range of sides and vegetarian delicacies to balance the belly out! As featured in Time Out Sydney Manly Guide 09

With over 20kms of dedicated bicycle tracks - many forged by Manly's famous Aboriginal warrior tribes 20,000 years ago - Manly Bike Tours offer a unique way to explore a beautiful coast and all its idyllic beaches, marine reserves and retail outlets in style. Manly caters for all levels of riders and all tastes in bikes. Hire your choice and take a guided (10.30am daily) or solo tour. Let the good times roll!

This is the closest Billabong store to the ocean in the world, but it’s inside where the action is – the whole range of fine Billabong clothes, accessories, wetsuits and surfboards awaits, most exclusive to Billabong and few found in rival surf shops. Perusing the stunning mega-surf images on the walls, you may even bump into one of Billabong’s Team Riders! As featured in Time Out Sydney's Manly Guide 09

Cutting-edge skate and surf wear with a social conscience, Element cut all their cloth from organic and sustainable materials and though their carbon footprint is small, they cast a long fashion shadow. Their Manly HQ shows why, with wallto-wall skateboards and accessories and hot lines of hoodies, tees, hats, knits for men and women. As featured in Time Out Sydney Manly Guide 09

entry.name: Royal Institute for Deaf and Blind Children

version.name: Royal Institute for Deaf and Blind Children

content.description: One of Australia’s major charities, the Royal Institute for Deaf and Blind Children (RIDBC) is also Australia’s premier special educator.

Chef Dan Hong calls this ramen 'The Chronic' and after the first spoonful, you'll know what he means. You'll find the stall at the far end of the Eating World. There's no phone number, no menu except what's on the board. It takes seven days to make the pork stock for the tonkotsu ramen and three ingredients: water, miso and 120kg of pork bones. This incredibly collagen enriched noodle soup is so thick, rich and porky that one between two is enough. Yowza.

Home Ideas Centres are free, permanent exhibitions of products for building, renovating, decorating, landscaping, architecture and interior design. If you are building or renovating make the Sydney Home Ideas Centre your first place to visit. The Home Ideas Centre also has consultants available to supply information on the thousands of products on show, not to mention regular free events and seminars. Topics include Sustainable Living, Home Renovation, Kitchen Design & Renovation, Bathroom Design & Renovation and Landscape Design.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 9am-5pm; Sat 10am-4pm; Sun (and most Public Holidays) 11am-4pm

content.description: Originally occupied by the Cammeraygal warrior tribe (rock paintings can be found in the surrounding hills), this park once hosted a sewage treatment works but has been gorgeous parkland since 1930. The former engine house, tunnels and canals today house an Art and Craft Centre and sports, walks and fishing abound. Follow the tawny frogmouths to Folly Point and bask.
A creative and inspiring warehouse venue, that can accommodate large-scale group exhibitions.

HeadQuarters is a Cruise Club (or Sex on Premises venue) for men to go and have sex with other men. You pay a fee to enter and this entitles you to use the facilities. Cruise Clubs are unique to the gay community and have developed a culture of their own. HeadQuarters offers a number of themed areas which are diverse and it is this diversity that makes HeadQuarters unique.

Open 7 days, Kings Park Tavern has drinks at pub prices, a quick but extensive lunch and dinner menu starting from around $7, as well as regular entertainment that covers everything from live music to trivia nights.

Easily accessible from Sydney's inner west,east and central CBD areas, 202 Broadway offers an ecclectic and unique mix of cultural experiences for all it's surrounding patrons. From a relaxed , every-night-of-the-week bistro through to hot Salsa and Swing classes, it's not hard to understand the attraction. Throw in some of Sydney's hottest D.J's and 202 Broadway easily becomes a weekend party destination not to be missed. Thursday nights host Basic, where Void, Foreigndub, Headroom and Space Is The Place join forces for this bass-heavy night.

Penrith Hotel can be found in the central business district of Penrith itself(directly opposite the main post office).Weekends serve up an array of live bands and karaoke ,while Wednesday nights find the lovely Portia Turbo hosting their Trivia event.You might just learn a thing or two!
With cheap beer,civilised poker nights and free entertainment always on offer, the Newtown RSL is the perfect place to start(and end) any evening. Worth checking out.

T-bone steak and shoestring chips? We’re there. Classic bistro food in space-age environs, you’ll find yourself in the large polished concrete room faced with choices like fried lamb’s brains or duck pate. A great choice for a quiet Wednesday night.

address.street: Cnr Parramatta Rd and Woodville Rd
Cnr Parramatta Rd and Woodville Rd

content.description: It can be a tough life if you don’t eat meat. Finding decent vegetarian food can be a real challenge, not to mention often disappointing. There’s a ripper vegetarian meal to be had at this massively popular Lebanese stalwart. Sure, there’s very tasty meat on the menu like the cabbage rolls stuffed with lamb and rice or chargrilled chicken skewers, if that’s the way you swing. But with dishes like warm, delicately spiced oregano potato salad or the incredibly comforting eggplant – fl ash fried then slow cooked in tomato puree and served on spiced rice (pilaf) – it’s easy to forget the fl esh of beast. Fifi ’s also do an excellent fattoush – that Lebanese peasant salad of crisp bread, thin cucumber slices, discs of crisp peppery radish, scattered with little shreds of lettuce and Spanish onion brightened with a lemon juice, garlic and olive oil dressing. It’s a small nondescript room but they turn tables quick snippety and the waitresses are old hands, hustling by with plates loaded with pickles and hummus as more Enmore locals (the Birkenstocks and facial piercings give ’em away every time) teem through the door for owner/chef/matriach Fifi Fudda’s falafels, which are some of the best outside of Lakemba. There’s a fairly modest booze selection but they also have Geleb (a type of Lebanese cola which tastes a bit like plum juice) and Lebanese coffee – pure caffeine in a cup. And though the baklava has a long way to go before it’s as fl aky, squishy and sticky as the ones you get way out west, short of leaving the inner sanctum of Enmore, they’re pretty damn good. Fifi ’s is one of your best bets for traditional Lebanese in the inner west. Pass the tabouleh.

Entrees are a pumpkin soup (sour cream swirl and all), Greek salad (with Aussie fetta, alas) and a grilled baby octopus salad cut with a surprisingly zingy lemon dressing (“who’s ‘aving the pussy?” asks the waitress on delivery). Between courses, we’re asked to clear the tables for the “beeeooootful Eeeeeeeva”. Descending from the roof via fireman’s pole before strutting up down the tables to Blondie’s ‘Call Me’ in a vinyl air hostess’s outfit – pieces falling off intermittently – Eva wiggles her toosh in one gent’s face, directs another to oil her buttocks before imploring Time Out to remove our glasses from between her gas-ripened gazongas. The main meal can’t help but be a letdown after such a show. Yet the house specialty lamb shanks gently sigh off the bone and melt in the mouth. The pork fillet looks like pork and smells like pork but tastes like corned beef. Mash and ultra al dente vegetables lend a wintry touch to both mains but considering how much booze is imbibed at these lunches (it’s offered every five minutes in such a way as to be difficult to refuse) such stodge offers much-needed ballast and lets face it, food ain't the focus here. Maybe that’s why there’s a food-free $150 "dessert".

A middle-ofthe-road titty bar – that’s just where it falls in the Sydney strip club continuum. Neither skanky dive nor executive club, it’s clean and comfortable but neither the girls nor the food will have the suited CBD crowd running to the toilet for relief of one kind or another. While there’s no set menu here, you can part with an $11 weekday cover charge ($20 on weekends) and order the juicy lamb shanks for a mere tenner. The veges may have spent a little too much time in the blanching pot and the meat clings to the bone like a drunk to a bottle of goon but at $10 with glimpses of pink flesh on offer (on stage, at least), who’s gonna argue? Elsewhere on Pure Platinum’s menu there’s a butter chicken that comes with a coat of thick grease atop pieces of barely cooked chook and a layered pasta heavily salted and swimming in cheese, both reasonably priced for good reason and solid compliments to the silicone-enhanced side dishes on stage.

It's a hornicopia of square mirrored dance stages dotted with naked pole dancers, some in various stages of thematic (un)dress to celebrate the Spring carnival. The pasty vixen closest to our ringside table is wearing a bikini/sarong made entirely of antique rose curtaining with matching fascinator and, as we sit down to a platter of mixed charcuterie and boiled eggs, she swings a stacked heel or more dangerous item our way. The girls here are less inclined to chat and more to grinding away for laminated dancer dollars to be tucked in their garters. No wonder. The celerysoaked minestrone is dotted with blobs of a mystery cheese, but it’s safer than a dry chicken tikka with cucumber raita and pappadums which haunted us two hours later. Between entrée and main comes Vanessa, reigning Showgirl of the Year, who mambos onto the stage to ‘Feeling Hot Hot Hot’ by Arrow then strips down for the most impressive aerial dance act since Circus Oz. Despite her perma-smile, Vanessa’s the hottest dish in this hell’s kitchen, although sometimes the amount of labia majora on show went close to putting us off a seafood banquet of Balmain bugs, lobster, prawns, scallops and oysters. Elsewhere, there’s veal with Cardinal sauce (creambased but coloured with tomato and brandy). There’s a bar menu, too, if you don’t want to fork out the $80 for two courses where you can eat as simply as a steak sambo and chips.

address.street: Cnr Pennys Lane & Kings Cross Rd
Cnr Pennys Lane & Kings Cross Rd

content.description: Simple, pared-back bistro fare in the heart of the Cross. The confit chicken leg with cavolo nero and blue eye cod with two types of artichoke (Jerusalem and globe – see picture above) are perfectly executed. Well priced wine list too
Big menu, little restaurant. The pages are Blu-Tacked on the wall and feature dishes like salt and pepper calamari as well as Sichuan-style hotpots, noodles, dumplings and congee.

Middle Eastern food in as stylish a space as you’ll see anywhere. Safi is fairly new with slick décor and a snappy menu that reads almost as good as it tastes. The salads, particularly the fattoush (crisp pita bread with cucumber, red onion, lemon and olive oil), are a highlight here, as are the grills.

This restaurant is a North Sydney stalwart on the teppanyaki circuit. It provides the whole kit and caboodle, with fl ying fried eggs, fi sh and rice, and punters trying their very best to catch it all, with varying degrees of success.

address.street: Shop A8, Victoria Plaza, Victoria Ave
Shop A8, Victoria Plaza, Victoria Ave

content.description: You might be waiting awhile to eat here – just keep in mind that it’s worth it. There’s a line stretching outside, but there are also shelves and shelves of tabloid mags to fl ick through, covering everything you ever wanted to know about golf, or about Britney’s latest hair scare. When you fi nally get to the menu, try the barbecue pork egg noodles or even a corned beef sandwich on soft white bread. They also have a Choose Your Own Adventure-style noodle cart, where you can pick anything from cuttlefi sh balls to marinated egg.

The space looks unfi nished even after a couple of years. But we like that. The all-concrete room with exposed iron bars and ceiling vents with the odd smattering of tables and chairs looks as speakeasy as you’ll fi nd in this town. And the negronis can’t be beat.
The rooftop is great on a balmy night.

If two hours of fully choreographed live comedy and rock'n'roll theatre (themed with Rocky Horror Picture Show-type costumes) is your thing, don't we have the venue for you! The Friday Night Comedy Theatre dishes up the hottest local acts, taking musical theatre to new dinner heights. Want more? The theatre turns into a dance party after the show so you can keep partying, and work off your meal. Oh, behave!

If you want to get your Tanya Zaetta on without getting the troops involved, Planet Bollywood is for you. An evening at Planet Bollywood is a mixture of dinner and entertainment; cocktails and karaoke, or watching the latest Bollywood blockbuster. Sounds like you could spend a week there, really. You can sing or dance the night away and if that's not interactive enough, the wonderful hosts can dress you up in Bollywood costumes.

The 3 Weeds is a beautiful old bloodhouse whose days of tooth-loosening infamy are past. Today you'll find the 'Weeds refurbed to the hilt, boasting one of the nicest diners in the inner west and with several bars catering to every taste. The front saloon is Time Out's pick, being more casual than the pumping back room, which overlooks an open kitchen full of copper pots and fine sauces that emerge in the form of everything from wedges to rabbit chestnut terrines.

Curated by Marsu Homme and a gaggle of the label's friends including Beat Poet, Saint Augustine Academy, Elke Kramer, Matt Weston and Izrock, this new curiosity shop is full of goodies such as new and vintage objects, accessories, jewellery, shoes, clocks that go backwards and customised retro hipster glasses.

The Surry Hills Library has a large collection of books, magazines, CDs, DVDs and toys for loan and specialises in fashion and design. This branch has 16 public access computers, a local history section plus a coffee area where you can sit and read or take advantage of the free WiFi.

The Sunday menu looks more like something you’d see in an English pub than a Chippendale café. The roast chicken is excellent. You get half a bird (breast and leg) with a big pile of roast tatties, a little grilled stuffing cake, pumpkin mash, pickled cabbage and gravy. They also do a roast sandwich with your choice of chicken or pork. They don’t offer the regular menu on Sundays, but a separate, smaller menu.

Balmain, Balmain, gentrified Balmain. The collars are up, the terraces are renovated and the Bugaboos are out in full force, set to all-terrain. The Riverview is where the well-heeled gather to drink. On a Saturday or Sunday the front bar will be absolutely packed to the rafters with thirsty mobs. The Riverview has had a recent refit and while the bar is filled with the blonde and fabulous, there are also quite a lot of grizzled old blokes staking a claim at the bar, so it's not all bad.The room is nicely decked out - a fairly sympathetic refurb includes bright red bentwood chairs, mod-light fittings and plenty of dark wood panelling. The restaurant upstairs is worth a nudge if you're planning on making a day of it, but if you're happier staying in the bar there's a fair selection of bar snacks from pizza to Sunday roast.During the warmer months, the 'View gets fantastic air flow and propping up the bar with a beer is an extremely pleasant thing to do. The wine list, put together by hospitality legend David Myers, is progressive, with plenty on there for all price points if you're not interested in sinking schooners.

The room may be simply laid out with a few modest wooden tables inside and out with bright red and white walls but above the counter are all manner of pastizzi ranging from bacon and egg to cheese and chicken and mushroom. Sit down and grab a coffee or snack on the hoof. BYO, around $3.00pp.
These burgers are bloody good. It’s all about the beetroot, barbecue sauce and pineapple.
Join the strange mix of Chinese nannas and surfi es chowing down on seafood, good roast duck and pork dumplings.

A shining star in the George Street throng, it's all about the som tum, the laab, and string (no, that's not a dish, it's Thai pop music). All your faves are here as well as some more interesting dishes. But you'll need to be able to read Thai to know what they are or be brave if you can't.
A fix for every sweet tooth is on hand, but it’s the duck-shaped meringues that delight passers-by and keep us coming back.
Chinese, Malay and Thai noodles. Find another Wok on Inn
Gallery and studio space for over 30 resident artists.

Rosebud, a relative newbie sitting on the old About Life site on Darling Street. This restaurant-slash-bar-slash-café is one of many jumping on the bandwagon to take advantage of the new NSW licensing laws – meaning it's a café by day and wine bar/restaurant by night.The large airy space certainly looks like the perfect place for a breezy brunch, and espresso-heads will be happy to discover that Rosebud churns out a particularly good latte. A combination of long, Bills-esque communal dining tables as well as cosy tables for two and banquettes for bouncy toddlers fill the warehouse-style space, and exposed wiring completes the vibe. While the all-day breakfast looks appealing, we're lured by promise of more exotic fare. The lunch menu and blackboard specials trot the globe with the likes of spaghetti vongole, lamb shanks and that café staple we'd thought had left the building in the late 90s, chermoula. Here, it's crusted on flathead fillets. The whitebait and mint fritters lose something in translation and instead of fresh, flavoursome crisp pucks of tiny wee fish, they're disappointingly stick-to-the-roof-of-your-mouth gluey – it's only a tasty garlic and yoghurt dipping sauce that saves this dish. The mezze platter is more promising, with a generous serving of classic Lebanese fare: lamb shish, pickles and falafel. Big props go to the falafel with its green, soft interior hidden beneath a crisp brown crust. The shish has the aromats right (garlic, cumin and coriander) but the old bugbear of forgetting to salt the food seems to plague this restaurant, too. Great café vibe, killer coffee and a trendy, family-friendly Inner West destination.
Licensed, around $55pp.
content.openingtimes: Lunch Mon–Fri 7am–5pm, Sat 8am–5pm, Sun 8am–4pm; Dinner Wed–Sat 6pm–late.

content.description:
Few people wear two hats as skillfully as Alan Thompson. The international DJ famous for his Ministry of Sound Housexy and Clubbers Guide compilations and tours is fast becoming revered for his brand new homegrown café, Bangbang in Reservoir Street, Surry Hills.
"My plan was to move to Australia from the UK, get my residency and open a café," says Thompson. Clearly this guy likes ticking off his ‘to do' list. Bangbang swung open its doors in Reservoir Street seven weeks ago and has experienced a great lunchtime weekday rush and phenomenal weekend breakfast patronage since its modest debut.
Thompson has put his personal touch into everything, from the menu through to the décor of this inviting little café. His trademark as a DJ is literally set in stone - in a mural depicting oversized headphones on the café's main wall that evokes a sense of urban chic.
Bangbang's menu is warm and inviting. Old- school favourites have been given the Alan Thompson once over and are served up with homely flair. "We make almost everything on the menu from scratch," Thompson assures us. His signature ‘posh fish fingers' offer a refreshing upgrade from Birds Eye. Here, Thompson serves up lightly crumbed strips of fish fillet with aioli on sourdough that is both tasty and filling for under $14. Bangbang's generously sized wagyu beef burger is another must-try and is delivered in a sweet little basket with a serve of crisp potato chips on the side. The Brits just love their crisps!
Bangbang is very well priced, affording locals a regular place to lunch. It's not uncommon to find competitors in the 'hood charging more for a whole lot less, so when it comes to value for money Reservoir Street's newest resident gets a gold star.
Thompson had more than 120 applicants for the position of head barista at Bangbang and tapped the award-winning Phil Capdor for the task. Capdor's latte was one of the best hits I have had in some time and given that this young barista took out fifth place in the 2007 Pura Milk National Latte Art Competition, I wasn't quite sure if I should frame the coffee or drink it.
While communal dining is becoming increasingly popular around the traps, there is enough space between tables here to ensure even the most severe claustrophobic dines comfortably.
Bangbang ticks plenty of boxes, the main being great tasting food at sensible prices, but its real strong suit is its home-made authenticity. There is plenty of passion behind this little gem that will ensure its future as a much talked about destination café and local favourite.
content.openingtimes:
Mon-Friday (Breakfast & Lunch) 8am-4pm;
Sat (All day breakfast) 8am-3pm;
Sun (All day breakfast) 9am-2pm

content.description: You enter the belly of the beast at Allpress. All the heavy artillery -- roasters, grinders, packers - is out back, yet all of it is visible from the sleek cafe frontage on Epsom Road. Service is brusque, but it can afford to be when the coffee blends and gourmet bread are this good and people queue into the street from dusk till dawn. Italian-style sandwiches and panini fly out the door as fast as the coffee and there's constant hustle on the banquettes and booths inside.

Weatherman Tim Bailey, radio tyro Tim Rosso and footy legend Ryan Girdler all spruik Belaroma's blends, and their 40-year legend is set for a new era with Australia's 2007 Barista Champion Scottie Callaghan as head trainer. At their deluxe new Coffee Centre you can roast your own blend, compare eight house varietals and enjoy a cup of caffeinated bliss.

Kurt Cobain sang of the virtues of Penny Royal tea but it's the coffee here that's nirvana. It trickles from a vintage La Marzocco espresso engine that stands sentry over a long narrow space and draws hordes of bean-fiend locals and Lycra-clad cyclists to a cute cafe in a lane behind Mosman Council Chambers. Try their sourdough, ricotta, mushroom and pesto sandwich too.

Formerly a battleground for east coast rednecks, Charing Cross is now a bustling little nexus of cafes, boutiques and organic food fans. Bellagio sits on the Bronte side and its sun-soaked, blue room banquettes provide a pretty vista for devouring muesli with yogurt and berries and hot piping Campos coffee.

In name and nature, The Bunker is a place to hunker down. Here, it's home cooking par excellence with immaculate espressos and, served on the side, gooey eggs and hot buttered toast soldiers, house-styled baked beans and muffins...plus a banana bread with lemon butter fast becoming Sydney legend.

CAFFE QUATTRO PASSI HAS CLOSED AS OF JUNE 2010.This cafe is a true local legend, namely because owners Roberto and Vikki Succi treat everyone as family. Menus change every day but the quality of stews, soups, corn cakes, pies and old school cuisine never falls below fantastic. Nor does Rob and Vikki's knack for remembering names, orders, and quirks in taste - a legacy of Vikki's training as a chef in British country houses. A big hit with mother's groups and Caffe Diemme coffee nuts, Quattro earns brownie points for touches like not charging for double shots, soy, decaf or babycinos. Classy.

entry.name: Toby's Estate Roastery and Espresso Bar

version.name: Toby's Estate Roastery and Espresso Bar

content.description: Roaster Toby Smith is a Sydney coffee alchemist. Although he's spent a lifetime sourcing beans and teas through sustainable networks, his latest venture is the SEE (Social, Ethical & Environmental) Responsibility Project, a stamp that adorns a magnificent seven blends. Its truest embodiment is in the eighth, the Sustainability Blend, a syrupy blend full of dark berries and caramels - a loving cupful best enjoyed at the Roastery & Espresso Bar where Toby runs evening classes at the Espresso School for trainee baristas.

entry.name: Guylian Belgian Chocolate Cafe - The Rocks

version.name: Guylian Belgian Chocolate Cafe - The Rocks

content.description: Sydney is a town built on sweet temptations and black magic, and Guylian deal in both. Their chocolates and cakes come prepared by hand and their coffee carries orgasmic qualities as does the 100% Pure Pleasure which pairs pure choc nirvana with espresso sponge!

The CBD's coolest coffee confederacy is on Clarence Street - owned by Israeli cafe baron Michel, managed by chef Zehavit, and fuelled by the sweet science of Genovese coffee rendered sublime by barista with the most Shelley. Elevated off the street and a clear cut above other big city blackwater barons, Spilling the Beans buzzes with luscious aromas - everything from the mayo the pastries to the muffins is made on the premises - and the puff of a coffee machine being stroked to ever-greater heights. Small but perfectly formed with its open kitchen, Spilling the Beans boasts a cluster of twin-sets for couples conspiring over toasties, home-made lasagne and sausage rolls, and a long table for gangs of office workers keen to gorge on organic breads and Zehavit's tagines.
$2.70 schooners from 5-7pm Mondays.
Not licenced.

entry.name: Guylian Belgian Chocolate Cafe - Circular Quay

version.name: Guylian Belgian Chocolate Cafe - Circular Quay

content.description: Sydney is a town built on sweet temptations and black magic, and Guylian deal in both. Their chocolates and cakes come prepared by hand and their coffee carries orgasmic qualities as does the 100% Pure Pleasure which pairs pure choc nirvana with espresso sponge!

A favourite with local tradies and fishermen up from the Sydney Fish Market, the Harlequin will do you a chicken schnitty burger and a cold beer. There's Thai food, too, but we recommend the fried chicken. Packed out every Friday arvo with thirsty workers, there's something on almost every night of the week, from meat raffles to trivia to a live band on Thursdays.

Laurie’s Vegetarian Take Away resembles a uni cafeteria but with better food and less table politicking. Fill a bowl with wholegrain lasagne, roast vegies and enjoy without the drear of student poverty surrounding you.

This meat-free utopia is a bargain – the $15 thali treats you to various curries, soups, rice, pickles, sweets and breads (including the tube–like poori, which hides a yummy stash of potato onion curry).

A Little On The Side is omnivorous but has great vego breakfast choices, including roasted field mushrooms on sourdough. Late-risers should try the rightfully popular haloumi burger and the witty front of house Brett is an avowed vegetarian himself and is happy to “veg up” dishes containing meat.
Small-beach side gallery with stylish photographic exhibitions usually featuring Bondi, surfing and beach life.

Sitting as close to the beach as possible without being in the sea, Barzura’s waiters haul their precious booty with panache, arms laden with coffee (the machine is churning all day long so it’s well warmed up and thus produces a consistently great brew all day every day) and hot buttered slices of fruit toast. Also on the sweet breeze are banana porridge and BLTs on soft, white rolls. But our pick is the scrambled free range eggs with sweet roasted tomato on multigrain toast. From inside, the only view of the beach you’ll have is the pictures of it on the walls but there are a smattering of tables outside where you can grab a bit of sunshine and a view all at the same time. Oh, and you can pop back in the evening for a cocktail.

For those who seek maximum bang for buck, you can’t beat La Vera. All it costs is $6.50 to buy you two poached eggs spilling gooey yolks all over the shop as well as baked beans, crisp finger-scalding hash browns and two rashers of luscious bacon – it’s an absolute steal. The environment befits the bargainry. It’s a sweet looking little cafe open to the passing parade yet there are still corners you can hide in if you’re feeling a little fragile. By night, La Vera is an excellent pizza and pasta joint but it’s early in the day they excel: they’ve got the classic fry-up down pat, making it a great place to rest and refuel after a bargain binge at the Glebe markets. Make no mistake, La Vera is no fine diner like others in this ‘hood, but for pure value, this is the pony to be betting on.

The Hawthorne Canal reserve is one of the biggest off-leash parks in Sydney. Before Cafe Bones started in 2004, people used to bring their own coffee down while running the hounds but since Cafe Bones opened, Sydney’s dog lovers have somewhere special to kick back, get frisky and frolic. Oh yes, it’s a veritable dog’s breakfast, at this mutt hut. Try the date and walnut bread or the marinated vegetable and cheddar toasted sandwich. For your four legged friend, you’ll find Bones Bix (in-house baked dog biscuits) and liver and lamb treats. And, very sweetly, you can drink a cappuccino while your canine companion gets down with a pupacino (the manager of the cafe, who refused to be mentioned by name, and also to give Time Out the ingredients on account of signing a non-disclosure form (!) He finally admitted it’s a “lactose-free drink with a secret sprinkle”. At any rate, it’s great to have somewhere to take your hound where there’s more catering than a cracked plastic container and a short length of frayed rope.
Maloney’s is a one stop shop with a selection of fresh produce, yoghurts and anything else you may fancy.
Duck in for a croque monsieur – smoky ham, Gruyere cheese and béchamel toasty.

The Hive Bar is all about keeping it in the neighbourhood. Everything's local, from the beers on tap to the artists who decorated the walls to the DJs who spin on a Wednesday night. Erskineville Road is a bustling jungle of traffic but inside the bar, you'd never know it. It's a relaxed space where people hang out and play boardgames that are stacked around the room (there's no Scrabble, but there is Guess Who), drink beers and play records. It's all pretty idealistic at Hive: BYO mug for discounts on coffee and BYO vinyl to spin your own at their Wednesday night Vinyl Club. The room's good ‘n' arty, with walls decked out in prints, spray paint and stencils. A school of colourful carp swims along one wall while treble clefs make their way up the staircase. The bar itself is printed in scarab beetles and a giant spray-painted robotic snake-thing hugs the wall above the bar. Hive features four different local beers on tap (Scharers, St Arnou, Blonde and the extremely malty E'ville) and by the bottle there's Wicked Elf, St Peters and Red Oak. They also feature cocktails (Mojitos, Caipirinhas and Martinis) but you're better off sticking to simple mixers or beer. Or give the wine list a tilt - it's all-Aussie, including the excellent Bloodwood ‘Men in Tights' rosé from Orange. This bar's only going to get better with age - chalk it up as a big plus for the residents of Erko.

"Who's-a next-a?" The constant queue at A&P stretches the breadth of the entire room, which looks more like a cafeteria than a café. The line snakes around tables as customers crane their necks to ogle the glass cabinets full of pastries, biscotti and other baked goods. If service seems a little on the slow side, it's because the folk behind the counter are packing orders into boxes with attention and care. This could be a blessing in disguise because (if you're like us) you'll want to take your sweet time choosing your loot. Takeaway is the way to go, but it's pleasant enough for coffee and a natter – the casual air of the place is reminiscent of Italian train station cafés. San Pellegrino varieties sit out the front, while the small shopfront window features assorted colourful cups and saucers and intricate-looking wedding cakes. It's not all sugar and caffeine, though – by late afternoon savoury snacks (pizza squares, panini) are fast disappearing, and we watch agape as a giant box of golden arancini walks out the door. From the outside this modest-looking pasticceria seems unassuming and run-of-the-mill, but inside the hustle and bustle hints at its status as a crowd favourite in the Inner West. The walls are plastered with "Dear Customer..." notes that remind us returns will not be accepted, but it is hard to fathom the necessity with pastries this delightful. Paradoxically, there's no signage describing the vast array of treats sitting in the glass cabinets below. Perhaps the pastries, cakes and meringues are decoration enough. Fat cannoli come in chocolate, vanilla and custard (and also piccolo size) while chocolate-dipped, jam-filled biscuits melt in your mouth. The zingy jam sandwiched between the buttery biscuit is a lovely balance: chocolate plus jam equals splendido. The bigné (cream-filled profiterole-like pastries) are a little bit on the dry side, but let yourself be tempted by the heart jam-decorated, icing sugar-dusted shortbread: it's romance in a biscuit. The pasticceria also does a great line in gelati, and word on the street is the tiramisu cake is a goer. While Haberfield is dotted with establishments purporting to be authentic Italian, A&P's attention to detail and its vast range ensure it's the real deal. Do yourself a favour and join the queue.
They're open late and the highlight is the potato pie. If you're traipsing up King St in a beer fug, these guys'll sort you out.

entry.name: Sylvia and Fran's The Upper Crust

version.name: Sylvia and Fran's The Upper Crust

content.description: For something to eat when keeping pelicans company, this is the pony to bet on. Slices of asparagus and chunks of chook get hella messy but that's what the pelicans are for.

Each morning between 9 and 11am, Wayside offer a breakfast program for Sydney’s homeless. The city’s street lifers aren’t cooked for but there’s a fully operational kitchen so they can help themselves to coffee and cereal. There are always volunteers around to hang out with or chew the fat with. On Saturdays and Sundays, community volunteers serve porridge, toast, eggs and cereal. Wayside Chapel invites anyone who needs it to come in and have a feed – whether it’s the homeless or folks just down on their luck, they don’t ask questions. To volunteer, please call. Pastor - Rev Graham Long's Wayside Stories
Okay, it's a meat pie with heaps of gravy, mystery filling and slightly yellow pastry but there's no better pie for that stinging headache from the night before.
$2.50 schooners Monday to Friday 4-6pm.
Sweet and luscious and tangy, it's all crumbly, sweet goodness. To all intents, it is the bomb.

Looking for a steak in the Hills region? Look no further! But be warned: the servings at Castle Hill RSL hot-spot The Rib Factory are titanic. “Big Jackaroo” Rumps and “Drovers Ribs” tip the scales at almost 1kg each, all gorgeous grain-fed prime meat expertly marinated and char-grilled over an open flame. On Wed-Thurs nights for a limited time $35 gets you a shared entrée and a magnificent main meal each. As if this wasn't enough - fitness has hit the RSL so you can combine the daily roast and schooner with a spin class, and while they may not have Elvis, they've got the Big O. (Well, a Roy Orbison impersonator, at any rate).

Get your brain on with Tuesday trivia or free competitions for just about anything you can lay your hands on. Learn to play poker with the pros or take advantage of the three free snooker tables for members. Roast: No. Bingo: Yes, every Friday from 2pm. (There are also poker tournaments on Sundays at 2pm and Thursday evenings from 6pm). Meat Trays: Yes, every Thursday and Friday from 7.30pm. Member's draws: Yes, Lucky Memberships draw every Friday from 6.30pm. Family Friendly: Yes. Function Rooms: Yes.

It's golf, golf and more golf but there's also trivia and free rock n roll dancing on Fridays. They do a big trade in weddings but it's also a picturesque spot for a drink and a snack. Roast: Roast of the day, $10. Bingo: No, but there's trivia on Thursdays. Meat Trays: Every Friday from 6pm. Family Friendly: Yes, there's even a kids' game room with pinnies.
It's massive, it's set over three levels and it's got a Mexican style restaurant. Ole!
