But it's the brick ovens, visible behind glass in the back by the kitchen, that it's all about. As far as we know, Golden Moon is the only restaurant which roasts its ducks over wood. (The menu claims fruitwood, as per the custom in Beijing, but the waiter we pegged said they also use eucalypts, depending on supply.) The oven also gives its smoky tang to full-blood wagyu beef, lamb cutlets, "aluminium foil-wrapped king prawns", baby abalone and pork chin, whatever that is, but it's really all about the duck. The fact that the first course comes out already sliced rather than carved tableside doesn't bode well, but as soon as you pick up the pancakes, steamy and supple, things look up. The skin has been cut to give a mix of nothing but crisp skin and piece of skin with juicy meat attached - you take a pancake, smear it with a little sweet bean sauce (tit's similar to hoisin and here, too sweet, we'd say), add batons of spring onion and cucumber, then some duck and fold the lot and eat it by hand: bliss. In Beijing you'd also be offered some sugar to dip the meat in, something that doesn't seem to have caught on Down Under. The second course sees the remaining duck meat shredded, stir-fried and served in neatly trimmed iceberg lettuce cups as san choi bao. If you opt for the third course, you'd get the classic duck soup made from the bones of your bird. It's brimming with straw mushrooms, preserved egg and silken tofu, the very definition of soothing. So is it the best duck in town? Maybe. It's still a got a way to go before it's as good as it could be - the skin could be that much crisper, the meat that much more tender - but it's an impressive showing, and reason enough alone in itself to pay the restaurant a visit. Service is fairly brusque and not really seriously geared to serve an English-speaking or wine-drinking clientele (the wine list offers a strong motivation to BYO), but there's no question that we'll be back, to see how the duck's coming along, to dig further through the menu, to try the goose liver paste, the crisp-skinned chicken and the deep-fried pigeon. Not to mention the wood-roasted pig chin. Jim Lee
content.openingtimes: lunch, dinner and late-night supper daily

content.description: Madame Rouge Boutique is set over 2 floors, with luxurious lingerie at street level, and a naughtier den full of delights upstairs. From sensual potions, right through to the LELO range, a designer collection of "pleasure objects", you'll be sure to be spoiled for choice by what you find.
content.openingtimes: Mon - by appointment only; Tues-Wed & Fri-Sat 11am-6pm; Thurs 11am-7pm; Sun - Closed

content.description: From vintage-inspired lingerie through to generous bras and even fascinators, this boutique little store will tap into the inner flirt in everyone. The outfits are sexy, flattering and feminine, with an accent on vintage designs and fabrics across the biggest names in the biz. Finally, a store you can shop in as a couple without shame!
The centre aims to create an environment of learning and opportunity, which will foster talent and pave the way for brighter futures for Indigenous Australians.
The centre provides city residents, workers, students and visitors with state of the art sports and fitness facilities and community services.
content.openingtimes: Main Centre - Mon-Fri 6.30am-9pm; Sat-Sun 10am-4pm. Fitness Centre - Mon-Thurs 6.30am-8.30pm; Fri 6.30am-7pm; Sat 10am-4pm; closed Suns

content.description: Youth centre with a range of facilities including a basketball court, TV and DVD player, pool table, table tennis, fooz-ball, playstation 3, wii, DJ equipment and computers with internet access.
content.openingtimes: During school term - Tues-Thurs 3:30pm-6pm; Fri 3:30pm-8pm; Sat 12pm-5pm. School holidays - Tues-Fri 1pm-6pm; Sat 12-5pm

content.description: A good old fashioned bakery just around the corner from Milsons Point train station.
The home of the Woodford Folk Festival and - in 2010, at least - the site for Splendour in the Grass.

address.street: Above the Light Brigade Hotel, Jersey Rd (Cnr Melrose La)
Above the Light Brigade Hotel, Jersey Rd (Cnr Melrose La)

content.description:
Do not adjust your sets. This is not a glitch in the Matrix. Just as the name La Scala is only very slightly different to La Sala, the menu is very nearly identical. But if it ain't broke, folks, why fix it? It saw La Sala packed and also drew a following out at Palm Beach's Barrenjoey House. And, if you're long in the tooth (and wallet) enough, it might even remind you a bit of eating at the River Café. Like Jamie Oliver, chef Darren Simpson worked at the famous London Italian restaurant under Ruth Rogers and the late Rose Gray. Unlike Jamie Oliver, who went on the spawn countless books, television shows and children with silly names, Simpson moved to Australia, making his mark with a clutch of River Café-esque hits that Sydneysiders have been clamouring for ever since. Simpson seems content to keep doing what he does best and Sydney is more than happy to let him. Dates stuffed with almonds and fried crisp in batter; roasted bone marrow with parsley salad (an ode to London restaurant St John more than the River Café); vitello tonnato "my way": winning dishes all. And let's pause for a moment to give the chocolate nemesis cake its due: this famously hard to bake, mousse-like cake has had plenty of cooks in tears. It's famously tricky to make (always too wet, too dry, or a frightening mix of both), but not so at La Scala. Here, to quote Goldilocks, it's juuuuust right. And, like the dates, the bone marrow and the vitello tonnato, is almost worth a visit in itself. Simpson roasts the veal for his tonnato (the tradional number is poached) and drizzles the tuna mayo over the top, garnishing with a mess of green beans and capers. And yes, it's very, very good. Recruiting Simpson is a wise investment for the Light Brigade. While they've given the upstairs restaurant a whole new interior decor that you could label as overly busy, you can't accuse them of slotting in just another chef and waiting to see what happens. They might, however, want to take a closer look at their service. It's a bit all over the shop at the moment (water orders lost or confused, wine being served after the food has arrived, no bread for the bread plates), though it's nothing more practice and a good floor manager couldn't correct. If you want to eat one of the best carpaccios in the city, though, you should try the one at La Scala. Unlike the many versions you'll see, this version is true to its Venetian roots and translates as thin slices of raw beef dressed with a Jackson Pollock squiggle of Worcestershire, beef jus, mayonnaise and lemon juice. That's all it is, and that's all it needs to be. Manzo – rib eye steak on the bone – is hidden under a salad of radicchio, Roman beans and, wait for it, drunken cheese. What is that intriguing sounding stuff? It's basically a pecorino cheese made tangy with wine and grape 'must' (not-quite-wine grape juice). Can we just go back to that chocolate nemesis cake one more time? It really is a marvel. This slender, dark little wedge of cake with a perfect quenelle of creme fraiche is one of the lightest-yet-richest desserts you're likely to taste.
For all the faults out the front (did we mention the bland doof-doof music in the background?), La Scala's kitchen is firing. Déjà vu never tasted this good. Myffy Rigby
Locals brunch cafe with shaded outdoor area.

Fairfield is renowned for its Asian cuisine. And while Fairfield RSL offers a selection of sensational Chinese and Vietnamese noodles at its Pho@fairfield, it’s the Club’s La Tratt Italian restaurant that gets the raves . Intimately lit with a sophisticated menu, La Tratt has won more awards than any other club in Sydney. But the secret is out so book ahead!

entry.name: South Sydney Graphic Arts Club - Mascot

version.name: South Sydney Graphic Arts Club - Mascot

content.description: Tucked away in a suburban street is a club pilots and flight attendants have made a legend. So good is the SSFCA club’s menu, it makes more money from its food than its pokies! No surprise when you consider assistant manager James McKenzie once cooked for Princess Diana! Now he’s cooked up a Tight Arse Tuesday 3-course meal for $20 truly fit for royalty.

Set smack bang on the Parramatta River, Dooleys boasts a smorgasbord of wonderful dining choices catering to food connoisseurs, casual diners and families. The menus change daily with the Brasserie filled to the gills with delicious fresh fare – prawn risotto, pastas, steaks, a Sunday roast as good as Mum’s and a $14.95 seafood platter Mon–Thu. Entertainment is also a highlight with big acts in the Waratah Ballroom and a dedicated Kids room nearby.
High-end women's fashion boutique.
Recently moved to a larger premises, Pretty Dog stock a number of local fashion labels.
Stocks international and standout local labels.
Stocks both international and standout local labels.
With a strong rock influence, Alvin Manalo's Surry Hill based fashion label features directional tailoring and an edgy look.
Stocking tailored casual wear for both women and men from Australian and International designers.
On-trend fashion boutique selling labels such as Mauri & Eve and Mezi.
Optometrist stocking an impressive range of spectacles and shades such as Colab or Isson.
Stockists of an eclectic range of local accessories.
Established for 50 years, this recently refurbished shop stocks a massive selection of hats and men's accessories.

Accoutrement has been established in Mosman for over 25 years selling quality cookware, tableware, gourmet foods and cookery classes from well-known chefs.
Plus, their cooking classes see many of Australia's best chefs run demonstrations of their culinary magic. Classes take place on a Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday at 6.30pm, and the odd weekend class on a Saturday afternoon ($99-$175). Their online brochure lays out the calendar year's classes, so you can book your favourite chef well in advance. Most classes are demonstration only. They also run excursions to destinations such as Sardinia, Morocco and Périgord (around $6,000 per person: those truffles don't come cheap).
The Cloakroom is a dedicated men's boutique specialising in tailor-made clothing and effects.

Rojo Rocket was founded on the dream to bring a slice of the real Mexico to Australia. Part owners Ngaldi Lupercio and Adrian Reed teamed up with Ken West, owner of Big Day Out, and his partner Cathy Rechichi to create this unique restaurant and bar. Authentic in every facet, from the amazing decor to the chef from Playa del Carmen Mexico, the Rojo Rocket is the ultimate cultural experience.
Cheap, tasty Asian goodness. You can eat here for a fiver.
Burgerman use fresh, quality ingredients to create traditional burgers with a twist. They offer burgers cooked fresh to order with table service and beers available.
Now with 7 locations across Sydney, Doughboy delivers pizzas with an authentic Italian flavour.
Now with 7 locations across Sydney, Doughboy delivers pizzas with an authentic Italian flavour.
Now with 7 locations across Sydney, Doughboy delivers pizzas with an authentic Italian flavour.
Now with 7 locations across Sydney, Doughboy delivers pizzas with an authentic Italian flavour.
Now with 7 locations across Sydney, Doughboy delivers pizzas with an authentic Italian flavour.

entry.name: Harrogate Tea Shop and Tea Rooms

version.name: Harrogate Tea Shop and Tea Rooms

content.description: This little teashop, also selling coffee and fine foods, is situated in an atmospheric period property in Pyrmont with a tearoom upstairs.
Here you can peruse 180 different teas and a beautiful range of accessories in the shop, or simply have a cuppa in their tearoom.
Settle in on a Monday for $5 pints of Bulmer cider. Local schooners are just $3.50 from 5-6pm too.
Wash down the $5 pub steak with $3 house drinks from 3-6pm weekdays. Is this Sydney's cheapest steak and beer combo?

Just over the Harbour Bridge, The Commodore Hotel has an impressive outside terrace beer garden, with views of Sydney Harbour. There is also a quality bistro, versatile function room for 20 to 200 guests, and a well stocked bottleshop.
The Blues Point Hotel is one of the original Northern Suburb Pubs with terrace bars, great Bistro food, a versatile function room, pool tables, TAB and boutique accommodation.

Lord John Montagu, fourth Earl of Sandwich, had a penchant for playing cards and eating meat between pieces of bread. In a tribute to his lordship, owner Robert Brennan has named his Crows Nest café for the earl, with a big portrait of the big man, to boot. Tucked away off the main drag (a quick step down the lane off Ernest Street), this little café is big on sandwiches. Try a panino with the likes of salmon, egg and horseradish crème fraiche, or an egg, bacon and beetroot relish number. Cooking the apple for the ham and gruyère sambo might have been a more exciting move than serving it raw, but the crunchy texture gives it some bite. Staying away from the evil (yet so very delicious) carbs? There's a salad of Moroccan lamb with preserved lemon and chickpea dressed with tahini. Take it to vego town by ordering it sans lamb. Or give the lentil and cumin patties with coriander and yoghurt a tilt. The fruit bread, studded with chunks of fig, apricot and other delights, is served with organic Kangaroo Island honey and ricotta. Coffee-wise, Montagu serves the Single Origin blend of Colombian and Indian beans. Small, low-sitting tables and stools spill out into the courtyard from folding doors, and an inviting, grassy hill is dotted with people lunch breaking and sun baking. You can bring a rug along and picnic with the bready goods on offer at Montagu, but add one dollar to the price of each item to dine in. Service is friendly and prompt, and the tiny little tables and stools add a certain Sydney charm. If you like your sandwiches to be more than slices of meat between pieces of bread, Montagu is a pretty good start.Nancy Lee

What is it? A poky little restaurant hidden down an alley off the main drag of Cabramatta. What's it like? Tuong Lai is packed with Vietnamese nannas, couples, hungry workers and kids. The vibe is bustling and no-nonsense with the usual DIY cutlery, condiments and tissue boxes on every table. The menu on the wall (all written in Vietnamese) can be daunting at first but staff know enough English to provide guidance. What should I order? Sugar cane prawns ($11), or chao tom, are a Central Vietnamese delicacy consisting of two skewers of light and fluffy shrimp paste wrapped around sticks of fresh sugar cane. First steamed and then grilled, the prawn paste is fragrantly sweet and deliciously caramelised on the edges. How do you eat them? Cut the prawn paste off the sugar cane and into bite-sized chunks. Dig in with your hands and wrap the prawn paste into lettuce parcels with the accompanying bean sprouts, perilla leaves and mint. Don't forget the vermicelli noodles, stir-fried shallots and tumble of crushed peanuts. Dip into the sweet chilli, garlic and fish sauce dressing of nuoc cham. Then there's dessert - sucking and chewing the leftover sugar cane to get at the juice within.What else? Com tam suon bi cha ($7.50) is a sweet grilled pork chop served on broken rice with pork mince steamed egg, shreds of pork skin dusted with roasted rice powder and a handful of cucumber and pickled carrots. Upgrade to com dac biet ($8) for the fried egg, sunny-side up. Bun thit nem ($7) is a refreshing cold vermicelli noodle dish topped with grilled pork, pickled vegetables and peanuts served with nuoc cham dressing. The pho dac biet ($8) is a commendable version of the beef noodle soup with beef and tripe. Chai gio spring rolls ($7.50) are even better when wrapped with lettuce and mint.Helen Yee

Anyone living down Bondi Road must be seriously happy not having to shell out 30 bucks for a ride to the Cross to find a good, affordable cocktail bar. Flying Squirrel and Rum Diaries set the scene for tapas and drinks; now the newly opened Corner House is continuing the tradition. With cocktail competition veteran Kass Hill behind the mahogany, you're guaranteed a good tipple - even if its not on the list. Hill will stir, mix and shake anything within reason, but we recommend a Hendricks Martini with a twist alongside some of chef Brent Mills' seriously good snacks. Sure beats the olden days of pub grub and a schooner of Carlton while avoiding trouble at the once-was-dodgy Royal Hotel across the street.
Decorative furniture warehouse showroom also available for private functions, photo shoots, fashion events and product launches.

Sydney is obsessed with reinventing itself, mainly because of the fit-out cost of establishing a new bar or restaurant. If this is what we're stuck with, then it's pleasing when you walk into a space to find a bar that works a lot better than its former incarnation. Eau de Vie did a brilliant job of the once-was Fix Bar at the Kirketon; Manly Wine funkified the former Will & Toby's beachside bar; and now Stanley Street Station is continuing the trend in fine fashion.Stanley Street Station commands the corner of Crown and Stanley Streets in East Sydney, the site that was formerly Just Another Restaurant – one of the worst names in recent hospitality history. The furniture in the bar section – an ottoman here and a retro couch there – works well with the 50s swing music creeping out from the speakers. The low coffee tables are perfect for small bites from the grazing menu and the lighting is just right.Thankfully, the Station hasn't followed the trend of several Darlo bars by charging eight bucks for a beer you wouldn't normally order – and frankly won't drink again – and instead has gone down the ‘touch above pub prices' path. Coopers Pale is $6 and a Peroni $7. Wines by the glass range from $7 to $11 and cocktails head north from $14. Classics are priced at $16 (think Martinis, Negronis, Margaritas and Mint Juleps) and that's just about right for both this area and the fact they are serving good quality house spirits (Herradura Reposado is used in the Margarita). Then, wash down the booze with some food from the grazing menu, particularly the lamb rump with balsamic onions and goat labne ($16) and fries with mayo ($6). Okay, so why only three stars? Well, Stanley Street Station is primarily a restaurant and even though the bar area is comfortable, it loses intimacy and you do feel like you are in an eating house. It's a shame because the service is brilliant and quite simply if the entire venue was converted into a space the same as the bar area (couches and low tables) and featured an extensive shared plate menu (lose the mains), it would, hands down, be one of the best lounge bars in Sydney. James Wilkinson
Hybrid arts space and venue.
The St Ives Showground caters for a variety of activities including picnics, equestrian, cycling, circuses, minibike riding and large events such as the St Ives Show and the Heritage Craft Fair.

Since it opened in 1995,The Tea Centre has served as a cosy nook for Sydneysiders providing respite from the cold and gusty street corners of the city. Offering over 180 tea varieties, The Tea Centre has a belly warmer for everone. There's a café in which to enjoy a cuppa and a piece of cake, and plenty of accessories for sale so that you can enjoy your favourite brew at home.
Sushi Fusion have a delicious range of fresh sushi rolls including feta and dried tomato, roast pumpkin and avocado, salmon teriyaki as well as spicy salmon and avocado for just $2.80 each!
Casa Barilla Cooking School is Sydney's heart of Italian food. Each Casa Barilla class lasts 2.5 hours, is intimate (no more than 16 people) and interactive - you cook and eat!

Cucina Italiana is located in a historic heritage listed Italian Villa built nearly a century ago by the Melocco Brothers. Classes emphasise teaching real Italian cooking, the home cooking that you can only find in a truly Italian home.
The hippest bicycle, scooter and apparel shop in Woolloomooloo, if not Sydney. There's also a huge table and fresh coffee for those waiting for afficiandos - because they will be in here a long time.
New art gallery and exhibition space.

This restaurant with adjoining cocktail bar offers amazing panoramic views of Sydney Harbour, the Opera House and the Botanic Gardens. Enjoy their International and modern Australian cuisine whilst taking it all in.

Dietmar Sawyere is unstoppable. Having re-opened Berowra Waters Inn in 2007 and added a guesthouse down the river, and recently closed Forty One, he has now opened Ad Lib - the pride of Pymble.
Here, you'll find all the restaurant finesse of Berowra Waters, only in a bistro setting. While you won't find brass railings, specials written in lipstick on old mirrors or the warm golden glow of old lamps (it's a fairly nondescript space) there's all the hustle and bustle of a proper French bistro. The room is typically packed and everyone's having a good time.
The offering is more casual as well as being cheaper, sure, but there's still a high level of service and the food is made with exceptional skill and great produce. Onion soup, thick with tendrils of melted gruyere and topped with a slice of (more) melted gruyere on toast, is brown, glossy and, well, oniony. Porky pucks of ear, trotter and tail are fried and served with a runny sauce gribiche and if you're a complete glutton you might order a couple of fresh-shucked oysters to have on the side. As it is, ordering the soup with a mimosa salad on the side is gut-busting enough. A mimosa salad, in case you're unsure, is a traditional French salad where a boiled egg is grated with the white and yolk separated. Here, though, they cheat a little (or update, if you like) with a slow-cooked egg hiding under a nest of frisée lettuce, bits of fried pork jowl and tiny little crisp croutons.
The duck liver parfait is like eating thick cream on toast. Light and fluffy and served in a teeny little jar with slices of sourdough, it's the best you'll find in town. If you want, there's steak (tartare, sirloin, fillet, rib eye). But there's also the braised chicken thighs - coq au vin style - with big sprigs of chervil, Dutch carrots, pine mushrooms and lardons. If you order sides, this dish is big enough to share between two.
And the sides – oh my, the sides. Go Swiss with the likes of spätzle (an irregularly shaped European style boiled noodle) with fried onions and cheese or crisp shavings of potato rösti. What about a side of buttered tagliatelle or French fries and mayo? The possibilities to carb load are endless. If you haven't actually ruptured your abdominal sheath at this point, why not order dessert? They serve massive quenelles of their dark chocolate mousse tableside out of a giant bowl, drizzled with thick cream, garnished with chocolate wafer straws.
The wine list offers great value. The first page of the list is broken into four different serving sizes from tasters to full bottles with nothing over $60. Of course, you feel you'd like to splash out a little more, flip overleaf for reserve wines.
Service is friendly and skewed towards locals. In fact, don't be surprised if you see chef/owner Dietmar Sawyere on the floor busting a few plate moves himself. Now splitting his time between Berowra and Ad Lib, he's also rumoured to be expanding the guesthouse at Berowra to include a set of tree houses out the back and maybe even a houseboat. Bring it on, we say. Myffy Rigby

We understand that this restaurant HAS CLOSED. September 2010. This restaurant in the heart of the Cross serves traditional Greek food from all regions of Greece in ultra modern surroundings. There is also an extensive list of Greek and Australian wines and ouzos available to complement each meal.
Nestled in the heart of the city, Aesops has offered traditional Greek food and entertainment since 1991 - from dancing the Zorba to smashing plates. Also offers takeaway.
The speciality at this Italian restaurant is their wood-fired pizza. However, they also serve a number of other classic dishes in pleasant surroundings.
Situated right on the water with floor to ceiling windows or the option of alfresco dining, Angelo's offers great views whilst specialising in seafood dishes by Chef Suna McKay.

Speialising in Italian aperitivi - small-plate Mediterranean dishes similar to Spanish Tapas - served with refreshing light alcoholic drinks such as Prosecco and Campari. Main dishes are also offered.

This traditional Thai restaurant is designed to look like a traditional 18th century Thai noble house complete with a tea room. Authentic Thai cuisine is prepared using fresh Australian produce which can sometimes even include kangaroo and emu.

Specialising in seafood, Atlantis in North Ryde offers food with a Mediterranean influence. Alfresco dining is available also. Every Sunday there is a buffet lunch including fresh prawns, Sydney rock oysters, blue swimmer crabs and Mussels Provencale.
Situated right on the water in an 1830's sandstone cottage, Banjo Paterson Cottage Restaurant serves European cuisine and fine wines.
content.openingtimes:
Lunch: Tue-Fri & Sun froom 12pm;
Dinner: Tues-Sat from 6.30pm

content.description: Reasonably priced and unpretentious, this little cafe offers authentic Italian food with the option of alfresco dining. This Leichhardt institution is also now open for breakfast.
Offering a large selection of pizzas and pastas, Bertani are open late every night of the week and offer takeaway.

Big Mama's has been serving up authentic Italian food in the heart of Woollahra for the last 20 years, but their management changeover in 2007 gave their range of traditional trattoria-style dishes a modern update.

Located in a converted Arnott's biscuit factory, this stylish bistro-style restaurant and wine bar turns out a range of wood-fired pizzas and other contemporary European fare under the eye of head chef and co-owner, Derek Baker.
The team at Bistroteque reflect their motto of "freshness and simplicity with passion" in the licensed modern Australian cafe/restaurant, serving sandwiches, pastas and salads to a city crowd.
A laid back beachside cafe by day and slick dining spot and bar by night, this Bondi institution serves up modern Australian food for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Licensed and BYO.
This colourful and modern café/bistro serves good quality food at reasonable prices with great service. It’s also a great place to have brunch.

This wine bar/restaurant is set in an old post office in Beecroft. The latest offering from Toni Abassi (owner of Sevardi and Positano), BPO offers authentic Italian food and a large selection of wines.

This second addition to the Braza Churrascaria chain brings all you can eat grilled meats to the North Shore. This Brazilian restaurant has a definite meat focus, but vegetarian options are available.
This cosy Italian restaurant, complete with red-and-white checkered tablecloths and kitsch interiors, boasts an extensive menu of home-style food and barbecued specialties.
This homely Surry Hills restaurant offers contemporary South American favourites, like dulce de leche flavoured ice cream, plus a good selection of Spanish and Latin American beers and wines.

Clareville Kiosk is situated next to Clareville Beach on the North Shore. Originally a post office and general store, the Kiosk became a restaurant in 1983. Now, under chef Matthew Kneipp who has worked with Marco Pierre White, the Kiosk serves simple, fresh food. BYO wine is permitted every night except Saturday.
Serving classic Indian dishes straight from the tandoor in addition to other Mumbai area favourites like vindaloos and samosas, and they usually have a special dinner deal on offer.
La Collina is a traditional Italian family restaurant that specialises in seafood with many alternative options present on the menu. Catering and takeaway is also available.
Offering Nepalese dishes such as pumpkin chicken and masala goat, this simple Leichhardt restaurant offers eat-in or takeaway. BYO also available for wine only.

Sahara serves a range of pan-mediterranean dishes, from greek mezze share platters to Turkish-style chargrilled meats cooked on an open flame in front of guests. They also have another restaurant in Burwood.
You’ll find every Vietnamese dish here you could possibly desire with their lengthy menu of authentic dishes and a selection of chef’s specials. Local delivery is also available.
A casual café/restaurant located within the Norwest Business Park offering mod oz breakfast and lunch options. They’re licensed and can also offer corporate catering services.

A sophisticated but relaxed restaurant in the CBD, serving up contemporary Australian bistro-style dishes, like crab-stuffed zucchini flowers and rosewater crème chiboust, for the corporate lunch and after work crowd.
Not too far from its fellow Abassi-owned BPO wine bar and restaurant, Sevardi takes a more casual approach to serving a range of modern, hearty Italian dishes in an intimate setting.
This quirky yum cha restaurant has recently been refurbished. Situated on bustling Campbell Parade, it offers outdoor dining and spectacular views of Bondi Beach.
The open-plan design of this contemporary, spacious restaurant feels as if you’re dining right on the beach, with a lengthy selection of modern Australian tasting plates and larger portions.

Fresh grilled or fried fish is served at this busy CBD location. Sit outside and watch the bustling city go by or get cosy inside. Alternatively reel in your catch and take it home. And what's fish without chips and salad too?
The Lighthouse is an oyster bar and seafood restaurant serving modern Australian food in the heart of Parramatta. There is also a cocktail bar here for you to enjoy a sneaky pre-dinner drink.
Moroccan-born chef Omar serves up contemporary North African dishes while the bar has created a list of spiced up cocktails, like the Turkish Blue Apple Martini with orange blossom water.
A fully licensed tapas haunt complete with outdoor courtyard, banquet menus for larger groups, a secret family sangria recipe and live flamenco shows on Fridays and Saturday nights.
Offering an extensive menu of authentic Lebanese food with entertainment in the form of Arabic music and belly dancers in the evenings.
In the thick of Sydney’s Spanish Quarter, this two-levelled restaurant serves lunch and dinner and has live performances throughout the week from solo Spanish guitarists and flamenco bands.
This Italian restaurant specialises in seafood and grilled meats with a large selection of wines. It has an alfresco dining area and is kid-friendly.
This family run café just around the corner from bustling Clovelly beach serves simple and fresh mod oz meals throughout the day, transitioning to a restaurant during the evening.

Ex-NRL player Matt Adamson has taken over this family-run Italian eatery, which specialises in modern Italian cuisine in a friendly family environment. There's daily chalkboard specials and an all-you-can-eat deal on Wednesdays.
Mazzaro serves Mediterranean food in the heart of the city, looking out onto Hyde Park. Their emphasis is on seafood, but meat and vegetarian dishes are available also.

Chefs and brothers Rudi and Max Dietzle have been serving favourites from their German homeland at Stuyvesants for over 30 years. Locals keep coming back for the impressive selection of imported beers, spirits and liqueurs, as well as the hearty European fare.
In the heart of Parramatta, the Mediterranean Kitchen has an extensive menu representing a number of different Mediterranean countries.
Husband and wife duo, Yoshiki and Yoshimi, have had this local Japanese eatery up and running for ten years. They specialise in seafood dishes, with a reputation for super fresh sashimi.
Taking its name from a double-handled mincing knife, Mezzaluna serves modern Italian food in swish surroundings. There are magnificent views across the city. Set-lunch menu available on Fridays.
This local Glebe haunt has a reputation for fresh Indian food – spice levels to suit all palettes - and speedy service with a smile. They’re licensed and delivery is available to surrounding suburbs.

Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner, the Museum of Sydney Cafe serves modern Australian cuisine - light bites and more filling meals. There is also a bar here which offers a Monday to Friday happy hour.

address.street: Stamford Plaza Sydney Airport Hotel, Cnr O'Riordan & Robey Sts
Stamford Plaza Sydney Airport Hotel, Cnr O'Riordan & Robey Sts

content.description: Have your fish cooked how you like it or rampage the impressive seafood buffet at this hotel restaurant inside the Stamford Plaza in Mascot. If seafood’s not your thing, the rest of the menu’s cuisine is ‘international’ to suit every traveller’s tastes.
Traditional decor and traditional Polish food such as pierogi (Polish dumplings), are on offer in this Glebe eatery. Set menu available.

Regional Italian dishes are the go at this Glebe old-timer (it’s been around since 1980) where you can find classics, like papardelle with duck ragu and porcini mushrooms, served in their covered courtyard.

address.street: cnr Campbell Pde and Beach Rd
cnr Campbell Pde and Beach Rd

content.description: This externally managed Swiss Grand Hotel restaurant, perched on the building’s terrace, offers family friendly service overlooking Bondi Beach – a bistro-style steakhouse at affordable prices.
With an alfresco dining area, this family friendly restaurant specialises in pizza cooked in its wood-fired oven. A good selection of pastas is also available.

This restaurant serves modern Australian dishes each evening. At the weekends it is also open for breakfast and lunch serving lighter dishes. It also has a special menu menu for kids and an outdoor courtyard.
Combining pizzas, pastas and seafood with an Asian and Australian influence, Pane e Vino is a cafe by day and restaurant by night. There is regular Flamenco entertainment on Friday nights.
Serving classic Italian pasta, meat and fish dishes with a modern twist, Pazzo is situated in the heart of Surry Hills. Banquet menus are available.
Peroni's serves traditional Italian food with an extensive menu complemented by a large selection of wines. BYO wine is also possible here. Check out their lunchtime specials.

Puntino Trattoria offer homemade pizza and pasta dishes made with fresh ingredients. Situated in Woolloomooloo, they also offer cookery classes at their restaurant, or weekend courses away from Sydney.
Raavi's Cumin serves a large selection of authentic North Indian Punjabi dishes, such as marinated kebabs, rich curries, and, of course, dishes laced with the fragrant cumin spice.
Serving classic Italian dishes such as pizzas and pastas on the Coogee strip close to the beach, Renato's Italian Restaurant is usually pretty busy.
Situated in the heart of Penrith's CBD, this recently refurbished restaurant is family-owned and run. They offer an extensive menu of Italian dishes.
Priding itself on traditional food, generous portions, realistic prices and welcoming hospitality, Romano's is situated in the quiet suburb of Castlecrag.

Roman's Cafe & Restaurant offers a unique dining experience, decorated with traditional Roman touches such as the black, red and white. Seafood (the preferred dish of the Romans) is the speciality at this eating joint.
Le Mirage Restaurant in Baulkham Hills offers classic Vietnamese dishes from an extensive menu in a family-friendly environment. BYO is available here.
This contemporary French bistro takes its inspiration from the Basque region of France using fresh produce to create dishes from its constantly changing menu.

Set in a historic sandstone cottage, Chef Paul Kuipers ever-changing Modern Australian menu incorporates the freshest local ingredients. A degustation menu is available, showcasing great Australian, Italian and French wines.
Friendly and relaxed, this suburban restaurant has an indulgent menu created by Chef Vincenzo Mazzotta. The restaurant features alfresco dining with spectacular views of the city skyline.

Situated in the quiet suburb of Pendle Hill, Piazzetta Bella serves authentic Italian dishes from a comprehensive menu. The restaurant also features a large selection of wines and an impressive Tuscan-style courtyard for alfresco dining.

Bondi Junction's Oxford St Mall has just had a multi-million dollar make-over and now plays host to a range of markets. Head down on Thursdays and Saturdays for the Farmers Market, swing by Friday for the Artisans Market and then come back Friday night for the Global Food Village.
Da Calvino is a cosy new restaurant in Mosman. Chef Kelvin Foster serves Modern Italian fare, from private dining to catering for functions. Licensed and BYO wine only.
On the corner of Ramsay and Dalhousie streets in Haberfield's "Little Italy" you'll find wood-fired pizza, fresh salads, panini and pasta. For dessert try one of the 46 flavors of house-made gelati.

Nestled in a protected area on the northern point of Palm Beach, husband and wife team Stefan Leibe and Cathie Wright have created the ultimate Palm Beach dining experience. The restaurant is warm and inviting with a simple yet stylish sandstone and teak interior, leaving the views to do the talking. The extensive menu utilizes the freshest produce, with an emphasis on local seafood such as pan-fried snapper, served with with potato gnocchi, brocolini and a rocket and lime dressing. With professional and friendly service, the restaurant is popular with locals as it is with Sydney-siders.
content.openingtimes: Breakfast Tue-Sun 8.30am-11.30am; Lunch Tue-Sun 11.30am-4pm; Dinner Wed-Sat 6.30pm-10pm

content.description: A beautiful modern space with open kitchen and courtyard dining. The food is refreshingly simple, Head chef Daniele Giannuzzi's dishes are marked by clean, distinct flavours. The floor staff are confident and informative.
Elysium, 'heaven' in latin is a little gem on the Avoca St strip of Randwick. The elegant restaurant serves Modern Australian fare, with a French-Italian influence.

If you're looking for a great cafe for a lazy Sunday breakfast and people watch in the lively Lane Cove Cove plaza, Epitome is the place to go. And be sure to try the homemade hash browns and Flapjacks. Also open for dinner, with a menu featuring mouth-watering steaks, seafood and pasta. Set over two levels, the friendly staff can accommodate large groups.

entry.name: Christ Church St Laurence Anglican Church

version.name: Christ Church St Laurence Anglican Church

content.description: An Anglican church offering frequent free organ recitals. Situated close to Railway Square.

This 'Providore of Fine Wine' is situated in the historic Reschs Brewery in Redfern. Selling all kinds of wine, from everyday drinkers to rare, vintage finds, they can also help with all of your other liquor needs.
The facilities at this Ryde leisure centre include water slides, spa facilities, a wave machine and numerous swimming pools.
Named after the traditional Chinese tile game, this quirky restaurant serves authentic Chinese food with a menu that excites.
A second-hand bookshop stocking a good range of genres at bargain prices.
Offering full-time, part-time and drop-in acting classes, ACA is one of the most well-known acting schools in Australia and boasts Hugh Jackman as its patron.
Offering a wide variety of beauty treatments, Zen Day Spa is a great place to head if you're after a little pampering.
Offering a range of natural therapies and beauty treatments, the emphasis at this Glebe day spa is on holistic well-being.
This quirky beauty salon devoted to hands and feet is a celeb fave and offers a kooky custom colour selection for fingers and toes.
Get some nail-therapy at this Balmain salon.
The ideal place to soothe those achy feet after a day of trawling the shops on King St - why not bling up those nails all at the same time?

Clean, green Japanese dining is the ethos at this small, minimalist eatery. The menu is gluten-, wheat-, dairy and refined sugar-free as well as organic, and there's even a selection of gluten-free beers on offer. Dedicated greenie and owner Yukako Ichikawa is so keen to reduce waste she'll turn you away if your eyes are bigger than your stomach and offers a 30% discount to all plate-cleaners.

Greek food always gets a bad rap in Sydney. It could be that many people associate it with stodgy moussaka, sticky, wet dolmades and dry baklava. Quite possibly it's because we don't have many great Greek restaurants. Enter Medusa - the Greek restaurant with a lot to give. It's in the heart of the CBD, offering fresh simple food in a casual yet polished room. Owner Peter Koutsopoulos works the room, serving jokes and backslaps along with souvlaki and haloumi. The room's mostly filled with blokes in suits eating lamb and drinking red wine, but it's not just a place for corporate canivores. Start with fava Santorinis – a smooth puree of chickpeas dressed with olive oil and lemon juice. It's not hummus, but it's not far off. And make sure to get the melitzanes – crisp wheels of batter holding tender-yet-firm pieces of eggplant. Kefalotyri saganaki are salty, crumbly fried fingers of goat's milk cheese (perfect with a squeeze of lemon and a little olive oil) while kotopoulo potharakia involves spicy little chicken legs (they call them shanks here) on a bed of grilled fennel. You could probably live without the lamb souvlaki – hunks of lamb skewered and grill served on a bed of chips and salad – but you should really consider the moussaka, which is a creamy, sweet dish of layered beef mince, eggplant and sliced potato covered in béchamel. There's a vego version of this dish, too. Desserts are a highlight. Ever eaten loukoumades? They're basically deep-fried puffs of dough, which are slightly chewy, covered in honey and chopped nuts. Oh, baby. Could this be the best darn Greek food in the city? We think so. Myffy Rigby

Sydney’s fresh produce mecca brings you the cooking class so popular you have to book a month in advance. You usually only learn one recipe but by God it’s always a good one. Classes are held twice daily on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, led by chefs from Café Sopra. The emphasis here is on simple recipes, prepared well using fresh produce. The added bonus is that you can precede a class with a killer lunch upstairs, and visit the downstairs providore afterwards for ingredients to make the dishes at home. Make sure you sign up on Fratelli’s website well in advance to reserve your place.

This all-male cooking school focuses on improving kitchen confidence through education in nutrition, safety, simplicity and efficiency, with specialised one-off classes and extended five week courses.
This imported Japanese grocery vendor, come here for bitter-but-sweet green tea ice cream and other curious treats.
Pop in on your way to the train for one of their classic(al) records.
A versatile creative warehouse space used for individual artists and companies for events, exhibitions and launches.

Essen, previously known as Una's is still creating cheerful home-style cuisine, operating thankfully under the same owner Geert Elzinga and staff. You can find massive schnitzels and Schofferhofer, yet they found a further gourmet edge. Try the delectable pork rib with parmesan polenta and roasted fennel. Followed by the new dessert, Creme de Couer or "Hang-op"- ricotta and egg white and sour cream hung in muslin for 24 hours, then served with a blueberry compote. Open lunch and dinner seven days.

Step upstairs and be welcomed by a menu that is constantly evolving to showcase produce in season. The large open balcony makes the perfect lunch spot to enjoy a selection of fine wines and chef Paul Pereira's stunning dishes.

Bourke Street's original Reschs Brewery building houses this providore of fine wines, offering an eclectic mix of local and imported wines and beers. They also host tasting events of Fridays and Saturdays.

Originally launching in the Tokyo suburb of Yanaka, Tokyo Bike has now spread to Sydney! Focusing on simple, reasonably-priced bicycles in a range of colours, Tokyo bikes are easy to ride and easy to carry weighing between 9 and 11 kilos.

Boasting 30 years of cycling experience, this Paddington shop has a three-storey showroom with hundreds of bikes and accessories on display. They offer a bike home delivery service and also have a bicycle workshop for repairs and maintenance.
Founded in 1975, this family-run business has over 200 models of bike on display and a wide range of accessories. They also offer free bike maintenance courses.

This tiny Vietnamese hot bread shop has a delicious ace up its sleeve. The banh mi - aka Vietnamese pork roll – is excellent. Mayo, pâté, coriander, pickled carrot and various pork luncheon meats all come together in one crunchy white roll for your chewing pleasure.
Estate, jewellery and general merchandise auctioneers.
Fine art, collectibles and antiques. General auctioneers and valuers.
galleryeight is a small gallery in Millers Point hosting changing exhibitions.
La Gerbe D'Or have a short list of deluxe cakes, pastries and breads. The specialty is the marik loaf. Their tarte tatin and taret au citron are tip-top too.

Six months after opening, owner Frederic Caillon had to expand due to overwhelming acclaim. When you taste the Charlotte aux Fruits Rouges (kirsch-soaked sponge cake piled with strawberries), you'll know why.

How many truly great Sydney cafes are there when you boil it down? Not as many as you first might think. Anyone can scramble an egg or put salmon on a bagel, but how many places actaully prize great service, repeat clientele and exceptional coffee over banging out banana pancakes with maple-flavoured syrup? More and more venues around town are adopting a less-is-more attitude: serve a few things, do them well, and everybody's happy. Especially Black Star Pastry's Chris Thé, who now supplies baked goods to some of Sydney's coolest venues including the Little Marionette, Shady Pines, not to mention Remy and Lee's - the little café on everyone's lips.Ever been to Aquadisiac, that amazing aquarium store that sells outrageously expensive exotic fish (it's like going to the zoo for free in Surry Hills)? Remy and Lee's is across the road. The display cabinets are still in place from the retail store that was in the space before the café. They hold a mash-up of stuff: stone buddhas, bicycle parts, a massive pile of coffee keep cups and Black Star ginger ninjas (like a gingerbread man, only deadlier) under a glass cloche. A communal table takes up most of the middle of the room, and there aren't any menus, just a wall painted orange listing pastries, pies and toast du jour. We could talk about the amazing sweet treats (including a pear frangipane tart and a persimmon turnover) and go on about the outrageously good lamb shank pie, but there's no point, really - not when you can just go there and eat them yourself. Anyway, Remy and Lee's isn't about how good the Black Star pastries are, it's about personable service, excellently made coffee and a great vibe. Got a spare $890? You could buy the very attractive bike in the front window - a reconditioned metallic green lady's cruiser. A little too rich for your blood? They sell bike seats seperately - you could work your way up one piece at a time. Myffy Rigby

A dedicated fromagerie in each Jones the Grocer store means there's no excuse to not have cheese in your life. Not sure how to choose? There's a team of experts on hand to walk you through it. Try a cheese platter in the cafe before you buy or take the plunge and go fromage crazy.

77 is set in a beautiful historic sandstone building, with a large courtyard. Serving classic and contemporary Italian, the menu includes home made gluten free pizza, pasta and a selection of vegetarian options.
Ginger Indian Restaurant serves authentic North Indian mughalai fare and interesting variations. With friendly, attentive service and seating for up to 100 guests.
An Italian restaurant that serves authentic, home-style meals and pizza. Set at the Rocks end of the CBD, this is a handy restaurant for weekday lunches and well-priced evening meals.
Harry's Fish Cafe offers you a choice between ten types of fresh fish everyday. A great selection of well priced wines are available and great views of sparkling Middle Harbour.

A mind-boggling number of gelato flavours are on display- made fresh on the premises with ingredients from Australia and Italy. That's not all- crunchy baguettes and sizzling plates of pasta and bubbly pizza are sure to tempt.

Frank and Gabriella Angilletta have taken the old Blues Point Cafe and have transformed it into an Italian eatery, offering the same award-winning cuisine as their sister venture Il Locale in Haberfield.

Oh Melbourne. You and your middle-tier restaurant excellence. Sure, we've got the flash, big-night-out thing covered, but it's the restaurant in the middle – the cool place where you can have a meal any day without spending a million bucks and still eat amazing food – that seems so easy for you and so hard for us. At least till now. We're clawing our way up the ranks with the likes of Bloodwood, Fratellis Paradiso and Fresh, Bodega and Vini. And now here's Berta, the new restaurant from Vini owner and chef Andrew Cibej – a concrete bunker on Alberta Street filled with Italian wine, share plates of Italian food and a room buzzing with people having a good time. And while Berta is distinctly un-Vini-like on the plate, there's a very similar aesthetic at work. The food and wine menus written on big chalkboards, the dark palette, the dim lights and the lively atmosphere. Oh, and the whole no-bookings thing. The menu is broken into fairly share-worthy propositions – while you could easily construct a meal for one, the food is far better translated as an Italian-style feast. Try the likes of cuttlefish and zucchini – fingers of tender cuttlefish enriched with extra squid ink very, very gently pan fried accompanied by rounds of zucchini. They're all dressed in olive oil and brightened with preserved lemon. The result is inky, viscous and fresh. Fried cauliflower and chickpeas may sound like a healthy salad but it's more like a bar snack. Here, both ingredients are deep fried with leaves of crisp rosemary – perfect with a beer. A lighter hand with the rosemary would be no bad thing. Make sure to order the radicchio, pan fried with sugna – pronounce it 'soonya' – little nibs of rendered, whipped pork fat with fennel seed. These bitter greens are sweetened up with caramelised red wine vinegar topped with toasted breadcrumbs. Break it up with a broth of oxtail and bits of oxtail meat interspersed with little knots of tortellini filled with wild greens that pop in your mouth with chlorophylly badassitude. If you're a diehard prawn fan, order away but for us, whole prawns with nothing but chilli oil and capers to keep them company doesn't pop as a dish the way everything else does. Instead go for the big ol' plate of mixed suckling pig bits (leg, loin, belly, wiggly little tail) with crisp, scorched golden skin. And order a side of braised green lentils with leeks and chicory – perfetto. Or slices of pan fried lamb rump with white bean mash and salsa verde and maybe a salad of watercress with thin fans of raw fennel. O Tama Carey is behind all these tasty snacks. For the last little while she's been cooking at Vini and before that Billy Kwong but you wouldn't necessarily pick that from the food here. While we're on the subject of people-who-make-Berta-awesome, there's Kristen Allen on the floor. She's from Vini too, and knows more than a thing or two about booze. A good thing, considering Berta's exciting all-Italian wine list and very impressive range of grappa. For dessert, buffalo milk and bay leaf sorbet makes a great palate cleanser or go for a real winter warmer like the tart covered with a waterfall of crème patisserie topped with a tongue of lewdly crimson quince and a little nest of caramelised sage leaves. There's also the baked chestnut custard – a bit of a table divider – with mandarin. There's a real mealiness to it that Carey describes as a feeling rather than a texture. Order it and see for yourself. Sydney doesn't need any more fine dining restaurants. Want views and starched waiters and triple sieved sauces? This town's got 'em in spades. What we need more of is Berta.

Sicilian restaurants are pretty few and far between in Sydney, which makes this one even more of a find. Head chef Paolo Patane serves up authentic dishes infused with the diverse flavours of southern Italy.
IN restaurant has been serving up Modern Australian cuisine in Neutral Bay for over 10 years.
Offering Italian and seafood on the menu at reasonable prices in casual surrounds, Isabella's in Randwick offers BYO and a home delivery service.
With a traditional atmosphere, this Italian restaurant serves up authentic pizza and pasta dishes along with a selection of desserts.
A studio that opens its doors once a month for one-night only hybrid art events such as experimental music and theatre performances, film screenings and poetry reading.
A creative and inspiring warehouse venue, that can accommodate large-scale group exhibitions.
Specialising in South Indian food, this simple Newtown stalwart is known for its Dosai and Hoppers but also serves a selection of Indonesian dishes.
Specialising in South Indian food, this Neutral Bay branch of the Kammadhenu chain is known for its Dosai and Hoppers but also serves a selection of Indonesian dishes.
Conveniently situated within the CBD, Karma creates authentic Indian food using fresh, seasonal Australian produce. Open for lunch and dinner.
Serving authentic Indian dishes with an innovative twist, Kashi restaurant in Annangrove builds on the success of its sister restaurant - Tribeni in Blacktown.
A new multi-disciplinary arts initiative. Fraserstudios support artists by providing sites for residencies, studio and performance spaces.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 7.30am-10pm; Sat, Sun and public holidays 9am-9pm.

content.description: Serving authentic and adventurous Thai dishes such as soft shell crab green curry, this restaurant is a favourite with the local office community.
An event space for weird and wonderful time-based and performance work by emerging artists.

Bill and George is comprised of 12 individual multi disciplinary artist studio aimed to encourage and support experimental and hybrid practice through its program of activities. The complex also hosts a rehearsal/dance floor and screening room.

Disappointed by Spice I Am's Victoria Street Branch? Love the original on Wentworth Street but can never get in? We hears ya. But never mind those bollocks, because here comes House. If you're among the some who like it hot, it's the restaurant you'll want to run, nay, sprint to right now.
It's the same team from Spice I Am, doing not the tricked-up top-dollar stuff that Darlinghurst is known for, but the street food of northeast Thailand. You won't find a lot of coconut milk or stir-fries on the Isaan-leaning menu but there are a lot of salads, grills and fermented and dried and sour gear. It's fitting that Sydney's hottest new Thai restaurant also does the hottest salad we've eaten in Sydney. A bit like a som tum, tum zua sees shreds of green papaya mixed up with fermented kanom jeen rice noodles, cherry tomato halves, green beans and Thai eggplant dressed in piquant lime, garlic and preserved fish. It's thermonuclear with tiny bird's eye chillies, the seeds coating the noodles. Forget rice, milk or water, the only thing that's gonna get you through this burn is some serious stones.
The restaurant lives in the space adjoining the Triple Ace Bar. What was once an unremarkable red-sauce joint is now a massive courtyard strung with lanterns, promising happy, beery times when the hot weather returns. The sturdy wooden tables should be big enough to fit around six hungry farangs or eight slender Thais on each. Framed Thai movie posters (our favourite is The Overture: ‘He Fights Through His Music') line one slatted white wall, and while you might complain about the noise of traffic and trains rumbling along Elizabeth Street on the other side of the fence, old Bangkok hands reckon it's pretty authentic.
Speaking of authentic, larb ped is a slightly less violent way of experiencing an Isaan specialty. Roughly minced duck is fried with ground roast rice - a crunchy meaty, tangy mess. The salad is finished with little deep fried duck bits, green onions, deep fried shallots and a whole lotta chilli. It's brought to the table with a glass filled with cucumber sticks, cabbage leaves and holy basil. The idea is to take a bite of cucumber or cabbage to assuage the heat, and you can try wrapping bits of duck salad in the basil leaves. Yum. It doesn't all have to be so fiery, of course. Order the chicken with coconut and banana blossom steamed in a banana leaf; delicate and fragrant, it's a far cry from the rich, sour pungency of some of the other dishes.
It's also great to see Sujet Saenkhan shaking the pans in the bright open kitchen. A co-owner, Saenkhan is Spice I Am's original chef, and things on the plate sparkle that much more brightly when he's in the house. It's a good looking and stylish group Saenkhan has working the place: everybody on the pass is resplendent in their bright orange neckerchiefs, and the incredibly nice floor staff are in denim and white tees emblazoned with fluoro pink.
Our plan of attack involves settling in with some beers (the drinks - and the toilets - are courtesy of the pub); there's no Singha at the Aces but they have Tiger, Kirin and Tsingtao, and there's always Pale on tap. The grills section of the menu has "bar snacks" written all over it. We can speak for the likes of juicy, sweet pork skewers (moo ping) and the sun-dried-then-deep-fried beef strips (nua daed deaw - a little like eating very soft jerky). What we want is to go back for the gai yang - marinated charcoal chicken. With any luck it'll have that same tender juiciness that's a rarity in most other local Isaan kitchens.
Neither of the desserts we have are on the menu. There's the chocolate pudding, baked in a little cup and topped with a scoop of coconut ice cream and there's the dessert they dub the BTS - Better Than Sex. It's basically a thick slice of fried bread covered in sugar and caramel and covered with a big scoop of coconut ice cream. It's certainly better than bad sex.
We're not sure if Berta, Sydney's other hottest new opening, is going to be getting the overflow from House or vice versa but we can tell you it's essential eating either way. Get into it. Myffy Rigby
This space is open to local, national and international solo artists- focusing on nonobjective art making.
SNO features three gallery rooms and a sound/video project facility. There is also a studio that can be applied for every three months.
Modern pan-Asian cuisine from the owners of Woolloomooloo's China Doll restaurant.

Mauro Marcucci (of Crown Street's Pizza e Birra and Mille Vini fame) brings his signature mod-Italian fare to the north shore. With a menu that appears as delicious as it is lengthy, this classy trattoria may just be the Italian stallion you are looking for.
Patchwork aficionados will find a range of fabrics, with special reproduction and vintage prints on sale. Regular quilt-making workshops are held at the shop starting from $65 for a one-off session.
Fabrics and soft furnishings sourced from leading local and overseas suppliers like Designers Guild. Workshops start from $75, including classes on creating tea cosies, oven mitts and cushion covers.
Fabrics and soft furnishings sourced from leading local and overseas suppliers like Designers Guild. Workshops start from $75, including classes on creating tea cosies, oven mitts and cushion covers.
Formerly an illegal casino and adult bookshop, this intimate wine bar and dining room runs just off Kings Cross' main drag, serving up Mod Oz and Asian-inspired dishes and cocktails.

Once known as Frog Hollow and later White Gum Flat, Rockdale has evolved into a buzzy little network of great restaurants, cafés and street food from all four corners of the globe. Bar Fresko is typical of the suburb’s versatility. Sunny in aspect and disposition, it’s as much milk bar as café but its all-day breakfast and ground-to-order coffee is legend in these parts. Nutty brews with soft gold cremas fly out the door alongside souvlakis, old-school sandwiches and fresh salads – perfect for Saturday morning grazes and late-arvo heartstarters.

The BSB juggernaut rolls on – outlets here, in Surry Hills and Marrickville, a cookbook on shelves and lines of slavering fans queuing out the door for specialty spelt sourdough and magnificent mellow coffee. There’s little better than snagging a couple of pork-and-fennel or lamb-and-harissa sausage rolls, a loaf of sourdough, maybe some of their chorizo and thyme-studded hot bread, and a tray of assorted sweetcakes (we love the sugar scrolls, the pain au chocolat and the teeny ginger brulee tarts).

Don’t let the pram-jam out front dissuade you from entering the gorgeous fug of fresh baked bread and ground coffee aromas emanating from this family-run café in Cloey’s cutest cluster of shops. Coffees come potently nuanced at Clodeli: doppios displaying all the soft, earthy notes and nutty burrs that are the hallmarks of great beans and A-grade baristas. Tables spill out onto the footpath to sustain the gaggles of families and the daily kiddygridlock while inside there’s a cabinet of primo meats and cheeses in a counter crying out to be eaten on premises or whisked down the hill to Gordons Bay or the Clovelly clifftops.

This beautiful old-school café is home to equally beautiful coffee. As if the sunny al fresco tables and all-morning rush hour weren’t comfort enough, the Danes coffee roaster is on premises and reassuringly thrumming in the background. The coffee itself comes with big bass notes, rich crema and latte art that hints at the flair behind the counter (the Danes Home Barista Champs run from 25 July). Want more? One of the baristas has a tattoo of a portafilter on his forearm! Now that’s dedication...

Bean fiends beware! No one leaves Di Bartoli empty handed. You’ll either walk out with a pep in your step (thanks to their complex and more-ish house blend), a new espresso machine tucked under your arm (this is Australia’s only “Home Barista Centre”) or a latte art certificate to hang on your wall (classes are run by Scott Callaghan, Australian Barista Champion 2007 and World Latte Art Champion 2006). You could cut the coffee aroma here with a knife so breathe in, order up, drink deep and dream on.
Euroluce's new Surry Hills-based studio showcases installations and designer collections.

Provincial delights abound here, pre-eminent among them the famous Bertoni house brand Arabica blend of four beans, which hits the palate in classic southern Italian style: strong, sexy and supercharged with gratis housemade biscotti on the side. Weekend hordes scramble for communal tables and milk crates, with most hankering after a fat slab of Mamma Maria’s lasagne – a 150-year-old secret family recipe encasing sweet meats and a variety of molten cheeses between luscious sheets of housemade pasta.

Architect and gastronome Davide Salmeri has created a hot slice of Italy with this café that has dedicated itself to masterful coffee and modern-Italian cuisine. Set on the corner of Putney’s busy village square, the room crackles with homestyle sweets, beautiful biscotti and the bellow of Italian tenors (often with the ever-smiling staff in chorus). The smell of the herbaceous Dolcini blend made by Illy is omnipresent and riding its thermals are some menu highlights worth writing home about, pre-eminent among them the aoli-soaked garlic prawn Ceasar salad served on piadina – incredible!

The lovely, wondrous whiffs of fresh-baked bread greet you at the door and, on entry, give way to musty gusts of lovely earthy coffee. The vibe is French all the way (café owner Dominique hails from Mauritius) with checked cloth under the bread baskets and a menu to match. It’s a hole-inthe- wall but the half-dozen tables for two are always full of folks munching fruit loaf, puffed croissants and beautifully filled baguettes collected from the best bakeries in Sydney.

There’s no food, no tea, no hot chocolate and no skim milk. This cutting-edge cafe is coffee all the way – they roast on demand, hold free cupping sessions and specialise in single estate beans. The alchemists behind this shop-front espresso operation are Coffee Alchemy, helmed by roaster Hazel de los Reyes, the 2007 Aussie Cupping Champ, a girl on a mission to make Aasca Demitasse, Kenyan Gethumbwini and Yirgacheffe part of Sydney’s coffee vocab via a La Marzocco Linea dripping with some of the most gorgeous espresso shots in Sydney.

This café is famous for serving monkey parchment coffee – beans chewed and spat out by rhesus apes at Merthi Mountain in India ($9 a plunger here). Owner Rob Forsyth has been at the vanguard of Sydney coffee for 25 years as a barista coach, master roaster and international judge – hell, his café (now with a new DIY coffee bar) even has a bean plantation out front! Ask nicely if you want Kopi Luwak – coffee beans eaten and excreted by the wild Asian civet cats. This one-off “crapuccino” is in short supply at $120 per 100 grams!

Mall cafes don’t often make the cut with Sydney’s coffee snobs but Kafenion turns that convention on its head. This cosy family café cranks out great coffee from a lovingly-tended little corner of a loud Shire megaplex and dishes delicious food to boot. In Kafenio’s cute little nook, brother Brendan does the books, mum Tass busses the tables and the salsa music sashays in time with owner Jason Bailey’s swashbuckling work behind the espresso machine. Di Lorenzo beans come creamy and rich (shots served in the traditional piccolo glasses) and the blend marries perfectly with their big brekkies and a spicy sour lentil soup we’ll be back for.

This café/music venue/bohemian hang is, according to its owners, “where thinkers drink”. And based on our forays to Mars Hill, they’re not far wrong. Both brainiacs and beaniacs will find themselves equally smitten. Although the menu doesn’t reach beyond the basics, a rolling cavalcade of entertainment ranging from blues fusion groups, art exhibits and book clubs more than compensates. All of it shares equal billing with a great coffee blend claiming Brazilian, Nicaraguan, Guatemalan and Indian passport stamps.

Despite being upwind from the Sydney Police Centre’s menace-plex, this cute café is bohemian to its Cuban boot-heels. Bordello red walls and street stools on the slope guarantee an off-kilter clientele and the café’s dangerously cool proximity to fashionistas Wheels & Doll Baby and Time Out small bar favourite Café Lounge make it about as snugly, smugly Surry Hills as is possible. Crown Street is a caffeine hot-spot where the mediocre die fast so although Pablo’s ownership seems interchangeable and there’s no phone, the coffee is so good the vice squad neighbours can’t be far away.

Small but perfectly formed, this café is tucked away on the steeply-sloping Dudley Street but works all angles to advantage courtesy of a robustly French menu filled with luscious croissants and fresh baguettes plus a house specialty nutella crepe with so much va-va-voom it’s near criminal. Although the café is so far open for dinner on Friday nights only, Petit’s owner Rafael has plans for extended hours in summer. For now, cheeky cheese fondues, cured meat platters and strong coffee will have to suffice.

Coolest café in the Cross by far, Piccolo was a den of iniquity long before The Golden Mile was paved. Founded by Englishman Bill Vader in the 40s, overrun by jazz cats in the 50s and lovingly desecrated by everyone from Jeff Buckley to Liv Ullman to Brett Whiteley in the decades since. Piccolo is today the baby of barista Vittorio Bianchi and he marshals the jukebox, coffee machine, kitchen and film-crews that visit with an iron fist, old-school courtesies and a sly nod and a wink to his ever-colourful but fiercely loyal Kings Cross clientele.

North Sydney is a nexus for coffee on the hop but Voodoo maintains a neat balance between corporate caffeine and cuddlier single origin cuppas, be it at this flagship café or their nearby Blue Street operation. The voodoo that they do, they do well (and no chickens are sacrificed in its alchemy). But perhaps a truer test of their coffee-making mettle is that their coffee still stands up at the coffee carts they’ve smartly strewn across Pitt, York and George Street in the city. The Voodoo bean comes from their roaster in Chippendale as Premium or Serenata and both are bittersweet but buttery on impact.
This store aims to provide a personalised and pampering boudoir experience as customers peruse the collection of cutting edge fashion handpicked by Eva Galambos.
Break your marital sex drought by swinging with other bored-to-death couples. This is a safe environment where you can live out your fantasies as a unit.
Fashionable street-wear for men and women.
Buy restored classic Vespa scooters with all the bells and whistles.
Satisfy your sweet tooth at one of Australia's oldest cake shops.
European and American designer clothing and accessories from men and women.

The powers behind the world-renowned Montreux Jazz Festival - easily one of the most popular music fests anywhere - have joined forces with the food and beverage company SSP to open the very first Montreux Jazz Café outside of Switzerland, right here in Sydney.The eatery is located amid the currency exchanges and souvenir shops of Sydney Airport's international departure level, before you hit your first security check. Frequent-flying jazz fans can enjoy footage from past fests on multiple monitors in the cafe, while surrounded by larger-than-life floor-to-ceiling images of Marvin Gaye, Yuksek, Macy Gray and others."The Australian market is a very big market for the festival," says Heinz Egli, Asia Pacific operations director for SSP. "It is a jazz-loving place. It made sense to open the first location in such a city."The café boasts an extensive breakfast, lunch and dinner menu if you're looking for a meal with your Miles or Monk, as well as a full bar. Egli says that once things get rolling they hope to feature regular weekend performances from local and national touring acts that are passing through."This definitely has a different atmosphere than any other airport restaurant," Egli says. "If you don't like jazz, you are in the wrong place." Gerald M. Gay
Offering a selection of French fashion, accessories, jewellery and fragrances, Paris Mode aims to bring a touch of Parisian chic to Australia.

address.street: Cnr of Carr and Byron St
Cnr of Carr and Byron St

content.description: Located just off the busy strip of Coogee, the recently renovated Coogee Diggers RSL offers three bar areas, pub grub and regular live entertainment.

The great thing about the way Sydney is evolving is that we have choice in the small bars we choose to patronise. You've got your American-style dive bars such as Shady Pines and the Flinders; your small wine bars such as Time to Vino; speakeasy-style cocktail bars such as Eau de Vie; and then there's the likes of the Passage. This recent addition to Victoria Street has adopted a more Sydney approach in their look: slick surfaces, metal, mirrors. In a way, we're looking at our first quintessential Sydney small bar - somewhere that hasn't ripped a page straight from the book of Melbourne-style bars.
The Passage is the brainchild of bartenders Edward Loveday, Andrew Emerson and Mark Eggers. AS you might expect from the name, the Passage is a long, skinny room. It's dimly lit and lined with banquettes and the bar, right down the back of the room, is moderately stocked with nice liquor. Try the Scofflaw, an old prohibition favourite: rye, grenadine, vermouth, lemon juice and bitters. Or go super-fresh with the Passage's variation on a classic Collins with mandarin instead of lemon juice.
They're very new and clearly still bedding in so we're prepared to cut them some slack. But note to the bartenders: if your bar is pretty much empty and your one table wants to run a tab, let them. Don't make them uncomfortable because your computer system isn't up and running; write what they had to drink on a piece of paper. Make them feel welcome.
Given that the Passage has an excitingly late licence (they close up shop at 3am), it may be worth your while to head here after dinner, rather than before, as we did. Once the DJ gets going, maybe the bar does, too. Myffy Rigby

The Indonesian favourite ayam goreng, or fried chicken, is lifted to new levels of crunch at ATL Marantha.
Where? A family-run Indonesian restaurant on a quiet suburban street corner in Kensington.
What's it like? Laid-back self-service is the order of the day here. It's DIY everything, including writing your own order on the supplied waiter's pad. Help yourself to cutlery or just roll up your sleeves and dig in.
What should I order? Ayam goreng tulang lunak ($8) is fried chicken with soft bones you can eat. Why worry about extricating meat from bones when you can just eat an entire chicken leg itself, bones and all? The secret lies in pressure-cooking the corn-fed chicken quarters overnight ready for deep frying the next day. The result? Earth-shattering batter, juicy flesh and brittle bones you can crunch on, from the ribs to the leg bone. The bones don't taste of much – as bland as the bones you find in a tin of salmon – but there's a sense of accomplishment involved in reducing a serve of chicken legs into nothing but a trail of stray crumbs.
How do you eat it? The fried chicken can be ordered with a salted egg batter or generous daubs of chilli sauce in hot or mild, but we liked the original the best, which is topped with a crumbling coral of deep-fried batter shards. Duck ($10) is also available grilled or deep fried. All of them have bones you can crunch on.
What else? Try the petai beans - their bitterness is best masked with fried anchovy ($12), but they're also available with prawns ($17) or served plain ($6.50). Cleanse the palate with sayur asem ($5), a sour tamarind soup and wash down everything with sweetened coconut milk drinks that double as desserts. Avocado ice ($5) and durian ice ($6) both come with chunks of fruit at the bottom. Helen Yee
A student performance space on the University of New South Wales campus.
This swanky CBD strip joint serves up nude entertainment to tickle the fancy of both gents and ladies along with dishes and cocktails to tickle their taste buds.
This is the TAFE NSW – Sydney Institute college for design excellence.
This homeless shelter features in the work of the Milk Crate Theatre Company.
Splinter Workshop is the home of a unique collective of designers working in anything from glass to metal.
Open only for special architecture tours and events.
Contemporary jewellery and objects design studio and gallery.
Boutique vendor of natural fabrics and textiles including hemp, organic cotton and linen.

For a city as obsessed with food as Sydney is, it's surprising how few good hole-in-the-wall joints we actually boast. Albee's is a welcome addition to the small Malaysian food scene where dishes cooked with a nod to authenticity are prized above location and water views.There are specials written in Chinese with obscure translations such as the mystifying 'Rice Drops Serve in Hot Pot'. There are brusque staff who may or may not greet you with a bowl of complimentary broth (if none is forthcoming a gentle reminder should produce results). There are smoking woks, a few old aunties and boxes and boxes of produce. There's also a fridge full of cold, sweet herbal tea (only $1 a glass) and if you ask nicely on your way out they'll sell you a jug of it to take home. The menu is short and sharp, with set meals that seem very popular with the predominantly Asian crowd. The nasi lemak pops with flavour. It's a plate of coconut rice, beef rendang, oily onion sambal, flash-fried ikan bilis and peanuts balanced with five (count them) thin slices of cucumber. You might expect it to be a greasy mess but you'd be mistaken: the mix of flavour and texture is like a well balanced punch to the mouth. Char kuey teow is a smoky jumble of flat rice noodles, bits of Chinese sausage, crunchy prawns and softly scrambled egg, all bound by a touch of chilli and a good glug of ketchup manis. Albee's char kuey teow substitutes pippies for those hard-to-get blood cockles. It's not the real deal, but full points for trying. Vegetarians don't miss out either. Stir-fried kangkong (water spinach) is a pungent, funky treat, and the imaginatively named Four Treasure Vegetable (green beans, okra, eggplant and petai beans) flavoured with chilli sambal is a jackpot of heat and freshness. The food's fantastic and the prices are wallet-friendly. Check it out soon. Wilson Chung

There's plenty to like at Boteco, the new Brazilian bar on Cleveland Street: namely a massive cocktail list, plenty of things to snack on and friendly service. The list is exciting with the signature drinks of every South American country including whole pages on pisco, rum, tequila and cachaca. Want a Pisco Sour? Easy. Fernet and Coke? It's right there on the list. But you'll want to take a book while you wait. Maybe we just went on a bad night, but we're talking waits of half an hour for a round of drinks. On the second round, some drinks don't appear at all and after asking three times over the course of another 45 minutes, the wrong drink arrives at the table. It's a shame, because the idea behind the whole operation is cool. Brazilian style snacks + a casual room + great drinks = fun times. Unlike the bar, the kitchen are really on it. The food comes out in fine time and we'd order more and stay longer if the drinks did the same. The snacks (petiscos), while not cheap, are pretty damn good. Love the pastels - kind of a mix between a chip and an empanada, a pastel is a feather-light shell of puffy pastry filled with your choice of cheese or minced salt-cured beef. Get both. Grilled beef with chunky cassava chips is fine but would you pay $23.90 for what is ostensibly a bar snack? Nah. You might have it for dinner, though.All the essentials are there at Boteco. It's just a matter of the guys joining the dots. Myffy Rigby

Neutral Bay, gentle readers, is where it's at right now. American diner Blue Plate Bar and Grill opened recently; there's word of a new Luke Mangan joint opening up; the guys from Glebe Point Diner have set their sights to Military Road with Neutral Bay Bar and Dining; and there's Garden Brasserie. The bar itself is pretty cool. A four-metre vertical garden is a verdant centrepiece in the downstairs restaurant, which offers modern updates on bistro favourites. And the cocktail list, at first glance, looks promising and thoughtfully put together. There are plenty of takes on the classics including Garden Brasserie's version of an Aviation - Aviation gin, maraschino, crème de violette, lemon and mandarin juice - which is fine except for the mandarin juice which dilutes the drink, making it lose all its citrusy edge and giving a fairly flaccid result.
