An Ashen Bobby Burns - Ardbeg scotch whisky, the bar's house made vermouth and bitters and a flamed spray of La Fee absinthe - lacks personality. It's missing that unctuous richness you get with a really good whisky cocktail. It's a pity the drinks list isn't as well executed as well as it might be. There are a lot of cocktails available and the guys behind the bar might do well to concentrate on basic bartending rather than making fairy floss and lollypops. Why? All the smoke and mirrors leads to watery drinks – a result of too much time spent sitting in the shaker with melting ice as bartenders fuss with garnishes. Still, the straight spirits section is pretty impressive. It's easy to imagine how full this bar may get on a Friday night. With the exception of Firefly a few doors down, dedicated bars are few and far between in this hood. But honestly, we'd rather go next door to Blue Plate and drink a Mint Julep. Myffy Rigby

Mamasan is a small yum cha and pan-Asian tapas restaurant opposite the Beach Road Hotel and very popular with locals. Ice cold Asahi is on tap and dishes including salt & pepper squid,steamed dumplings and bbq pork buns.

Phillip Searle and his partner Barry Ross run the best restaurant in the Blue Mountains. So what makes Vulcans the restaurant you should hop in your car or brave the country train and travel two hours out of Sydney to visit? It's the skill, the finesse and the care that goes into the food. Vulcans is BYO only, so you'll want to organise yourself before you leave for the Mountains and take it from us – it's no bad thing to overcater (we always like to pop an eighth of whisky in our coat pockets for the train ride home. But you didn't hear that from us). A pioneer of food in the 80s and 90s, Searle taught and influenced many of Sydney's top chefs, such as Universal's Christine Manfield and the Bentley's Brent Savage.Before it was a restaurant, Vulcans was the Blackheath Bakery - which went from finger buns to fancy sourdough. The old bakery oven has remained, however, and many of the dishes that come out of the kitchen are made in it, such as the special of aromatic, soft and yielding roast duck breast, spiced with star anise and pepper, steamed slowly in the oven then crisped up in the pan for service. It's served on the bone with a side of spicy smashed potatoes, a scant scattering of coriander leaf and a tiny curl of green onion. Glazed duckling sausage sees rounds of this super-tender sausage piled over slices of roast beetroot and the finest chiffonnade of mint. The Searle also does some of the best vego food in the land. Though the offering changes from year to year, there's often a similar through-line. There's usually some sort of lentil/chickpea number and there's always a veggie main. At the moment it's a rotolo of spiced pumpkin, goat's milk ricotta and lentils. For dessert, there's the classic chequerboard ice cream - alternating squares of pineapple sorbet and vanilla ice cream bordered with liquorice. The upside down caramelised pear cake is essential - a moist, yet rough, irregular cake batter of hazelnut and almond meal covered in sticky roast pears and roast pear syrup. Myffy Rigby
Monique Maul and Anthony Milroy's tiny little cottage restaurant on the Bells Line of Road is reason alone to take the scenic route.
Orange lost Selkirks and gained Racine - a French-leaning locavore restaurant (that is, focussing on local ingredients).
content.openingtimes: Lunch Sat-Sun (Mon Public Hols) from 12 noon; Dinner Thu-Sat (Sun Public Hols) from 6pm; Cellar Door Wed-Sun 10am-4pm; Racine Cafe: Thu-Fri 10am-3pm

content.description: This coastal retreat offers produce-driven Italian fare by chef Stefano Manfredi.

Located in a majestic heritage building constructed by convicts more than 150 years ago, The Coachmen captures the luxury and splendour of both Imperial Russia and the colonial Australia. The Coachmen offers live music, cabaret shows, Russian, traditional and continental cuisine from a la-carte or set menus, vodka tasting and Russian cocktails.
Reverse Garbage has expanded to a second location at the former T2 nightclub site.
All Australian-made products and designs inspired by eco-friendly principles and contemporary aesthetics.
Homewares, designer babywear and unique jewellery and gifts.
Luxurious homewares, furniture, gifts and fashion by international modern designers. Take a break in the on-site cafe, open Monday-Friday 8am-4pm.
Viscopy art management group's resident exhibition space.

Tucked behind the south of Manly Beach, Cabbage Tree Bay is a charming north facing spot, home to rocky outcrop, snorkeling grounds and waterside restaurants.
Two gems are nestled in the bay; Shelly beach and the Fairy Bower pool, a tiny triangular enclosure which is marked by two welcoming, effeminate sculptures.

Paradise beach is one of northern Sydney's small treasures. Set in front of the Clareville reserve, it is a haven for those who want to relax in quiet tranquility and soak in the myriad beauty of the Pittwater expanse. There is a pool enclosure at the beach and the area is perfect for swimming, fishing and watersports. Close by along the foreshore, one can access Taylors Point Baths, another idyllic swimming enclosure off Hudson Pde at the southern end of the reserve. The grassy area behind the baths here is the archetypal picnic spot.

For optimal outdoor swimming pleasure this aquatic centre is picturesque, ideally located on the harbour in Cabarita Park.
The pool is heated and suitable for the whole family with a 50 metre lap pool, a 1 metre deep programme pool for children and, of course, even the youngest visitors can have a play in the shaded toddler pool and accompanying playing equipment area.
The centre is open on a seasonal basis from 1st September through to 30th April and closing times vary during Daylight Savings.

In hand with $9 beer jugs, standard Aussie pub food is served at this modest, but honest local hangout. Trivia night is held every Tuesday at 7.30pm with the chance to score a $70 bar tab.
The Erko brings the traditional country pub feel to it's city context.

Another small local characterises this watering hole in Annandale. Equipped with beer, a pool table, forgettable pub grub and an outdoor courtyard, drop by and get cosy while the TVs blare the latest match....and why not join the Annandale residents for Wednesday trivia nights, 8pm start.
Indie wine vendors with a local rep for a solid range of premium and boutique champagnes.

This Erskineville favourite is flocked to by locals of the area, and is hidden from the King Street hype for a casual pub lovin' session. The Rose of Australia brings you an authentic, colonial pub with all the classifying features; tap beer, food and the old rubbing shoulders with the neighbours vibe. 8pm on Thursday nights hails the running for a $50 bar tab at trivia night.
Independent wine vendors who focus on getting bang for your buck for boutique finds.

In the heart of Norton Street lies a pub, cocktail bar and pool room in the shape of The Royal Hotel. Monday hosts a night of Texas Hold 'Em, Wednesday thinking caps need to be switched on for a 7:30pm commencement of trivia night and Friday and Saturday then serenade the week out with none else than Karaoke at 9pm. Week sorted.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat till late; Sun till midnight

content.description:
Having recently undergone a slick refurbishment, this Alexandria drinking den offers a Modern Australian bistro and is very encouraging of the wine flow. It is a hit amongst Alexandrians, not to mention the significant 'locals only' deals.
The Technology Park Hotel is not short of entertaining it's patrons from 'Trivia Night' to 'Ladies Night' to 'Bogan Bingo' to 'Toss the Boss'.

Conveniently located close to the city centre, Mercure Sydney Hotel is situated in the heart of Sydney's entertainment district with the Capitol Theatre nearby.
Walking distance to the Sydney Convention and Exhibition Centre, Darling Harbour, Chinatown, The Sydney Entertainment Centre and Sydney University. Immediate access to Sydney's major transport hub, Central Railway Square, which is directly linked to Sydney Airport.

Master chocolatiers since 1845, Lindt has become a staple Sydney cafe experience in Winter. The chocolate itself may have Swiss origins but all the cakes, ice-cream and chocolate delights are made in Sydney's south and hit plates fresh, decadent and true to the traditions of founder Rodolphe Lindt.

The Willoughby Hotel is a quaint local pub that has sat in the same Heritage listed building for 110 years.Each day of the week has a unique theme, including Tuesday triva night at 7.30 and Friday night acoustic sessions. Enjoy a brew at the beer garden, a steak at the Bistro or a punt at the TAB.
Angel serves up mod oz fare from their humble heritage-listed abode, with views to nearby Freshwater. plus collections of local artists' work displayed in the restaurant monthly.
content.openingtimes: Lunch 12pm-3pm Thurs-Sun, Dinner 6pm-10pm Thurs-Sat, Brunch 10am-12pm Sat-Sun

content.description: The freshness of market seafood echoes Aquarius' natural parklands locale and riverside location.
A casual diner that specialises in seafood and seasoned family-friendly service.
Casual lunch and dinner dining in downtown Sydney, located inside Chifley Plaza.

From brunch to dinner, Sous Le Soleil serves out of a quaint, old corner cottage in the bushy northern suburb of St. Ives. One can sit outside in the sun or up on the veranda amongst the ambience of other diners, to a menu ranging from calamari to lamb rack. Like it's Roseville sister, this Modern Australian spot is very sweet indeed.

Indulge in parmesan & thyme crusted barramundi and a glass (or make that a bottle) of majella riesling at this Cronulla joint. With a range of tapas options available, the focus here is seafood. South Sydney, we introduce to you Mango Sangria.
Castle Towers Shopping Centre, or known locally as "Towers", is a regional shopping centre in Castle Hill and is one of the largest shopping centres in the southern hemisphere.
This restaurant/cafe serves up Modern Australian fare and is a local favourite on account of the coffee.

address.street: Cote D'azur Building, End of Kingsway
Cote D'azur Building, End of Kingsway

content.description: Serving Italian and Modern Australian food, with amazing views of Cronulla beach and an outdoor terrace dining area.
With an extensive menu of classic Indian dishes, Bijolias prides itself on good customer service and over 25 years of experience.
Conveniently located close to the cinema, pop in to Billows for a bite to eat or a drink before or after your film. Offering breakfast, lunch and dinner, they also have regular wine tastings.
This recently refurbished restaurant offers Modern Australian cuisine fusing the flavours of east and west across the inventive menu.

Balmain's Town Hall Hotel, has been favoured by locals for some 130 years. With over two levels, the Hotel has both spacious open areas and small intimate rooms, as well as a large sundrenched balcony overlooking Darling St. If you're into sports, the Local Bar won't disappoint with it's huge 2.5m screen.
Offering Italian/Modern Australian food in the heart of Cronulla, this swanky restaurant also dishes up the dessert that is its namesake.
Serving Mediterranean-influenced Modern Australian cuisine, this restaurant has an extensive menu. It overlooks the beach and the waters of Botany Bay.
With a menu that changes every two days, Cafe XXII cooks dishes to order using fresh daily produce. A local favourite, booking is highly recommended.

A Manhattan-style restaurant and wine bar in the heart of the Sydney CBD, this slick new joint offers loft-style dining with garden views. Head chef Zac Sykes, formerly of Pier and Fish Face serves up a fresh contemporary menu.
This cosy, family-friendly restaurant in the heart of Chatswood serves up traditional Italian dishes ranging from pizzas to pastas with a good helping of meat and seafood inbetween.
Providing a haven from the bustle of Penshurst St, this little Thai restaurant serves up authentic dishes from a wide selection at reasonable prices.
Serving up Modern Australian cuisine with an emphasis on prime steaks and Australian seafood, this elegant restaurant boasts an extensive wine list.
Feast on traditional Nepalese favourites from takeaway, a la carte and banquet-style menus.
Colourful Iranian artworks line the walls of this local Middle Eastern eatery, where Friday and Saturday nights see exotic belly dancing performances.
Executive Chef Andrew Duggan serves up modern Australian meals overlooking Wynyard Park.
An authentic Brazilian churrasceria serving up expertly chargrilled meats including lingüiça (sausage) and camarão (prawns), plus Latin American-inspired cocktails like Pisco Sours and Caipirinhas.
content.openingtimes: Lunch Wed-Sun 12pm-3pm, Dinner Wed, Thurs & Sun 6pm-10pm, Fri & Sat 6pm-12.30am

content.description: Mediterranean dishes meet French culinary flair under head chef Michael Chun’s creative direction. Feast on the all day breakfast menu, light lunches or bistro-style evening meals.
A relaxed, family-friendly restaurant that specialises in pizza, pasta, seafood and steaks. It’s fully licensed and BYO, and also does takeaway meals and can provide catering services.
content.openingtimes: Dinner Mon-Sun from 5pm, Lunch Thurs & Fri from 12pm

content.description: Inside The Hughenden Hotel’s Victorian terrace setting, head chef Kat Medina serves up elegant yet hearty country dishes with a twist at the recently refurbished Quaife’s restaurant and bar.

Attention all food lovers.. Learn the culinary skill at this cooking school in the Hills District. The three hour, hands-on classes include wine matching and the opportunity to eat your trophies at the end with a celebration at the dining table.

address.street: The Entertainment Quarter, G Driver Ave
The Entertainment Quarter, G Driver Ave

content.description: This family-friendly restaurant offers both contemporary and traditional Italian dishes, and a particularly extensive range of desserts.

Taking it's name from a financial district in New Delhi, this restaurant finds itself in the slightly more relaxed surrounds of an atmospheric 19th century villa. The menu boasts all of your favourite dishes from all over India.
A modern European bistro-style menu, alfresco and indoor dining areas plus a solid wine list featuring local and foreign drops make Saveur a local haunt amongst the upper north shore crowd.
This house of worship is host to a range of activities from music and art to charitable missions.
The Time Out Office on Level 1.

In the heart of trendy Newtown sits this cozy cafe. A bountiful menu of Australian fare is offered, not to mention the extensive dessert menu sure to be a salivation provoker. This Newtown den is also host to music gigs and art shows.

Give a good old blasting without the bruises. Let off the steam and run around like children (or warriors of the dark world) in the activity you didn't think of. Laser Siege will provide skirmish fun for kids parties through to corporate events.

Grab a fine brew while you're clipped, trimmed and shaved at this traditional grooming house. Grand Royal Barbers is a staple salon for men, located in the heart of Sydney - it is bringing the longstanding barber tradition to the 21st Century.

You may be able to burn a steak like no other, but how would you go with a duck a l'orange? Cooking is not just a realm of matriarchal skill; these classes facilitate a smooth gateway into the too often intimidating likes of the gourmet kitchen.
Perfect shoulder points, measured collar bones, width, length, balance and double stitching. No fabric gaping will convolute here as you are suited up to a T at this bespoke tailor.
Exhibiting provocative uncensored artworks with an indigenous influence.
This old school ballroom built around 100 years ago is now an arts venue.

Welcome to Neutral Bay Bar and Dining: the new restaurant from Glebe Point Diner chef Alex 'Kearnsy' Kearns, with RJ Lines in the kitchen and Jake 'the Pirate' Smyth on the floor. So is it another Glebe Point Diner? Not exactly. For a lot people (Time Out included), half the fun of going to the 'Diner is people-watching and table-hopping – it's like one big party. In the Neutral Bay dining room the high, smooth, undulating wooden booths - each joined with a space to hold cutlery, napkins and glassware – mean you can't see what's going on around you. Then again, they also mean that no one can see you. The bar, however, is all tiled and open-plan, so you have the choice. And unlike Glebe Point Diner, Neutral Bay Bar and Dining has a proper bar with dedicated seating, a great cocktail list and a separate menu of bar snacks. Kearnsy first made his mark on Sydney by cooking up that artfully simple stuff people were lining up for in their hordes at Glebe Point Diner. And though the carte is a little different than GPD, there's still that clarity and simplicity evident in dishes such as the snapper broth – feather-light with pieces of lightly poached fish in the mix – adorned with a single strip of crisped-up fish skin. Fried green tomatoes topped with ricotta and a drizzle of balsamic are more just a texture thing, and I'm still not convinced they shouldn't be left to chutney. That said, the dish is fresh and crunchy. Oh, and give the flat iron steak a go. Known as oyster blade in Australia, it's a cut you very rarely see in restaurants, which is a shame because it's awesome. Pair it with the silverbeet sauteed with garlic and chilli, or some of their chunky handcut chips. There are a couple of mainstays that have travelled over the bridge, such as the crisp, lightly fried Spencer Gulf squid and aioli. Little things like Pino's nduja (hot and spicy pork paste) spread over thin toast are an excellent way to start the meal, with a cocktail on the side, such as their Blood and Sand (here, it's a smoky mix of Ardbeg whisky, cherry brandy, blood orange juice and Martini Rosso). Or save your dram for after your meal and have the Starry Starry Night (Highland Park whisky, Cognac, absinthe and bitters). If you're propping up the bar, make sure to get the little spicy deep-fried winglets - oh, baby. Dessert-wise, we like the tiny sweets (or petits fours, if you want to get fancy) such as the mandarin nougat and passionfruit jubes, but we're not so sold on the blood orange and pistachio tart with its slightly gummy-yet-dry pastry. Neutral Bay Bar and Dining might not have quite the same magic as its sister restaurant, but we've gotta tell you: north of the bridge has never looked so tasty. Myffy Rigby

entry.name: Trains Planes and Automobiles - Mount Victoria

version.name: Trains Planes and Automobiles - Mount Victoria

content.description: Release your inner child with an incredible selection of model trains, planes and, um, automobiles. Plus all sorts of 50s and 60s Americana. Savvy staff can help beginning collectors get started and can provide something special for even the most experienced aficionados.
Once a Quarantine Depot during WW1, now a lush park with bush walks and harbour views.

Plot your next corporate takeover or political coup over a bowl of penne Bolognese at Machiavelli. Every heavy hitter has eaten here at one time or another, from "Aussie" John Symonds to Julia Gillard – each with a larger-than-life photo on the wall to mark the occasion. The restaurant's been open 22 years now offering the likes of steak Diane (a Machiavelli signature) and crepes Suzette. The dining room is 95 per cent older-man-in-suit. Get power dressed, grab a seat in the corner and start scheming.

Max Brenner was 10-years-old when he read Roald Dahl’s Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and vowed to one day make a river of chocolate and sail on it. Today, you can sail from Circular Quay to Max’s Manly temple and live that dream because this café-cum-shop is where childhood fantasies come true.
Paddock meets plate at these markets where visiting gourmands can indulge in organic cheeses, olive oils and fresh flowers from local farmers.

A favourite with film costumers, this extraordinary collection of reasonably priced vintage clothing from the 30s to 70s, is purveyed and displayed by Jeanette Luke, a collector for 30 years, fab former go-go dancer and mother to well known Sydney burlesque stars Gypsy and Amelia Wood.

The Art Gallery of New South Wales is the leading museum of art in New South Wales and Sydney, and one of Australia's foremost cultural institutions. It holds significant collections of Australian, European and Asian art, and presents nearly 40 exhibitions annually.
New Japanese restaurant from the owners of Busshari and Gari.

Beachside beer drinkers on Bondi's main drag can now enjoy German hospitality complete with surfer-friendly early morning breakfasts, lengthy communal timber benches and outdoor seating to soak up the sunshine.
Authentic Austrian hospitality complete with home cooked German fare and steins of all sorts of imported beers. Take the 1kg schnitzel-eating challenge if you're game.

address.street: Northern shores of Lake Burley Griffin
Northern shores of Lake Burley Griffin

content.description: Commonwealth Park, situated on the north side of Lake Burley Griffin is the home of the annual spring Floriade festival. The gardens were designed by the British landscape designer, Dame Sylvia Crowe in 1964.

New South American restaurant from Ben Milgate and Elvis Abrahanowicz of Bodega. Porteno opened on Tuesday 14 September and is sure to be the hottest booking in town for the next few weeks. Full review coming soon.
Busy local cafe with Campos Coffee, breakfast served all day and fresh salads. Service is quick and bruschetta with roasted tomatoes and feta cheese the pick on the menu.

Food writer and broadcaster Sheridan Rogers conducts cooking classes for both adults and children. Adults cooking classes are available at a time of your choice for groups of up to 10. Kids cooking classes are held during the school holidays for groups of 8-12, and on last Sunday of the month. Team building classes are also available. Book through Sheridan Rogers.

Little Spoons cooking classes are designed for children aged from two years to teens. Typical classes run for one hour and promise to offer facts about healthy foods while preparing and enjoying practical hands-on cooking activities.

Tiddlers offers fun 90-minute food clinics for three to 11 year olds that'll have the grommet gastronomes making everything from sushi to lamingtons. Cupcakes, cookies and doughnuts are the most popular creations.

Sparkle Cupcakery make and bake their cupcakes from scratch every day. Each cake is hand finished and topped with a splash of colour. Book a private soiree with canapes, cupcakes and champagne or order 'cupcakes for a cause' in support of a local not-for-profit organisation.
This traditional Italian ristorante spans three levels in an historic sandstone building in the heart of The Rocks.
The BBQ Grill takes centre stage here and is the feature of the kitchen. The Subterranean Grill provides traditional Greek and Mediterranean delicacies. Located in GPO.
content.openingtimes: Lunch Mon-Fri 12 noon-3pm; Dinner Mon-Wed 6-9.30pm; Thu-Sat 6-10pm
Breakfast Daily 7-10am; Lunch Fri-Sun 12 noon-3pm; Dinner Tue - Sat 4.30-9.30pm

content.description: An inner city lane occasionally used for public art installations.
An inner city lane occasionally used for public art installations.
An inner city lane occasionally used for public art installations.
An inner city lane occasionally used for public art installations.

Want to know the future of Sydney eating? It's regional Chinese food. Yunanese. Hunanese. Xiang Jiang. Uighur. And, of course, Sichuan. Just take a walk up the top end of Dixon Street and you'll see what we're talking about. Grills. Noodles. Whole chickens doused in hot chilli. Sweet buns barbecued and filled with squid. But back to Spicy Sichuan. There's a version in Glebe already but this one, which you'll find on Cunningham Street in the CBD, is far superior. It's also very fancy. The upstairs restaurant is all sandstone and wood carvings and murals. Oh, and the waitstaff are incredibly friendly and no one tells you you've ordered too much food or anything's ‘too spicy' (code for the good stuff they don't want you to order). And chefs Zhang Xinrong and Li Xian are doing some incredibly spicy food. Their version of ma po tofu is a lifechanger - absolutely riddled with Sichuan pepper that's so fresh that it fizzes with soft tofu interwoven with pork mince and redolent with chilli. That old favourite of cubed-then-deep-fried chicken bits nested in a sea of dried chilli and Sichuan peppercorns is on the menu, with the almost-druggy effect of the pepper combined with the whole dried chillies and little pieces of chicken hidden like jewels. It's all about picking through all that hot and numbing danger for the tasty (and surprisingly, not very hot) chicken bits. How about a fried corn pancake? Basically a big pile of corn bound by a light batter then fried, it's so sweet you might eat it as a dessert. Steamed buns can be eaten sweet with the little bowl of accompanying condensed milk but you might try ordering the twice-cooked pork with pickled vegetables and making your own pork rolls. Myffy Rigby
Buy, taste and learn about premium food at Signorelli Gastronomia. Not just a store, they run regular cooking classes for adults and kids alike.
Surf and fashion store.
Located on the King Street less traveled, Scraggs is good for accessories and clothing.
One of best op-shop hunting grounds in Sydney where you can pick up $4 mens’ brogue shoes, a $35 push-bike and almost anything else.
Come here for oddities, collectables and bric-a-brac to decorate your house.
Great for books and records.
A great spot for some second-hand pieces, shoes and books.
A Smith Family store with a penchant for obtaining some brilliant denim and leather pieces. The manchester is good too, so pick up some 70s patterned towels for your next trip to the pool.
Following on from the success of Dank St Depot, Jared Ingersoll's new restaurant combines laid back surrounds atmosphere with an exciting menu from head chef Penny Williams.

White and yellow striped awnings mark this quaint deli and welcome you to an enticing range of cheese, meat, pastries and antipasto delights. Overflowing on weekends with beach regulars and mates of the owner, Deli Bottega caters to the hungry from morning through to night. When the moon draws nigh, Bottega flashes its newly attained license and transforms in to a wine bar to make sweet sweet love to that cheese platter that has been staring you down from the deli cabinet.

This all-Australian burger chain signals a revolution with the lot. Grill’d boil the burger down to basics – not too big, not too expensive – and take it stratospheric with zinging ingredients sourced from small, family producers.
Each of their 18 burgers has a distinct personality. And a conscience. Buns are gluten- free; eggs are free-range; beef, lamb and chicken is fresh, never frozen. Ethics aside, these burgers taste gooood. Is it the lean Aussie chuck ground thrice with herbs and relish? The cool pop art on the walls? Or is it the share tables, the beer fridge or late opening? Whatever. Burgers are back!

Lotforty is the newest tapas restaurant to spring from the food-fertile turf of Darlinghurst. This cosy little hole-in-the-wall specialises in great food, fine wines and cocktails by candlelight and offers a relaxed yet vibrant atmosphere perfect for big groups of friends.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Thu 5-11pm; Fri 12 noon-11pm (lunch booking essential); Sat-Sun 5-11pm

content.description: Their 'Little Piggy' burger has pulled pork, corn puree, grated apple and aioli. Oink!
Bondi's newest sourdough bakery has so alluring an aroma that you won't want to leave.
Wheat- and gluten-free bread, lamingtons and quiches. Rejoice, coeliacs!
Seasonal grass-fed meats sourced direct from farms.

What is it? A patisserie serving European and Middle Eastern sweets. Sea Sweet is a well-known brand name in Lebanon – this is the first outlet in Australia. What's it like? Sleek and modern. The shop is split in two with European desserts on the left, Middle Eastern sweets and biscuits on the right. The decor is a mix of chocolate browns and shiny whites. You'll find a small number of tables at the back but most locals prefer to sit outside, nursing traditional brass pots of muddy Arabic coffee and watching the world pass on by. Newcomers will appreciate the detailed labelling and descriptions on every dessert. Takeaway is significantly cheaper than eating in. What should I order? Knefe cheese ($13.90 eat-in/$7.90 takeaway) is a cheeseburger made for sweet tooths. Take one ka'ak sesame bun, slick the insides with syrup and then sandwich around a generous square of creamy knefe cheese coated with semolina. A quick grill results in a toasted sesame bun with a stretchy-sweet core of syrup-laden molten cheese. What else? Kashta (thick clotted cream) is celebrated here in an endless choice of desserts. You'll find it hiding under pastry, layered between shortbread and wrapped in pint-sized, fluffy pancakes. Sea Sweet might be the only place in Sydney to serve kashta ice cream ($14.90); you may detect a subtle yoghurt tang beneath the pistachio nuts. Otherwise go all the way and order the Beirut Delight ($14.90), an island of pure kashta cream smothered with honey and a tumble of crushed pistachios. You'll also find kashta on top of the fruit cocktail ($14.90), a refreshing fruit salad piled in a parfait glass atop a bed of smooth avocado puree that works a treat. Does everything come with kashta? No. Chocolate beklava is a modern twist on a traditional favourite, with chocolate-flavoured filo pastry drizzled with stripes of chocolate icing. Grab half a kilo of baklava take away for $13.90 – by the time you get homw you should be ready for more. Helen Yee
Formerly Fairfield City Farm.
A specialist store selling Japanese food and knives for chefs and home cooks.

Boobs as far as the eye can see. Nudie pictures from old magazines in the toilets. This is Eathouse Diner - a new addition to the increasingly civilised Redfern that's surprisingly saucy. You could be in a tattoo parlour, you could be in a bordello. In fact, we wouldn't be surprised to see the incredibly attractive waitstaff speeding by on rollerskates.The Redfern gentry and their offspring are already packing it out, clamouring for space in the violently turquoise room. And in case the pram blight gets to be a little much, find a spot at the long, red Formica bar overhung by a tilted mirror – you can see what everyone else is eating. Or look down their tops. As to what's on the plate, that's where the operation falls down a little. You can partially forgive it, given the place is more of a scene than an eating destination. Age Durrant and Selena Murray are banging the pans and we've heard rumblings that someone in the kitchen has spent time working at Sean's Panaroma. Indeed, there are a few dishes on the menu you might recognise from the popular beachside restaurant, such as the borscht, which they're calling beetroot and smoked paprika soup with kipflers. The version here is a lot more potato than beetroot, garnished with a whole boiled kipfler and sour cream. And unlike the Sean's version, it's served warm. Still, it's a bargain for $13. We're also keen to go back during the day to try the coffee and the pulled pork sanga. We're hearing good things about their Philly cheesesteak, too.Lamb shanks are definitely worth ordering: tender hunks of meat fall off the bone after a long, gentle braise tempered with the salty pop of capers, a fine sprinkling of fresh mint, all on a bed of pea mash. Beef cheeks are as you'd expect: dark, glossy and extremely rich. They're given a spruce up with a scattering of rainbow chard pieces, served on fennel puree. There's also a vego chilli (sans carne) on the menu, which is basically a bowl of bean mix with a separate bowl of sour cream and a big pile of corn chips with lime halves. It's great party food for the middle of the table and a foil for the beers, including Time Out fave, Whale Ale. Speaking of party food, make sure to order dessert. Consider the good old-fashioned banana split complete with a gold cocktail umbrella, or the dulce de leche and strawberry sundae with vanilla ice cream, caramel sauce, fresh strawberries and a wafer, all topped with shavings of toasted coconut. Eathouse Diner might not be pushing boundaries when it comes to the food but it's definitely one of the best designed rooms in town. Mark it up as another win for Redfern. Myffy Rigby
content.openingtimes: Lunch Tue-Fri 12 noon–2pm; Sat 10am- 2pm; Sun 10am–2pm. Dinner Tue–Fri 6pm-10pm; Sat 6pm–10pm

content.description: On top of the free pool and juke box on Sundays and Tuesdays, Mansions also features an Indiana Jones pinball machine.
The Winston has recently undergone major renovations and includes an outdoor terrace, bar and dining areas (with a large wine list) and bottleshop.
The Rag and Famish Hotel is a classic Australian heritage hotel set over two levels with bars, bistro, fine dining restaurant, outdoor garden and function areas.
Located in the back streets of Balmain, The Royal Oak Hotel has a neighbourhood feel, not to mention a large wine list and great range of local and imported beers on tap.
After a 3 year closure for renovations the Dee Why Hotel has finally reopened with a new fitout by the architects who designed Establishment and Hugos.
Housed within a heritage cellar and inspired by New York's chic steak restaurants, The Cut Bar & Grill offers the finest cuts of Australian beef and sustainable seafood.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri lunch and dinner; Sat & Sun dinner
